description:
Super cute, convenient internet cafe in the middle of the city. Love the industrial look. 

Pro: Nice food selection. (I ordered avocado toast with charred green onion schmear, cucumber ribbons, super seed crunch and fried capers on firebrand sesame bread). 

Con: have to pay to use their expensive wifi which is timed. Hours they are open are limited.
author: Jessi J.

description:
Sure, I'll buy your overpriced, bougie-a** breakfast burrito. But it *has to actually* be good. If you're gonna claim there's bacon in there, then i should be able to see at least an entire strip of bacon in there. Bacon bits or bacon crumbs *do not* count! 

Also, your expensive SFbreakfast burrito shouldn't be premade and reheated at the prices you're charging. Make that sh*t fresh, you feel me?! You can't charge me $8 for a snack size, made the night before, bacon bits, more tortilla than egg- burrito! That breaks ALL the burrito codes!

And finally- i just gotta ask- mayo? Really? Oh wait, it's *chipotle* mayo. No. No no no no. You don't dip a breakfast burrito in mayo. It's salsa you're looking for- or add even kimchi- but not mayo! Why?!

You do have good coffee, nice baristas and a chill place to grade papers- even if im the *only* one grading actual papers. But fix that burrito!
author: Chriss L.

description:
First of all, the first 10 hr is free. So there is no excuse not to give this work-perience a try.

*** Workspace ***
Yes you pay to sit here, but it is worth it. Plenty of seat variety, from couch to tables to nooks and tables in closets, it is easy to work solo or haul your group in.

*** Coffee ***
Standard SF coffee (none of that Seattle's 'Best'). I got the cold brew and for the price, I received a generous portion. All in all, the coffee prepared here will complement your work and powers you through it.

*** Food ***
Pricey with good portion, but as a health nut, I appreciate the variety of healthy options from sweet and savory. They are all cooked perfectly and seasoned well. No complains here! 

Coupling the convenience with the functional and spacious workspace, as well as the food-coffee selection, Workshop Cafe at FiDi's branch is a dependable place you can hole up in through a workload hurricane.
author: Priscilla M.

description: This place is everything. Great chill place get stuff done. My new spot to focus on my future plans.
author: Juan V.

description: This is one of my go-to places to work. Unlike your typical "coffee shop with free Wifi" you have to pay for a spot here. In truth you're paying for a variety of comfortable seating options and super fast WiFi. Who among us has not gone to our local coffeeshop and been frustrated by the speed of internet? I find that personally I get more work done here because everyone around seems to be in a work mind set as opposed to socializing. Not of the food options have ever enticed me (I get food from other places and bring it) but I have gotten the wine happy hour which is a tad bit overpriced. This place is very SF and with that comes inflated prices but overall, this is a good options if you like to work remotely or outside of your office.
author: Sharvari J.

description:
I'm gonna start by saying this place is SOO SF. 

I really like that the coffee is strong and they make the work space look like a We Work. You walk in and pick any place you want to sit, register your seat and you can work till they close. Don't like you seat? Move and find on you want! It's really nice how you aren't tied to just one spot. You can reserve private rooms, they even provide computers! The catch? You get the first 10 hours of work for free, after that you get charged per hour.  So SF, am I right? 

The pros to working here out weigh the hourly charge for the space, thank goodness. I ordered a glass of wine on happy hour and they delivered it to my work spot, how cool!  I also got a HUGE iced latte for like 6 bucks, worth it! 

This place is rad, and the free hours roll over so catch you next week Workshop cafe!
author: Nicole K.

description:
Your first 10 hours of work here are free, so I'd give four stars for the first 10 hours. After that, maybe 3 stars.

Yep, you have to pay to work here. It is a nice space, with plenty of outlets, fast WiFi, and great coffee, but the seats are definitely not comfy enough to deserve $2-$3 per hour. If you aren't coming to work, there are free places to sit near the entrance, but you are not allowed to use laptops there.

That being said, while I wouldn't frequent this place due to the cost, it's definitely worth going for a one-off work session. The avocado toast is aesthetic af and includes cucumber ribbons and capers, which is somewhat unique. Coffee, as mentioned earlier, is pretty darn good. And most importantly, there are outlets!
author: Serena J.

description:
This place attracts the crowd for sure!

Pros
------
# Wi-Fi - quick in connection
# Separate space for people who wanna spend time working at this location with lots of power sockets.
# Separate meeting rooms for meetings/ group discussions I believe so.
# Great eating area with good outdoor tables/chairs
# Good service by the employees to people seated outside
# Attentive cashier and quick drinks service too.
# Clean cafe, filled-in refrigerator
# Bran cake was delicious

Grows
--------
# I drank Hot chocolate from here and it was okish only. I had less sweetness compared to other coffee houses I've had so far, which was perfect for me. The drink's texture was a bit watery. Not sure whether this is how they prepare, but I prefer slightly thicker/stronger ones

I might try to visit Workshop Cafe FiDi again if I'm in the neighborhood and prefer to check-in!
author: Ramyaa V.

description:
Really cool place! The food and coffee is good plus I LOVE the coffee shop / startup workspace vibe...inspiring. Feels like a stereotypical SF tech Place (in a good way). It's unique and spacious! 

Also they are QUICK which is so nice! Some coffee places take their sweet time - but this place is convenient!
author: Alex H.

description: This place is pretty interesting! The menu is limited, and it's very expensive, but it's really more of a workspace, with a bonus café. The coffee was expensive, it was three dollars. And you had to refill it yourself at the self-serve coffee station. And that cost three dollars as well! However, if you want to meet someone here for a business meeting, or casual place to grab a coffee, you need to charge your phone, or maybe bust out a quick paper... This is the place to go! There was a clear separation between the workspace in the café area. There were signs that said you could not pull your laptop out in the café. But, you could use it outside if you really needed to check work documents or something on your laptop.
author: April C.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday afternoon after an interview to chill and escape the reality that I'd have to go back to Berkeley sooner rather than later. I'd say there's 3+ sections in the Workshop Cafe. The first is the outdoor area/patio. There are probably around 20 seats outside with tables to hang out, chat, and do work. You don't have to pay to work here. The second is an indoors area still before the paid point, which is where I did work after grabbing my coffee. The third is the pay-to-work area further in (and around) -- this is a sizable space with plenty of seating and outlets. There are even rooms I assume you can book or reserve.

The line when I entered was pretty short -- just two people in front of me, with one cashier handling transactions and several more employees working in the kitchen. This would be fast, or so I thought -- I waited in line for around 15 minutes as the person in front of me set up a room reservation with the cashier and the other employees twiddled thumbs in the back. I finally ordered my usual -- small black coffee -- and received an empty cup from the cashier. To the right was a steel canister to self-serve the coffee. That would have been fine, but the canister was empty. I notified another employee, who looked at me and sort of snapped that he'd get to that later. I sat down with a half cup of coffee and waited for the employee to switch out the canisters. He politely let me know.

I hung out here for about an hour or two. I realized the caffeine had gone through me but that as a non-pay-to-work customer, I didn't have access to the restrooms. I left to find a restroom elsewhere.

Overall, wouldn't really come back here unless necessary. The service and staff are a bit slow and unfriendly, the atmosphere isn't too great because (as a non-pay-to-work customer) you can see everyone else with access to outlets, restrooms, comfy seating, etc. that you get. The coffee is coffee, and I'm sure I can find a better cafe elsewhere.
author: Rahul R.

description: I really like this concept and work area. Pretty spacious, plenty of work tables, work lounge areas, a couple private rooms, free wifi, and easy access to electric outlets of course. Two additional really nice things about this place is that they give you the first 10 hours of work time here for free and have a pretty good cafe with a selection of breakfast items, salads, sandwiches, light bites. Happy hour is 3-7pm everyday with $2 off wine, $1 off beer, and a couple of combo items (meat, cheese, wine; beer, pretzel, cheese). Great work spot.
author: Will H.

description:
Came here to work on a Tuesday afternoon and found the space to conducive for what I need to get done. I stayed for maybe 5 hours and got a good deal of work done thanks to the vibe and fairly comfy space. 

The check in process is easy. As a newbie, I found the directions clear and planted myself at an open spot. The ordering for food is easy (go to counter or order on your phone). I ended up starting with a nonfat chai latte, a bit bland for my taste. As the day wore on, I refueled on kombucha and a cookie. Wish there are more light snack options to help recharge. The sandwiches looked good, but not what I'm looking for as I'm working.
author: Elizabeth F.

description: This place was perfect for catching a few hours of work while in the city on business. The app makes ordering/paying simple. The back area was the most quiet but pretty hot as I didn't notice any air conditioning.
author: Colleen S.

description:
Stumptown coffee was proudly served here, making it different from elsewhere. It also had a large space inside, that one could use to study or work.

However it took them a long time to get my coffee ready, and they messed up my latte art!!
author: Elaine H.

description:
This place oozes productivity juices - Stumptown coffee, more than plenty outlets, great study/focus playlist, monitors and printers if needed, reservable seats/tables/rooms (even standing desk spaces!), and a cafe ordering system via text or email so you never have to get up for food - just keep working. 

The staff is super nice. They even have ppl seated by the entrance who help you set up if they see that half confused/half amazed look on your face upon entering. 

They really try to switch up the seatings so that it caters to whichever style you like to work. For example, I focus best with high ceilings and corners of a long table. They had that. There's sofas, round tables, rooms with white boards, etc. I didn't even finish scoping out all the spaces cause I looked like a lost tourist staring at everyone working hard core. 

First three hours are free! After that, it's a subscription of hours (5 hrs for $15 and up to 40 hrs for $80).  Personally I think putting a price tag to my work minutes helps me focus faster and harder..or else I'm just snapping away on social media. Which I did anyway bc I was too excited.
author: Jing Y.

description: Like the space but coffee was cold and the having been closing earlier the last couple of days
author: elizabeth t.

description:
Don't get food here. Way over priced,
But one of my favorite places to work out of if you're visiting sf since you get 10 free hours
author: Jenel M.

description:
tl;dr don't come here if your phone is broken.

I came here to work while my cell phone was being fixed. After I paid for some orange juice, the staff told me that to get a free 3-hour block to work at the cafe, they needed to verify my phone number-- but my phone was broken! The only other option was to pay $3.50/hour for a "manual timeshare". The staff were courteous and the space looked amazing, but it wasn't worth the cost for me.
author: Matthew M.

description:
After seeing a line outside the door at Philz, I searched for coffee shops in the area and decided to try Workshop Cafe instead since it's been on my bookmarks for a while. 

I ordered a mocha and the latte art was great! The concept of this cafe was really interesting. After you order, you can reserve a table by entering the number of the table you choose in the Workshop Cafe online app. The app also allows you to order food to your table and view the names and a bio of other guests. These features made me feel like I was on Virgin America plane. 

The first 3 hours of internet are free but if you don't want to pay for internet, you can choose a table outside. There is an indoor open seating area, but it is computer-free. I was very impressed by the work space and will definitely be returning to get work done and use my remaining internet credits.
author: Karen L.

description:
One of those "only in SF" kind of places.

Came here on a weekend to grind it out and was surprised it was pretty busy even on a Sunday afternoon. Love the convenience of the app for payment, and that there's both spaces facing the register where it seems you don't have to pay by the hour, and the large workspace in the back.

Food selection is great too- and I was impressed by the selection of both food and drinks. I know it's kind of weird to pay to sit but, there's definitely something motivating about grinding it out with a bunch of other people just as passionate and maybe a little cray like you too.

Also had the nooch popcorn delivered. It was yummy and well popped! I hate hitting kernels so both me and my teeth were thankful.

Would definitely come back :)
author: Jackie C.

description: I've been going her for 2+ years now and it's always a good bet for getting work done. They always play interesting music too!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Workshop is the bomb.com and a great place to get some work done in the city-

The first 10 hours of work here are free and then I think it's $2 or $3 an hour after that. When you arrive at Workshop you'll "check" in, and then you can use their app (or just the web if you don't want to download it) to manage your stay. The cool thing about the app is that you can order food from it, so if you're feeling pretty lazy and/or dedicated to your work you never even have to get up.

Workshop also has a good cafe as well and the prices are really awesome. I had scrambled eggs with avocado which was just over FIVE dollars. How awesome is that???

I would definitely recommend coming to get some work done here as it's centrally located, has great amenities and an overall sick vibe. It is a taddddd bit louder than some other co-working spaces so if you need complete silence to work may not be your first pick but if you can handle some slight ambient noise you'll really love it.
author: Elliott W.

description:
I freaking LOVE this place. 

My boyfriend has classes in SF every once and awhile, and I like to tag along so I can come up to the city. I always need a place to get some work done and this place is amazing!!!

There are tons of seats and tons of outlets, which normal coffee shops are always lacking. It's also very affordable if you need a place to work out of for a few hours ($2-$3/hour-ish), and don't want to pay a monthly fee for something like WeWork. They have conference/quiet rooms if you need to reserve them for a meeting or group project.

They have beer, and wine, and some great food! I love the avocado toast. They even have an app that lets you check in/out, reserve a seat, buy more hours, and the BEST PART: get food delivered right to your seat. This is random, but they have REALLY nice napkins. They are super thick and don't rip like any other napkin would. 

Even the music in this place is great. I even follow their playlist on Spotify, that's how good it is!

Why only 4 stars if it is so amazing? 

I've been here 10+ times, and unfortunately, EVERY time I come here I order food/wine, and EVERY time there are fruit flies trying to attack. Every. Single. Time. To the owner: order a glass of chardonnay and some avo toast and sit in the second booth on the left once you get into the workspace (that's where I usually sit, but it happens to me no matter where I sit). Have it sitting on your table for a little bit and you'll see exactly what I'm talking about. 

That's not going to stop me from coming back -- seriously love this place -- but they should really look into it.
author: Audrey M.

description:
Ordered the Classic Breakfast bowl that came with smoked salmon, eggs, avo, arugula, feta. 

Underwhelming at best. Their eggs reminded me of what I get at Mc Donald's - square shaped and firm like it came out of a pre-packaged made egg that they cut up.

For a $10 bowl it was a ripoff.
author: Sue C.

description:
Got a bagel here to go. 15 minutes later I received a boxed, open faced bagel with "hummus" that was more like tahini - very thin and runny. I was unable to take this and eat it on the "go" and had to waste my time making a mess of myself before I left.

It's a bagel. Don't be cute with it. Put toppings on it. Wrap it up. Give it to me. Waste of money. Waste of time.
author: Peter S.

description:
y'all know me whenever i see the words BREAKFAST BURRITO i automatically ignore the other 99% of the menu n go straight for the gizzoods

hotpocketesque crispish texture kinda fun, surprisingly nonorange sweet potatoes (http://bit.ly/1xnoTmE) kinda fun, overall small tho more like a snack than a meal #twss. had to keep reminding myself there's meat in there #twss

from outside this place already hints at spaciousness but inside goes way tf past the foodservice counter to hegga work tables then glass wall work areas. kinda like a small library but instead of books there's food
author: Dan B.

description: It's a cool concept though the music is a tad loud. Went in on the free hours, not sure if it'd be a go to once they start charging per hour.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I came here a twice, once to meet up with someone and talk about business and another time I was hungry and needed a quick snack togo. 

When I first came here, I was pretty confused with signing up and making sure I log in my times before I go in. Not sure if I dig that, maybe I'm just slow haha, I prefer something like Capital One, where it's quick and easy and free. However, this is a very cute cafe to study and do work. They have a great selection of food and snacks that are quite delicious. I ordered a Chicken Hapa Salad togo and I loved it! Super fresh and colorful. I wouldn't come here to study/work, but definitely getting a quick togo snack next time is an option!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Awful experience here, came on a thursday night to do some work. Ordered a tea and a bagel. While deciding whether or not I wanted the bagel with my coworkers, the cashier snapped "So do you want the bagel or not?" quite rudely at our group. Not to mention he completely forgot the tea so 20 min after we sat down we had to go back and ask for the status of it. 

Then this greedy business model of seating is one of the stingiest things I've ever seen in SF. Paying customers don't even get to sit and work for free in the "workspace" section. Moreover, they charge per person, so when me and my two coworkers (3 total people) were sharing 2 tables they demanded us sign into 3 seats. Way to disincentive people to share space so that you could potentially fit more paying customers. Maybe next time I'll come in with 10 people but all sit at a different table so no one else can work there. Just kidding, I'm never coming back here again.
author: Alex H.

description: I had Avocado Toast and a Decaf Americano. It was my first time checking in here. The staff is very helpful. There're plenty of space for work with free WiFi.
author: Juthaluk N.

description: One of the saddest breakfast I've ever had. Bland, dry and made with no love. Very disappointed.
author: Rommel Q.

description: Non-compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act. I was denied access to the cafe because I had a certified service animal accompanying me. I provided documentation (not required by law) to prove the certification status of the service animal, but was still denied access. The behavior of the staff was rude and unacceptable -- they pulled me out of a ongoing meeting specifically to interrogate me about my disability. Unprofessional, unethical, and illegal.
author: Alan D.

description:
Pros:
- Really good food, actually. Surprisingly good for a cafe. The prosciutto salad is killer. So is the date smoothie and the pineapple parfait.
- Great workspace. Quiet, with electric outlets everywhere and decent seating. Good, subtle music.
- Nice staff.

Cons:
- A $2-3 fee per hour just to sit there feels kind of expensive, especially when you're buying like $20+ worth of coffee and food while you're there anyway.
author: John L.

description:
I was blamed today for a mistake in their buggy app, and their staff of ragtag seat-fascists kicked us out mid-call of the room we'd booked and paid for.

They told us we'd been in the room an hour longer than we were. Then, instead of accepting their app was wrong (or checking the cameras) they accused us of lying and kicked us out, as if we can't tell how long a 20 minute call has been. I'm angry enough at the campaign against facts in this country; I don't need these chumps telling me what I know to be false is true!

I WILL NOT support a business that blames their paying customers for their own mistakes (and calls them liars to boot), and I urge you not to support them either.
author: Arel C.

description:
Interesting and needed.

I spent about 30min prior wandering around the area, freezing my face off, looking for a coffee shop that had seating and internet so I could work. This place was good for me, but it would've been nice if there were more private areas for conference calls too.

I stuck around town after a conference and needed a place to work for the day. Most places were packed and had very little counter space. I came across a bunch of places that were encouraging face to face meetings only, which is great but terrible at the same time.
author: M M.

description:
Come here to work all the time and usually sit for a stretch of 8-10 hours! 

Perfect workspace, with great coffee and food. Excellent seating. Highly recommended if you're around the city and want a place to work.
author: Aditya G.

description:
Love this place!  I visited really quickly and just got a coffee while I caught up with some friends.  

There's plenty of seating, wifi, and outlets everywhere.

I got the standard drip coffee, and it was actually really good and strong.  One cup around noon kept me awake and alert all day (and night).  

I wish I could've tried their food too, as it looked great, but that will be for next time!
author: Nisha S.

description: Three stars because no one is around to clean up anything. They have like 4 people behind the counter, one guy eating while everyone is waiting for their order which takes forever. I asked for a bagel scooped with cream cheese. First I asked the girl what this particular cream cheese was, spicy she said and said she'd give me a taste. Well, I ended up getting regular on my bagel because she never brought it until I went back and asked. So she gave me a small side of it. My bf had the eggs with cheese and avocado which was good. No complaints there. A great big workspace and tons of stations for people to come and spend the day working. The egg dish was only 5.50 which was very reasonable. The staff needs help, it seems like there is no owner, manager to really manage this place and it's being run by millenials that have better things to do, like eat and text.
author: Valerie M.

description:
My girlfriend and I were looking for a place to study and found this place by accident. 

To summarize, it's a bunch of working-class yuppies feeling important at an awesome cafe that provides a wonderful working environment. 

I loved being here, the people working intensely working around me made me want to work really hard on something myself, so I decided to make a Valentine's Day reservation, something I wouldn't do at any other cafe!

You have to pay to work here, but to be honest, it's great to be able to reserve a spot to work. Plus, it's only a few dollars to sit there.

Leave the comfort of your own home into a well lit, well-established, and great work environment cafe like Workshop Cafe! You gawd-damn workaholics of SF you.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
I got an expensive tea with tea bag broken so all the tiny pieces of leaves are in the cup

I get it that it's middle of the city and busy and your tired but please serve what's expected.
author: Yuki K.

description:
Nice decor and lots of places to sit.  It seems like a good place to spend a few hours if you have work to do.

The system for checking in to claim a seat requires a phone number and credit card.  I got confused by this - you do not have to check in if you want to sit outside or in their inside lounge.  If you are just looking to get a quick bite and sit down while eating I'd recommend you don't do the full checkin and find a seat in one of those locations.
author: Gautam P.

description: Great drinks for a great price. Quality menu and venue. Be ready to come in and work. If you are here for a chat or just a place to spend time this is not it. You pay by the hour or you sit on the really small tables by the front. They've got strict rules about using laptops only in the work space. Anyway if you want work done with a group this is a great place to work.
author: Meilyn A.

description: First time here and I brought my mom to try the coffee. It was pretty good. I like the Curry Quinoa Wrap I got, and my mom enjoyed the Avo Egg Scramble Bowl. Downside is that I didn't know this wasn't a regular cafe so the majority of the space is for those who rent out the work space. Not much seating for just having a meal, but we enjoyed our meal outside. Only complaint my mom had is that the coffee cups are too small, so she didn't have enough.
author: Jodi T.

description:
A café carved out of an office building lobby that also serves as a paid co-working space. There are a variety of workspaces, whether seats at shared tables, personal armchairs, or more private workspaces and conference rooms. You can purchase time directly from an app, which you can also use to order from their café, which has a surprisingly good selection of food and drink. 

The net result is an environment that has more amenities than, say, the free Capital One café nearby, yet it also feels like a "lite" version of WeWork. If you don't want to pay for your own space, the front of the café is free for everyone, but it consists of only a few backless sofas and you'd be better off going to Capital One, Peet's, or Starbucks. In any case, you can order items from the café without partaking in the shared workspace.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Stopped in for an Avo Scramble: sliced avocado, about 2 eggs, some arugula and olive oil. Simple perfection. Granted I'm more one for some seasoning on the eggs, but you can get this at the condiment bar. $5.50. Can't be beat.

I didn't need the workspaces, but it reminds me of the internet cafes I saw in Europe. Great concept where the workspaces aren't the afterthought for the coffe eshop. 

They have Stumptown coffees and quite the healthy fare if you're avoiding the cakes and scones of your typical coffee shop.
author: Mari H.

description:
Initially I felt I had found my perfect spot in San Francisco to have a breakfast and get some work done. When I entered the place, the barista welcomed me nicely and explained how it all works and the fact that I could get a 10-hour free access to the workspace area where I can eat and work. 

But once I went through the check-in, it would not accept my overseas number and they told me: "it's a beautiful day, why don't you just sit outside!" 

I felt so disrespected. I was happy to even pay the hourly fee but that option was not in place even. Maybe they thought I'm a foreigner and won't be coming back here again so why should they bother! I am very disappointed with my experience. Specially the food (breakfast egg bowl) wasn't great either and there was hair on my salmon
author: Laleh O.

description: I'm from the east coast so the concept of paying for a space at a cafe is odd, however I appreciate when you need to work the ability to have a dedicated outlet. This is a cool concept but the app you use to reserve the space is really buggy. I was in my spot and kept getting texts that I was not there. I also recently looked at the app and it had me signed in and not assigned a seat. Even though I wasn't in a seat it still docked me time. I was surprised because if the app used GPS it would have shown that I was not in the area. This place could do a lot better but the app is really holding it back.
author: David L.

description: Meh. Massively overpriced coffee - when you factor in that a refill is $3 - and snooty vibe. Popped in looking for a place to grab a quick coffee and open my laptop for 15-20 minutes. One has to pay to use the workspaces, which is fine. If I was looking for that I'd give it 4 instead of 3 stars.
author: Plutarco L.

description:
Their toasts.... their toasts are so flipping good!! I actually come up with reasons to come work here just to be able to order the toasts!!

This workshop cafe can either just be a coffee shop with delicious food (if you sit in the front area), or it can be a highly productive workspace with delicious food (if you enter the back workspace area).

When i first came to workshop cafe, i didn't realize i had to download an app to reserve my space. That took all of 1 min and couldn't have been easier. The staff assisted and did a great job explaining. 

You can order food and drinks from your desk on the app, as well as reserve a work station for yourself. You can also walk into the workstation area, find a spot you like, then log in and reserve it. Very flexible! 

The other people working here seem to be focused and polite (both in terms of noise and also not letting their stuff go all over the table). 

All workspace seating options have electrical outlets (snaps for that). Some workstations have large computer screens you can use. Other stations are behind closed doors or are group stations. 

And they have clean bathrooms!
author: Katie V.

description:
Worst breakfast I've ever had in the city. No one knew what they were doing. Cashier was absent from the counter, barista frustrated and remaking drinks while placing order tickets in an order that the server and cook did not understand. Waited 25 minutes for an order of a bagel, avocado egg bowl, and two drinks. Bagel came without cream cheese. Drinks took even longer because they misplaced our ticket. And were you hoping for fresh food? That's not a thing here. I got 5 tiny springs of arugula, a pitiful sprinkle of feta cheese, 5 silvers of avocado, and a handful of rubberized eggs. They don't cook food here. They microwave it. 

Also you have to pay to sit. That's not a quirky SF thing - that's idiotic.
author: Caroline N.

description: Came in early (7:30 am) on a Friday morning after a bootcamp workout next door.  Exactly what I was looking for - chill workplace with food.  I had the avocado scramble bowl (which are about 2 scrambled eggs with feta cheese, avocado and arugula) and had a macchiato with almond milk.  The eggs were priced at $5.5 and were ok. Good healthy option.  They also offer stumptown coffee.  Great place to camp out and work.
author: Erika R.

description: Rotten attitude towards their customers: asked me to leave my seat because it was only for logged-in internet users when (a) normal seats were filled, (b) dozens of internet seats were free so I wasn't blocking anyone, and (c) I'm actually a customer that does pay for internet time on other occasions; I just wasn't that morning because I was running to a meeting. But they officiously asked me to leave my seat. I had bought a coffee but they wouldn't let me sit down.
author: Thunersee V.

description:
From the outside it looks like a good place.  Don't be fooled.  Never any seats unless you pay.  Yes you pay for a workspace.  

Food looks healthy but don't be fooled.  Everything was coated in oil. The sandwich bun was bathed in oil.  The sauce had fat and oil.  Chips oily.
author: Joshua G.

description:
Yesterday morning around 11:10 am (Sep 6th), I went to the Workshop Cafe for a cup of coffee. 
When I saw many people read or studied there, I was interested finding out how their system works and how I can pay to get some studying hours there. During my conversation with the cashier, another customer interrupted and started asking questions. She went on to talk to him, chatting, laughing... Left me standing there for over several minutes! I was shocked by this rude manner, felt very bad of being treated like this!
I walked out this cafe shop and never will be back.
author: Michelle J.

description: Overall nice atmosphere and delicious food but beware that this place is kinda weird. They will charge you $3 per hour for a wooden chair -- even if you order a $20 lunch! You must download their app (asks for location), give your credit card, name, home address and cell phone number to sit there. I think their system might be designed to curb campers but it hurts regular, paying patrons with some sense of privacy. Finally they have wardens who don't mind publicly nagging you that your time is up and you need to pay more to sit or leave now!
author: Ozan B.

description: Cool place. Has outlets in every seat. Good lattes. Good place to get work done, not very comfortable chairs though.
author: Suzanna S.

description:
Been here a couple more times and service, convenience, cleanliness, and everything else about this place has been absolutely great.

I've gotten to try a few more of their food items so thought I'd share:

-Chipotle Chicken Sandwich: Wasn't exactly what I expected but still delicious. The chicken is actually cold and shredded but the flavor is good. The bread has a crisp outer shell though the inside was a bit dried out. Between the slaw, chicken, and bread, there's a slight sweet taste to it all which is balanced out by the cheddar. I do wish there was more cheddar but other than that the flavors work very well. It comes w/ Terra chips which are chips made from a variety of root vegetables. I love root veggie chips but Terra isn't a brand I'm particularly fond of. They seem to have a staleness to them (even the bags I've purchased at stores). 

-Breakfast burrito: So friggin good. I'm very particular about breakfast burritos and this one almost has everything just right. The only bad part is they have those overscrambled fake tasting eggs. Otherwise it's great. Their bacon isn't too salty and has the perfect amount of fat on it. There's not an overwhelming amount of potato and I like that they used white sweet potato which was a bit starchy and only a little sweet. It complimented everything perfectly. The best part is that they fry the tortilla a bit so it's super light and crispy. I will definitely get this again.

Other notes: The inner work room area closes at 9pm but the outer space is open until 10pm
author: Vivian C.

description:
This is really an amazing place. It is so unique for what it is and where it is located. It is centrally located in the financial district. There is a space in the cafe, for you to grab your coffee, eat your breakfast/lunch, and chill with people. THEN there is a back space, aka their "workshop" space where you can have a designated spot for just you to work! It's away from the cafe area, a lot more quiet, and yes the caveat is that there is a charge per hour, I believe? I also believe from there, you can have wait service, where you can order food and drinks and it will be brought to you.

The menu here is quite expansive. It has a good range of everything, coffee, beer, other drinks, breakfast items, pastries, lunch, snack, salad, sandwiches, bowls, etc. This is really a wonderful place. Great idea for whoever came up with it!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
4 stars for their workplace, yet faulty wifi. 3 stars for their sub par/pricey food. 

Since I work really close here, I love studying here as its quiet, convenient, and they have lots of good snacks/drinks. For 2 dollars an hour to work here, it's very affordable, but wish they had better wifi than the nearby Starbucks. 

In terms of food, I have tried the Xushi Bowl, chicken salad, and the roast beef sandwich. All are okay, but there's nothing special about their food. 

The staff is super nice and they try to make sure they serve quality food and drinks, but think they need to be organized especially for bigger orders. It's cool that they are trying to serve more than your regular coffee shop food, but think they need to improve the quality of their menu.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
At first I was skeptical about paying $2 to sit in a cafe, when so many other cafes around don't charge. This is no ordinary cafe,though. And the price is well justified twice over. 

Of all the places I've tried studying/getting work done, this place hits all the points in what I would ideally want: 

- music isn't too loud or overpowering. If you need it to be quieter, go towards the back where the conference rooms are. You can hear the music even less back there, and you also don't hear the sounds of the kitchen and patrons coming in. If you're fine with some background noise then you can sit in the front. I've usually sat in the front and have never had Noise problems. What's great is that everyone is there to get stuff done so it's not like other places where the people next to you are loud. Everyone seems to be very focused, even if they are just on Facebook. 

- it's open until 10pm, making it one of the only places around open passed 7pm. + major points 
- there is food. Not just cafe food (coffee and pastries) but actual food. Good food, might I add. I've gotten the popcorn, the Thai wrap and most recently the chicken bowl. I was into all of them.  They have beer, wine, kombucha, and.... Stumptown coffee! 
- more plugs than you know what to do with
- the seating is really nice. There are booths, high tables, low tables, and the chairs are comfortable.  There is plenty of space to spread your stuff around. You can even reserve conference rooms. 
- the staff are all really cool and friendly on every single occasion I've been here. 
- the place is clean. There are people constantly wiping down tables and making sure everything is ready to go for when tables are reserved. 

There definitely need to be more places like this in SF (perhaps open even a bit later?) That serve as a one stop shop for those of us who need to a place to study/work (because if I go home, I'll just end up taking a nap). 

Finally, a lot of people have said their food is a bit pricey. True. I probably wouldn't pay the same price for the same thing somewhere else. But you have to factor in the convenience here. This place goes above and beyond being just another cafe. Where else can you order your food (and stumptown) from your phone, and have everything come to your table without you have to move? Exactly.
author: Thielson D.

description: My small team had to work here for 1-2 weeks due to construction at our nearby office and this was a much better (and cheaper) alternative to Wework and other shared spaces. Good wifi, affordable hourly rates, cool layout, lively background music and awesome cafe staff. Only negative is that it is *freezing* whenever they leave the doors open (think Fidi + SF "summer").
author: Nene N.

description:
Love this place. It has really captured my heart, providing a place for us workaholics to spend evenings in FiDi/SF in general. Can order a beer and work from my laptop in a comfortable setting (I.e. not at a bar, getting awkward glares from happy hour goers) oh! But Workshop does have a happy hour, too!

Overall; love this place. Worth the $ per hour to use the space. Food and drinks are a *liiiiittle* on the expensive side, but I don't mind paying just because it's such a great spot!
author: Ann Marie P.

description: Great place for breakfast in the FiDi area, decent selection of coffee, pastries, and cafe food, but also has some different menu items like chicken pho. You can order stuff on an app and skip the line (they'll also bring your food out, instead of you having to wait for your name to be called). Service is pretty slow and not super friendly. It's also a co-working space where you can either pay by the hour or get a different plan.
author: Julie Z.

description:
A rather drab working environment with bad lighting. It's also overpriced and they're rude about their rules, e.g. forcing me to move over one chair because I checked into the wrong number. Err, the place is almost empty, who cares?

Won't be back.
author: Craig J.

description: This appears to be a working environment for students and solopreneurs, but the food is extraordinary. I had DIY Soft Baked Egg Bowl w (pulled) roasted chicken, and seasonal ice tea. My friend had the Avo Egg Scramble. Mine was soft baked eggs (barely poached, very runny), avocado slices, roasted sweet potatoes and arugula- all dusted with seeds and green goddess seasoning. Looked pretty strange. But it was amaaaaaaazing. With the first bite I realized this was a special creation. And it only got better. The seeds and dressing were a magic combo that yielded a very unique and wonderful taste, especially with the arugula and roasted sweet potatoes. The tea was wonderful, unusual but satisfying if you are a tea lover like me. My friend was equally impressed with his meal, so much so that he photographed the menu so he could attempt a recreation at home. And over on down the counter a woman was adjusting the drop speed of a cold brew coffee that would take 16 hours to complete, which they will serve tomorrow. Yummm!  Atmosphere super casual. I am in a t-shirt and cargo pants, not out of place here. I look forward to returning to sample more.
author: Seth K.

description: The people working here are extremely nice, but beyond that my experience was pretty awful; as my drink was being made, the workers talked with each other about how the espresso machine wasn't working properly. Turns out they were right, my drink didn't taste like it had any espresso in it. The eggs tasted and felt like they were straight from a carton, and alongside two small pieces of bread and the five arugula leaves, it definitely wasn't worth the price. Was disappointed because I was excited from the reviews I had read.
author: Luke C.

description:
Only in a tech town like SF will you see a cool, hip, tech savvy and clean coffee workshop like this one.  I was looking for a place to work for a few hours on a rainy day while visiting SF with good coffee an workshop cafe came up.  I was a little worry case places like this usually have terrible coffee and terrible food.  Well, boy, was I wrong.  This was a place that anyone who needs a remote work location would love.  There are plenty of outlets and plenty of seating areas.  This places does get pretty pack and you may foresee some weight during weekdays. 

As for the coffee, it can be a little stronger.  I like my coffee strong, so maybe this is just me.  I ordered the chicken salad, which was not bad, but not great.  It's fresh and light, so it's perfect for not putting me right to sleep.  It usually cost about $2.00 per hours, which is extremely fair in my opinion.  I would definitely come back here again.  


Tip: First 10 hours free.  Use your app to order food and drinks, and they'll bring it to your table for you.
author: Rosemary T.

description:
Great place to get work done and really pretty inside. Limited choices of coffee but still good quality cause it's Stumptown. 

First 3 hours are free to use their work space!
author: Wing U.

description:
Awesome concept and great workspace! 

Plenty of outlets, great internet, and lots of big tables and individual study spaces. There are some computers along the wall as well. The atmosphere is great!

First 10 hours are free, and it's easy to check in and out using the phone app, or the computer screen before the "work zone" Each seat has a number on it. After the first 10 hours, it's $2/hour. The plus side - you'll find seats because you can check and reserve to see what's available! The down side - you pay per hour. But it seems worth it to me!

They have food and drinks that you can order via the apps and they'll bring it to you. No need to get up, which is really nice!

They also have some seating out of the work zone that's free to hang out at. 

Lastly, it seems that companies can reserve certain spaces which is cool! Workshop Cafe had signs posted up everywhere when this happened, so you get plenty of warning ahead of time. 

I didn't get to try the food, but it looked really pretty. My friend ordered the avocado toast, I'll probably grab one of those next time!
author: Tsyria T.

description:
Abandon all hope ye who enter.


Something out of the eighth circle of hell. As you gaze out at a sea of emotionless drones and their dead-souled eyes you may scream. Resist that urge as you turn heel and run.

Even the employees have abandoned human social norms. They know the job of suckling lucre from the corpses of tech drones is better accomplished by robots, and will be shortly.

Alas, the food was poor and overpriced.
author: M C.

description: Love the concept.  Hate the loud music.  Difficult to concentrate or focus.  Music is loud techno rock music.
author: Paul C.

description:
Decent place to study and you get your first 10 hours free! They stock the place with coffee, food, and snacks so you're basically set. I came here to sit with my bf while he was studying because we were going to do something later so I just turned on my Netflix. The space itself isn't quiet like a library but not noisy like a restaurant either -- it has a good balance. Because I had nothing better to do, I got to try a variety of their food and drinks!

- Blueberry Lemonade (don't know the real name because I didn't order it): I really liked this one. It's refreshing yet not overwhelmingly sweet or sour.
- Chicken Bowl: I'm pretty sure this stuff is just heated up in the back and put on a bowl for you but it reminded me of those guilty meals I had back in college while studying for finals. Hits the spot but can't be good for you.
- Cinnamon Popcorn: I expected it to be a little sweeter but you still taste a little bit
- Tomato Bisque(?): Forgot the name exactly but this was horrible. Do not get this.
author: Tiffany E.

description: I literally couldn't ask for more. Your first 10 hours are free. Super easy to check in and their coffee is delicious. Once you sit at a work station you can text or email your order and they will bring it to you. The food was so fresh and delicious.
author: Eva D.

description:
This place is very San Francisco. It's a place that probably only works in a place like San Francisco.

Basically a workshop for techies to be around other techies. Prices start at $2/hr but if you use their app, the first 10 hours are FREE! So it's definitely worth a try if you're skeptical.

Atmosphere:
Music is quieter, which is a plus. In comparison, Starbucks usually blasts their music. It was quiet enough for me to take a phone interview. They also have conference/single rooms if the music is still too loud for you.

Setup:
They have all types of setups - couches, desk, booths, private rooms, desks with external monitor. It's nice they provide you with an array of seating options.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Only 3 hours free as of 5/23/17. 

I don't know, maybe I'm not tech-savvy enough, but I didn't have a very welcoming co-working experience. It was awkward not knowing that I didn't finish verification process on my account... and was later booted out because I wasn't alerted that my free 3 hours had come to and end. Anyway, why is this all done through phone? Shouldn't it be easier to manage if it's through the device you're logged onto? It's weird how the WiFi doesn't require a password/has no time limit, but your check-in account / seat times out. 

Also, I ordered a bagel with lox and cream cheese, but the counterwoman didn't realize until after I paid that they hadn't had their bagels delivered yet-- too early in the day (6:50am). I didn't mind waiting for my order. She was so sweet and nice about it. She kept on apologizing repeatedly and gave me a coupon for a free drink later.
author: Colleen W.

description: It's my second time to this joint.  Great downtown location and pleasant staff. I get there peppermint tea and really enjoy it. There is work space to rent to if you need it.  I'll be back a third time I'm sure.
author: Robert C.

description: Oh man this place is slow. Latte was ok and the place wasn't that clean. The concept and the vibe were fine but man I can't reiterate enough how slow it was.
author: Patrick W.

description:
This place is extremely dedicated to nickel-and-diming the customer. First of all, you pay $3 an hour just to sit there, then they charge $2.50 for mediocre drip coffee. Then, they don't even give you free or reduced price refills for coffee. This is regular coffee, not a triple espresso with 100 syrups. 

Will not return.
author: R J.

description:
If you don't got time to spare, don't come here. I took down one stars for the long wait .  Overall, I like the mocha and the works. 

I felt like I got a good amount of salmon for the price in the city. The sesame bagel was over toasted but not burnt so too crunchy for my liking, but it did add a little something to the flavor. The cream cheese is like a combo of mayo, cream cheese, sprinkle of sweet/sour capers and slight taste of miso soup(likely due to the black and white sesames on bagel).

The mocha is a cross between Starbucks sweetness and a light roasted kick from Pete's. I'll definitely go back and try the regular coffee. Coworker loved it!
author: Penny S.

description: After paying for a $4 coffee I really don't expect to be told that I can't use my laptop inside in the tiny, non-workspace pay per hour area in front of the counter. If I had known, I wouldn't have come here. They advertise this fact on a tiny print out smaller than a matchbook on the tables. They should advertise more visibly before you buy anything.
author: C. L.

description:
I can't connect to the wifi using my Windows 10 computer.

I'm disappointed that they don't have (a) bomb-proof wifi that anyone can connect to, or (b) people who can debug problems, like at a genius bar.

Meanwhile, my fiance downloaded the app to try to get in--it keeps redirecting him to a bot that seems useless.

And the app I've had on my iphone crashes.  Which, I guess is nice cos after trying so many ways to pay I'm just not going to. So I save about $3 but honestly I'd rather have had my hour working instead of an hour spent fruitlessly fiddling with wifi settings!
author: K R.

description: Service is slow and lattes not sufficiently hot. Not worth $4.
author: Siobhan M.

description:
Concept is really innovative and creative. Located in downtown San Francisco, so if you don't want to head straight into traffic on the way home, this can serve as a nice place to do some work. 

They have a lounging area as well as their towards-the-back of the store working area. You don't have to pay anything to use the lounging area in the front, but to use the working area in the back, you must check in using your phone. Your first 10 hours (cumulatively) are free; however, after that, it's $2 / hour. You can choose to order from the front when you walk in, or go straight to checking in a sitting down then ordering from your seat through your phone. I think it's definitely worth a try to use some of those free 10 hours to check the back out, it's set up really efficiently with whiteboards, meeting rooms and outlets galore!

Wouldn't recommend ordering the snacks though. Got the sweet potatoes, and they were pretty bland and dry. My favorite part of that snack dish were the onions. The tea and coffee were mediocre as well. 

But! Aside from the menu, the concept is promising! It is very spacious, and everyone around you is working hard, so it motivated me to finish a lot of work during the two to three hours I was there as well.
author: Kim N.

description: This place is pretty cool. Focused on working professionals who need to get work done after work hours. They also serve food here and the menu is pretty extensive! I was impressed. The only con about this place is that for a new customer you only get 3 hours free. Then after the first 3 hours, its $2/hour. I could go to the library or a coffee shop and buy a $3 coffee and stay for unlimited time. But it is a cool scene. I would come again especially if I am in the area.
author: Jessica C.

description:
The ultimate study spot. This is exactly what I've been looking for. Maybe it'll be yours, too. 

Yummy food. Great coffee. Working wifi. Spacious tables. Too many outlets. Penty of alcohol. I think the only thing they need now is a lounge area. You know, with a couch and some tv's for that occasional study break. As an alumni, we've all experienced those midterm or final nights to cause us to search frantically for a decent study spot. Workshop Cafe definitely made me feel like I was in school again. However, it is NOT conveniently located (in Financial District). You know what a pain it is to get there? But then again, the spot doesn't get busy as there's not much people who want to spend another hour after work. They all go home and so that leaves me with the perfect opportunity :) It was a smart investment on the owner's part as they know there's not much around after work hours. This leaves limited options for people and so they come here. 

As you enter, it can be intimidating as it is pretty quiet. Their menu is up on the screen. You order and find a seat. Now there's a catch. Nothing can be too good right? You have to pay by the hour ($2/hr). However, as noobie, you get your first 10 hours FREE!!! Yes, FREE! Then afterwards you gotta pay. Don't like the idea of paying for a seat? The solution: they have free spaces in the front and outside. And yes, wifi still works. On a bright and sunny day, who wouldn't want to sit outside then? 

I'm pretty sure outside food is allowed, but don't take my word. I'll be sure to bring my sushirrito the next time. 

For the owner: Please consider playing the same song/radio. It was a bit annoying having to hear two completely opposite songs try to do a collaboration. Otherwise, Fifi super likes!
author: Fiona L.

description:
I've lived in the city for 3 years now and I have to say that Workshop Cafe might be the most San Franciscan place I've been to. You have a cafe serving the usuals along with some exotic teas and other dishes and you have a workshop area where you use an app to pay for each hour you are there. The two combine to form Workshop Cafe, a concept I'm slightly uneasy about. 

It's cool that when you first show up, you get ten free hours. I might use those since they're free but I can't see myself paying $2-$3 per hour for an outlet and wifi. There's a lot of things about working at a typical cafe that is lost here. One thing I like about working at cafes is the chit chat going on in the background. That white noise is like a little melody that you can't find when working at home. That noise seemed to be missing here when I stopped by. There's also the people watching aspect of it. You sit at a cafe and you see all sorts of people wander in and out- here it's mostly people plugging away at their laptops much like what you'd see at work. 

You could argue that this is the place to be if you are looking for silence. But then I'd rather just go to my public library. It's quiet there and you are surrounded by books you can peruse whenever you feel like it. The library is free and plus it feels good to support your local library. 

While I thought this was a good concept, it's not compelling enough to drive me to pay for an outlet and wifi.
author: Philip W.

description:
The mocha is sickeningly sweet. The Avo Egg Scrabble is 8-10 arugula leaves next to a half avocado and some mediocre (and not freshly cooked to order based on the crusty edges) scrambled eggs. Salty cheese crumbled over the top and a little black pepper on the avocado provides the seasoning. I was asked away from the tables in the front because they don't want laptop use there. I was invited to move to the back, but not informed if needed to enter my cc into an app to access seating inside.
If you want to use your laptop inside you have to provide a credit card to sit at a table, even after placing a food order. You can sit at a dirty, small table in the front and not work, or sit outside. 
When I mentioned that they should have told me a credit card was required to sit inside, before I got settled, the guy who asked me to move originally got condescending. Setting proper expectations for guests is just too much to ask. 
Total disappointment.
author: Char Z.

description: Not very impressed.. Costs to sit there (except three tables in the entrance and tables outside) and the coffee was not the best I've tried.. nice staff though!
author: Jessica E.

description:
I tried to make an appointment online but somehow it didn't work so I made a call to reserve a spot.
Staff was very friendly over the phone and helped me go through reservation with patience. 
When I got to the place, it was pretty awesome. Place was quiet and clean, perfect for studying. 
I reserved 4person whiteboard area, and cost was reasonable for 4 people, staff was very friendly when I ordered OJ. I didn't try there food yet but would like to try next time.
author: Yenny O.

description:
What used to be my favorite place to work has become the only place I can count on to be ignored. Most mornings service is slow, which I don't mind because quality usually prevails. Today, was the straw that broke the camels back. After standing 5 minutes ready to order breakfast, and watching 6 humans behind be counter working diligently, without being acknowledged I left. Heartbreaking because they'll never know. 

Walked across the street to the new Peet's, greeted with a smile and had coffee in literally seconds. 

Such a shame when you're trying to support local businesses in the FiDi
author: Jessa C.

description: Prreeettyyy neat place to work, but having to pay for workspace is a huge downside.
author: Hillary A.

description: This is the perfect place for anyone who works remotely or needs strong wifi and coffee at the same time! It is a great workspace with tons of outlets and good internet, and being around other working people helps me feel super productive. You get 10 free hours there with the app, and after that it is $2-3/hour. You can even order food and drinks on your phone and have it brought to you! My only complaint is that a few times the mobile ordering has been down, and then after I ordered and paid at the counter, I was still charged for my mobile order after I left. However, this is a small inconvenience and I'll definitely be back to Workshop Cafe!
author: Sophie C.

description:
This place really changed my mind on proper coworking spaces versus simply working in coffee shops. Probably because it's a hybrid of the two!

To start, there's an app, and you get 10 hours free when you sign up. After that, it's $2-3 per hour.

So why pay this?

You get to pick your seats. In a city where showing up at 10am often means "you're late" and all the seats in a cafe are taken, this is clutch. You can also order everything from the cafe from within the app and they'll deliver it TO YOUR SEAT. I've used it a ton, it's amazing and dangerous and glorious.

They use Stumptown beans, e.g. the best there is, and their selection of food is pretty varied and solid overall. I've had a good breakfast sandwich, various cookies, beers and popcorn.

Sure, paying by the hour on a daily basis can approach the cost of a monthly membership elsewhere, but for occasional coworking or simply the flexibility, it can't be beat.
author: Nick S.

description: I've previously had a great experience but it was such a mess today, I have to tell everyone to avoid this place. The cheesy popcorn was the worst food item I've ever had. It was stale popcorn and raw parmesan cheese. I ordered a sandwich and they didn't have the bun. That happens, no big deal. So they told me to pick something else so I did. They couldn't do that one either because apparently it was the same bun (they didn't tell me it was the bun the first time). But they didn't tell me until 15 minutes after I ordered it. I decided to get it on a bagel instead because I was starving. I asked for it on wheat and for the bagel to be toasted. Well, they got a piece of that right. It was 50/50 wheat and white (wheat bottom, white top) and not toasted. Then I get the bill and they charged me for the sandwich I didn't get.
author: Scott H.

description: It's just not nice enough to bother for the hassle.  If you need some power strips - this place has them.  The food is good enough but the vibe is dingy.  If I was leaving my parents basement for some time out of the house - I wouldn't want to come here and pay for the same thing.
author: Trent W.

description: Their food is good and their coffee is ok, ( their latte is a bit cold) but they are SOOO SLOW. I had to walk away too many times, cause they either taking too long or there were no one at the counter to get my order.
author: Sadaf S.

description:
T.I.P - First 10 study hours are free, after which you gotta $$ out
Brought the gf here on a study date thing~ read other happy revs, and was not left disappointed. Needed a cozy spot w/ fast wifi and everything checked out.
Expect better food here than your Starbucks. Parking might be hard to find though
Overall- B+
author: Marcus C.

description:
This is one of those rare places where a great idea meets excellent execution.  For those that don't know, the workplace is made up of a bunch of tables and seating arrangements with quality wifi and plenty of plugs.  They also have conference rooms that you can use if they're open or reserve, which have hookups to a TV for larger presentations.  

Everything worked exactly as it was supposed to, which is exactly what you want when you have little time and need to get some work done.  

The way they get paid is that the first 10 hours are free (which is how they hook you) and then you're charged an hourly fee for their wifi.  Great right? 

I took off one star because their drinks are ridiculously expensive (over $4 for standard tea).
author: Denis S.

description: I used to love this place but the music is too loud and I find it hard to focus or use my own headphones - I can hear the music even with my noise canceling headphones.
author: Andy R.

description: I've been going to this space for over a year. And it's a fine affordable option for coworking space because you can pay by the hour. However the staff is incredibly aggressive and sometimes rude when checking to see if you've checked in. And sometimes they play the music a little loud, making it hard to do any calls.
author: Karla C.

description:
For a coffee shop that charges $2/hour, the least I expect is a decent Internet connection. Every time I make the decision to come here, I regret it deeply. The Internet is as fast as an injured donkey walking uphill. Please, take my money and get me fast Internet so I can come here and be able to work!

Fun fact, the connection was so slow that I couldn't post this review until my fifth try.
author: Zorayr K.

description:
This place has a pretty cool concept. They function just like any other cafe, serving food and drinks, but a large area in the back is reserved as a co-working space. The have several different set ups for individuals, teams, people who need quiet rooms, people who need conference rooms, etc. They even have an LCD screen displaying which seats are available for you to reserve for yourself.

My friend and I came here since we're both able to work from home. To use the workspace, you have to download an app and create an account (which involves entering your credit card info). However, they have a great promotion that lets you work your first 10 hours there for free. I wasn't able to try any food since I had already eaten prior, but I ordered a Horchatte to sip on while I worked. The drink was a little watery, not that sweet, but not terrible.

Overall the place has a great vibe and is a good place to go if you work from home and find yourself in San Francisco.
author: Miguel H.

description:
I LOVE this place! It can seem a bit intimidating at first glance but basically, the patio and a few tables on the right side once you enter are part of the free cafe area, and the rest is the workspace area, where you can rent seats. There's an iPad at the workspace entrance, but you should just download the app. Check in and enter your seat number and you will have officially booked that spot. 

There are tons of outlets, whiteboards, and different types of couches/chairs/desks to satisfy every personal preference! The energy here is amazing - everyone is super focused and in-the-zone, so if you're someone like me who is really affected by her surroundings, you will be extremely productive here! The tables are also really clean, which is uncommon for cafes, especially one that is as busy as this location! 

Also, they serve some really good food and Stumptown coffee. It does get a bit crowded but you can check seat availability on the app.
author: Melody Y.

description: They allow people to bring pizza in from a different restaurant and sit during slow times. But they will come tell you to put away your laptop if seated in the same section (after purchasing beer and dinner). Awesome that they have Old Rasputin, but sorry to say I won't return.
author: Kayla S.

description:
Honey Almond Latte. Do it. 

* HONEY ICED ALMOND LATTE ($5) - 5 STARS:
Honey mixed into 2 shots of Stumptown espresso topped with Barista Califia Almond Milk. I requested this hot but it usually is served iced. It's slightly sweet and super delicious. I was kinda shocked by the price though - $5 - yikes. I love it cold too, and usually ask for this with light honey.

They serve delicious pastries from Pattisserie Philippe as well as a full cafe menu including salads and sandwiches. 

* HAM AND CHEESE CROISSANT ($4.50) - 3 STARS:
Overly buttery to the point it's a bit soggy. Fresh and tasty as would any fresh croissant might be, but I would probably return to try the blueberry brioche or chocolate croissant. Ask for it toasted!

* CHOCOLATE CROISSANT ($3.50) - 3.5 STARS:
Decently sized with a decent amount of chocolate but it's just not my favorite croissant. Better than the ones at La Boulange. Ask for it toasted!

There is some limited free seating but plenty of seating you can rent for $2/hr. It can get pretty crowded especially in the afternoon but it's almost completely empty in the morning.
author: Jess C.

description:
This is a great place to get work done, since you can pretty much always find a seat and there's power everywhere.  However, there are some ways staff could improve things:

Pourovers delivered to the tables often aren't hot.  My guess is that someone starts the order, and then gets busy with something else.  By the time they remember about it, it's no longer hot and they deliver it anyway.

The $4 pourover uses the same beans as the $2.50 drip and tastes exactly the same, except it probably will be close to room temperature.

The drip coffee comes in either a mug or paper cup, but the mug is smaller.  I wish I didn't need to chose between wanting more coffee and being eco-friendly.

Ordering from the counter takes far longer than it should.  I think their point-of-sale system is just too complicated.  You'll sell more if you speed this up.  Consider timing how long it takes each customer to move through the line, and I think you'll be surprised.

Sometimes a staff member will clear away dirty dishes, but not frequently.  They pile up on at the desks.  Since table service is offered, why not go all the way and bus tables too?  We're paying to sit there, after all.

The background music is often distracting.  They could consider playing ambient music without vocals.

The air temperature is often too hot or too cold.

There's only one toilet and one urinal in the men's room.  With so many people sitting in the cafe, you often have to wait in line.  The restrooms aren't kept very clean either.

The August 4, 2016 health score of 79% seems low.
author: Lucullus L.

description: Cool coworking space, you receive 3 hours for free when you sign up. Great location and furniture. Recommended to work if you visit the area for business.
author: Ferran A.

description: Harassed by rude management. We were told at the counter that they offer 10 hours free at their 'work' space, so we paid for several drinks. We were unable to get any work done. We were interrupted a dozen times by an incredibly rude manager, who demanded payment of $4 per hour, because their 'free' 10 hour app was unavailable on android. He took our credit card, charged it, and even then denied service and asked us to work in the freezing patio. We had to leave without finishing our drinks and without getting any work done. I doubt this business will survive. We went to the nearby Nespresso. Elegant and respectful ambience, and we can actually get some work done.
author: Charles B.

description:
WC FiDi is a great place for dev work.   Easy to get into a zone with no distraction.  Food and drink good also.
I tried the new Soma location this morning but with all the doors flung open the swirling wind inside made it too cold to concentrate.  After ~20 minutes I was forced out and back to FiDi.  When people are sitting with quilted jackets zipped up IT IS TOO COLD.
author: helge m.

description:
This is almost exactly what I am looking for as a workspace cafe. I love that there are plenty of seats and that the coffee is top quality (Stumptown beans). The wifi is fast. I like being able to rent a seat on a per-hour basis instead of purchasing something that I don't want. 

The big problem is that the music is too loud for a workspace. You can feel the bass in your seat. It's obnoxious. 

It's a big flaw in what would otherwise be a dream location for my peripatetic work habits. It leaves me wanting to pony up the cash for a seat at wework.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Workshop Cafe is a great spot to get some work done away from the noise and clutter of your typical coffee shop. Sure you have to pay for the privilege, but for a couple of dollars it certainly isn't anything to complain about.

The space is large, with an abundance of indoor and outdoor seating and pleasant service. Overall, a great spot to get an affordable cup of Stumptown coffee and a tasty turkey cranberry sandwich while you get some of your afternoon work finished. Sure to become a lunch-time favorite.
author: Kevin B.

description: I don't generally like mocha, but they do it really well. Their food is delicious, too. Nice and quiet place to work with great comfort
author: Sophia S.

description:
The service isn't the best and neither is the coffee (sad - the fact that they serve Stumptown was the whole reason I went there to begin with), but if you need somewhere to get things done this is a lot better than hanging out at a Starbucks.  There's tons of seating, plentiful outlets, laptop stands floating about, comfy chairs, etc. 

They also have conference rooms that can be reserved if you wanted to meet with a larger group or have some privacy. 

Order the popcorn.
author: Jason F.

description:
Interesting concept. You rent a workspace in a coffee shop with some great coffee! 

It's pretty big and I loved my mocha.
Btw, there's no small M L .. Only one size !
author: Sowmya S.

description: This is a review of their "proudly served Stumptown" latte. My office coffee machine makes better lattes. Stumptown founders would be horrified if they saw the latte served at Workshop
author: Yevgeny K.

description:
I come to the Workshop Cafe before, between and after meetings in SF to get some work done. The place offers everything I need - good wifi, enough space, the right amount of distraction and coffee :-). 

I like the simple checkin and checkout procedure. I don't have to deal with payment and it's easy to use. 

The website to make booking in advance is still confusing and at times it's very crowded. I would give 4.5 stars if I could ;-)
author: Dario S.

description:
I need coffee and WiFi stat! 

This place is full of 40 somethings dressed like 20 something hipsters. Oh, San Francisco you smug, adorable city. I actually really enjoy this place; the atmosphere is perfect for getting some work done, sipping some delicious coffee, and doing a little people watching in-between spouts of typing and social media lurking. 

This communal working area has what seems like miles of tables and outlets for you to get cozy and get down to business. The way this works is you can either check-in online and receive two free hours of WiFi or pay two bucks and get the same thing. It baffles me that enough people just pay the two bucks when they could simply just check-in. Why?

I ordered the egg sandwich on a wheat bagel with a large iced coffee. The coffee served in here is almost exclusively from Stumptown Coffee Roasters, which if you're a coffee snob like me you know it's amazing go juice from Portland. Stumptown has this slight bitterness to it on the backend of your palate, you know like that tangy feeling you get when you eat a good BBQ sauce, to me it's delightful. The egg sammie was ok, pretty basic and nothing really to write home about. This place does have many other options to graze or sample; like soups, salads, and even beer or wine, but be warned you might be waiting a while if you order food. 

Good spot if you're from out-of-town and need a place to get some work wrapped up.  If you have to drive here, I would go somewhere else because the traffic around this neighborhood is cray.
author: Nate M.

description: Spacious and great spot to work or have meetings. Many tables and outlets and not terrible crowded. Might be hard to have a virtual mtg bc there's music in the background. I got the blueberry steel cut oatmeal w date milk and it was delicious! They have other oatmeals options too! Also got the avo/egg scramble and it was good. Highly recommend this place!!
author: Food L.

description:
Great space, great pastries... Industrious, cool environment. Also, a neat biz idea.

Stumptown coffee sold here too---bonus!
author: Jana C.

description: One of the few places I can stand to work in the Bay Area. Ample outlets, good wifi, good food and drinks, and a fantastic Spotify playlist.
author: Alex P.

description:
Workshop Cafe is a little over-hyped in my opinion, especially if you want to get some real studying done.  I was super impressed by the front of Workshop Cafe - that industrial-looking chandelier with oblong bulbs and orange wiring is sooo cool! - but once inside, the space felt...worn out.  Burnt out light bulbs overhead, scuffed walls, and deflated pillows made for a less than stellar impression of the back area of Workshop Cafe.  Cleaning maintenance is not performed often enough in the bathrooms, too...blech.   

Sure, this work space is good for meetings, but isn't it also meant for those needing a space to study?  Don't get me wrong, I love the idea of being able to order food from your phone and having a designated spot to work from.  However, the food is overpriced and nothing to write home about.  Maybe they charge for delivery to your desk?  

My main complaint is that the music is just too loud for good studying.  It is actually louder than other cafes I have studied at, which is strange.  In addition, the private, enclosed study rooms are no quieter - trust me, I've tested them out.  I found myself glazing over my notes because I kept latching on to words from the catchy tunes that were playing overhead.  Who studies to rap tunes with lots of words, anyway?  I guess some people do, but for me, the more words in a song, the less I can pay attention to my reading material!  

Anyway, back to the food.  The food is mreh and suuuper pricey.  We ordered the chicken pepper stir fry ($12), breakfast tacos ($6 each, eggs/salsa/black beans/cheese) and the nutty wild rice salad ($7.50, organic wild rice/figs/toasted cashews/pecans/raspberry vinaigrette).  The first two dishes are things I can make at home for under $5 each, while the nutty wild rice salad was unique, reasonably priced, and yummy.  

If I return back to Workshop Cafe, it will be within the first free ten hours, and I'll probably just order the nutty wild rice salad and a drink.  And I won't go to the bathroom.
author: Brittany N.

description: This is definitely one of the most interesting coffee shops I have been to. I like the hybrid coffee place and workplace separation they have . A little pricy but can't complain since it's in one of the prime locations in the downtown. Nothing can beat the stumptown coffee here.
author: Sailaja B.

description: From Utah, stopped in on a work trip for a few hours. Love this location and the vibe with it. Was full of people and everything runs smoothly. Great place to work and eat. Love how easy it is to connect to wifi, order food and get to work! Love this spot!
author: Ashlee E.

description: They've changed. Now, you have to pay extra to book rooms. The food is a little more too. I still have hours from the 80 hr package I ordered that they no longer provide. I still come here but not as regularly as I had before.
author: Frances S.

description:
Good spot to get work done, You can rent a workspace and plug in your laptop -- or you can sit out front and use the free wifi (no password needed).  

I got the brisket sandwich with a glass of chardonnay -- and it was pretty good.  I never finish a whole sandwich, and I ate the whole thing.  

I would say I like the atmosphere the most, very cool vibe and really interesting people.  I wouldn't recommend just going for the food or for drinks (as most people are working), but definitely a great spot if you need to get some work done.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Stumbled upon the café today. Did a couple Speedtests while sipping an espresso. Might be an interesting place to come back and do some work.

First 10 hours free, $2-3/hour after that. You reserve your work space in the café via App. Private glass rooms also available. Outlets galore.

Espresso was delicious.
author: Paolo V.
