description: Super efficient spot to work with great food and drink.  Superb concept.  Have worked 100's of hours here.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Free-ish Wifi
Strong Coffee
Friendly Staff

A little on the pricey side, but its a cool concept. Its a nice space to get work done for a few hours if you don't mind paying a few bucks and hour to be there. To me, if I can be more productive in a few hours and pay a couple of bucks an hour than if I were to work at home for free, then I consider that to be money well spent! 

Even though my "hot cereal" wasn't the greatest (tasted super floral// borderline tasted like the smell of fresh laundry??) it was nice that the guys working there made a me a new one with no complaints! :) 

If you haven't tried it yet, definitely check it out! Plus, your first 10 hours are free
author: Katie 2.

description:
Great coworking spot! My boyfriend and I were in town on a Tuesday and needed to get some work done. We walked a few blocks here and it was perfect. This sort of set up doesn't exist in Baltimore yet and we've only seen it internationally. 

It's a few bucks an hour to have a work spot and internet access. There are a few different work styles - tables, stand up tables, couches, private office / meeting space. If you download the app it's free for the first ten hours. 

You just walk in, start your timer, pick a spot, and start working. You can order food and drinks via text. I didn't order any food but the almond milk latte was solid and arrived quickly. 

I thought it was great! Would def return again.
author: Morgan S.

description:
I had a fairly poor experience during my last visit - staff didn't seem to know the rules/rates, and did a poor job following up. 

We checked into one of their 2-person rooms for a business meeting, and were interrupted at least 5 times for little things. 

One of them took down my order, but didn't clarify that they only accept orders through their app/website. When he returned to take a credit card for the room check-in, I asked about the order only to find out that it hadn't been placed, and that I need to use the app/site. I wonder if he would've bothered to tell me had I not asked. 

Not sure I care to return to this place; there are some great spots in the city to get work done; grab good food/drinks; AND with great, friendly staff. I'll be working out of many SF joints in the future, and Workshop Café won't be one of them.
author: Arthur M.

description:
I was picking up a date here and wanted to grab a bite real quick while she finished up work.

Short and sweet: 
Avocado toast here is off-the-charts! Lovely bread with a light layer of cream cheese, a nice portion of fresh avocado slices, topped with cucumber, sautéed clappers, sunflower seeds, and crushed and toasted nuts of some kind.
.... all I can only really say that it's a sleeper hit. So good and hit the spot. I'm coming back just for that!

The overall atmosphere is low key with some alternative hip hop and world beat humming in the background. They also have some appealing looking grab and go choices I did not try.
author: Steve B.

description:
I got "the works" bagel, and I can see now why it took 15 minutes to make, because they toasted the crap out of it.  

I'm not sure why is called "the works" because there isn't that much on it? Cream cheese, smoked salmon, tomatoes, cucumbers, fried capers. No red onion which is weird. It could use sprouts too or something else. 

I'm not sure why you would fry capers for this? Kinda defeats the whole purpose of them,and why people get them. 

If you want a smoked salmon bagel go down to working girl cafe, it's cheaper and a lot better. Just seems like they're trying to dazzle the hipsters with 'fancy' ingredients. And yes, this review was about a smoked salmon bagel. (And the wait for it!)
author: Nikki G.

description: They arbitrarily decide when to close and stop serving food.  Nowhere near 10pm on a week day.
author: Girish J.

description: Add another one to my list of work cafes in the city. The Workshop Cafe is an excellent space if you're looking to post up somewhere with your laptop or kindle.  Insanely stable wifi, an unreal outlet per square foot ratio, and solid cafe snackies to sustain your multi-hour work bender.  The place is packed with people grinding on work, which facilitates an environment that really pushes you to be productive. The cafe is really big. The front half is your standard cafe seating--outdoor tables as well as small indoor tables and a long counter top to work on. The back half is a pay per hour space (roughly $2-$3 an hour which you pay through their app). This space is loaded with different kinds of seating options to accommodate a variety of work condition preferences. They offer long counters, small tables, communal tables, private work rooms, lounge chairs, booths, and standing wipe boards among other work arrangements. It's an awesome work space and they provide you with three free hours in the pay space for your first visit. Vibe-wise it's a very productive space. Tons of people are working intensely but it's also a place where you can see someone reading "Crazy Rich Asians" on their Kindle. Great place to knock out some work in the city--highly recommend!
author: Max S.

description: I've only had the coffee, which was decent, but mostly I just like that there's a cafe/workspace that caters to folks that primarily want a workspace by explicitly charging for it. The rates are quite reasonable and seating was decent the few times I've been in.
author: Jeff F.

description:
This was a pleasant place to work for a day, and they seem to have their bases covered. I love the concept of ordering food and coffee from your phone and having it delivered to your workspace/table...very convenient!

Speaking of coffee, the iced latte with almond milk and honey is a delicious (and unique) combination.
author: Jason L.

description:
First time here. I wanted a quick breakfast. I tried the Egg scramble with Avocado for $4.50 and Coffee $2.00 everything $7.00 
NOT worth it. I could've made better tasting eggs at home for less than $2.00. Eggs were VERY dry and bland. And you could tell they were made in microwave. Yuck. Even Starbucks breakfast sándwich tastes better. 2 stars only because the guy at register was very friendly and welcoming.
author: v v.

description: Cute space but not clean at all which was kind of a bummer as the menu looked promising
author: Netta G.

description: Are you kidding me right now?  Did I really just pay $10 for 4 pieces of bacon on some kind of clearly old, overly dry, crumble in my fingers roll BLT sandwich. How do you guys stay in business? I just drove 2 hrs to get to an appt.  I order a sandwich to go and I get this.  Was it a bad day, or just the wrong menu item...  I'm not sure but I thought a BLT would be safe. It didnt even have Mayo.  Who puts mustard on a BLT? How do you mess up a sandwich that has 3 ingredients?  Very disappointing and what a let down.  This was old food.  The bread, the bacon, the limp, translucent, wilted lettuce.  This stuff had clearly sat out and was ready for the garbage.  Instead, you sold to me.  The included potato chip crumbs thrown in the box with your poor excuse for a sandwich was just a further insult.  Since I'll be visiting the area regularly, I will be sure to avoid your establishment and tell everyone I know to do the same.  I will never patronize this establishment again.
author: Rick K.

description:
There's something a little sad about this whole phenomenon of wired, work-focused spaces that serve coffee, don't you think? Sure, it's convenient for telecommuting laptoppers and Steve Jobs wannabes, but it strikes me as yet another way to encourage people not to interact socially with each other. Call me old-fashioned but I normally patronize a cafe to forget about work and hang out with friends or just read a book with a cup of orange pekoe tea as I pet my Persian cat. But the Workplace Cafe wants to have it both ways - a place to do work and have meetings as well as a place to have some caffeine and a croissant (photo: http://bit.ly/1baxP3P). Well, at least the approach solves the problem many cafe owners face of laptoppers hanging out for hours at a time while sipping on the same latte.

Now they can hang out all they want for ten hours and then they charge $2/hour after that. That strikes me as awfully generous given the access to free WiFi, workstations, meeting tables and whiteboard spaces. You could run that internet business you always dreamed about and not have to worry about overhead costs. As for me, I think I've only been here for half-hour visits, just enough to charge up my iPhone and order the $4 Chai Latte (photo: http://bit.ly/16EOVsz) which isn't bad but doesn't last you very long. Pastries are an option as well. Open until 10PM, this is quite a large spot brightly lit with high ceilings. No mood lighting in here, and it's in the heart of the FiDi right next to the Bank of the West headquarters on Montgomery. This is definitely worth a stop if you just can't imagine a life disconnected. But I guess it depends on how you define being connected.

COFFEE - 3 stars...decent chai latte if a tad overpriced
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...pretty spacious...I've never had trouble getting a seat
SERVICE - 4 stars...always friendly here, never intrusive
TOTAL - 4 stars...yes, I've give it up for the space
author: Ed U.

description:
Came here to get some studying done (textbook+notebook+smartphone for online lectures). I will definitely be back.

Pros: 
-Coffee was pretty darn tasty. Got the drip coffee for $2.50. 
-Cafe space outside of the workstation was just the right room temperature for me.

Cons: 
-Tables inside the workstation seem to be designed for laptop use since my space was a little small to fit a textbook+notebook. 
-Bit stuffy inside the workstation (but to be fair SF is having some abnormally artic-style chilly weather at the moment)
author: Linda C.

description:
Definitely a great spot if you're looking for a place to work and feel cool doing it.  Workshop Cafe serves up Stumptown Coffee, in addition to a variety of espresso drinks, pour overs, and beer and wine.  The space itself is seriously a very cool concept; how can it be that there's so many great coffee shops in this small area?!  You've got:
-Coffee Bar (with a perpetual line flowing out of it)
- Workshop Cafe (the "let's-start-our-own-company" crowd flooding the tables/couches); and
- Coffee Cultures around the corner (the "I-need-more-Hayes Valley/Mission-in-FiDi" crowd).

I had an almond milk latte from here and it wasn't bad! I still favor the Coffee Bar's version, but this certainly was worth the afternoon walk to.  Check it out if you're in the vicinity or don't want to wait at Coffee Bar!
author: Lisa I.

description:
You're in San Francisco, the start-up capital of the world, what else do you expect other than a start-up work space-inspired cafe!

I've always wanted to check out Workshop Cafe and I am so glad I finally did. Located in the heart of San Francisco's Financial District, it is the perfect place if you've got work to do or need a spot for a business meeting.

In the front end of the cafe you'll find the restaurant/cafe portion of the space along with some seating and an abundance of outlets (to charge all your devices). In the back end of the space is where all the magic happens...or where you'll find the majority of people typing away on their computers, along with several meeting rooms. To get to the back you need to input your phone number into the iPad, which will grant you 10 hours of free access. After that, each hour (along with unlimited water and internet) costs you $2. 

As for cafe offerings, you'll find all your typical items - strong coffee, fresh juice and snacks...all of which you can order from the comfort of your phone. Servers are friendly, the space is clean and quite, and there are outlets everywhere, so you'll always be fully charged and ready to work. 

If you're looking to get out of the house or the office, Workshop Cafe is a definite recommendation. The space is inspiring, the service is fast and easy and it generally just has a groovy vibe.
author: Aletta B.

description:
Good:
Their espresso gets me really buzzed, decent music playing, way better then a regular coffee shop to work in, very solid wifi, great service, fairly comfortable spaces, interesting food (oatmeal bowl).

Bad:
The oatmeal bowl was awkward because I had to gently maneuver my spoon so the food would not spill out the sides.
author: Evan F.

description:
Stumptown!
Great Workspace!
+Open later than your average coffee shop
+Convenient if you work in FiDi
+ Quick service
author: Marie P.

description: While the location of the Workshop Cafe is great and the concept is awesome, the level of volume for the background music is out of control!!!  Even with noise cancelling headphones, I could physically feel the base and still hear the music over my own music with ear plugs and in a private conference room!  I have visited this location a couple of times prior to my CPA exams and even asked them to turn down the music and simply received a shrug and "sorry we can't".  Please keep in mind people are not coming to your location for a concert, but to work or study and make this an actual priority.  If money ain't a thing, you do have the option to pay more and go in a "Quiet" room with no speakers.  Making your customers who want to work or study without blaring music in the background pay more for a few quiet rooms is a ridiculous business model, of which I have voiced this to any of my friends who ask about the Workshop.  Please revisit the volume level of your background music.
author: Desiree J.

description:
Modern college library meets hipster cafe. There are plentiful outlets, good wifi, and comfortable chairs. Since you pay to be there, you can stay as long as you want without feeling guilty or getting dirty looks from the staff.

I've had the Gochujang Ramen Bowl and the Southwest Bowl and would recommend both. A bit overpriced, but worth it for the convenience of getting all your needs met in one place.

Also worth noting -- you can order and pay using their app. If you don't want to interact with any humans, you don't have to.
author: Randa S.

description: Workshop Cafe is a co-working space that charges per hour. They have some good coffee and a few table seats for non-co-working people, who just want to sit and have a cup of coffee. I like the staff, they are super friendly and nice. It's a popular space, so be warned ahead of time and bring headphones.
author: Magnolia O.

description:
We reserved a conference room at Workshop for my team offsite through Peerspace. It was great! The room was well set-up (plugs in the middle of the table!) and the chairs were pretty comfortable. It was really nice having the cafe right there--you can text your order and they'll bring it to you! There's an app that you can use to reserve space and order food and drinks. 

I thought the setup of the whole space was pretty neat. There was a mix of seating, including long communal tables, smaller tables with booth seating, cozy chairs, and meeting rooms of various sizes. 

Also, I am recovering from surgery and needed a disability accommodation, so we emailed them ahead of time. The staff was *so* nice and helpful! They really went above and beyond for me.
author: Amy G.

description: Horrible! I walked  1.5 miles to this place cause it shows on Yelp that they where open till 10!! Reason I didn't drive?? Have you driven in San Fransico at rush hour?? Horrible if you plan on closing your establishment on a SATURDAY then maybe you should update your Yelp so consumers can know your NOT OPEN!! What a waste of my evening now I have to go have stupid Starbucks!!
author: Natasha R.

description:
This place is a contemporary workshop cafe to get any forms of work done!

The coffee making area reminds me of a science lab with the design tubes and the dripping of coffee being measured in them.

They have bar side tables, side secluded tables in the back area, open space tables and even white boards sectioned off so you can do all your visual learning there with a group or by yourself.  Of course, you can throw Wi-Fi into this workshop cafe as a plus factor.  Otherwise, it wouldn't be called a workshop cafe.

It is a cafe that is super convenient to linger for some hours and to get your work done indefinitely with caffeine serving as a bit of a booster!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Definitely down with the vibe here.  I go to coffee shops to do work all the time and so I was super surprised when my friend told me about this place and I hadn't heard of it.  Guess I just don't frequent the FIDI very often.  

If you want a bite to eat, coffee, or beer and to get some work done on the computer this is your spot.  They have plug ins galore and super fast internet.  Didn't try any of the food but they had Stone IPA so that was good enough for me!

Will be back if I'm in the area for sure.
author: Jamie B.

description:
I wish we had more of these in Canada, enough said.

The concept is simple, check in and book your seats online, buy your food and/or beverage and it will be delivered to your table.

Everyone is quietly working there, and it's guaranteed that way because that's the only type of people who come here in the first place. 

Not that it's crazy, but they even have an online community that people could interact on staying what they want to do or who they want to meet and their assigned seat number is shown, so you could walk right up!
author: Richard Y.

description:
Will never come here again, worst experience ever, nothing worked at all. I found Workshop Café here on Yelp. I was looking for a private space for a job interview via phone, which also included a test on my laptop via Skype. So reading the description of this café, it sounded good and I rented a single room. When I arrived, room was empty, had my name on the door, things starting off right. After setting up, had a little difficulty connecting to the wifi but was able to get on after several tries.

Now the fun begins. Potential employer calls and interview begins. After a minute, found that the cell signal was horrible inside. Interviewer said sound quality was bad and call kept dropping. Interviewee called me back 3 times and finally gave up. I'm in a panic, run out to the front to get help from one of the employees and the person who spoke to me didn't give an F. He just said, oh, yes, cell signal is not good in here, but wifi is and tries to walk away. He looked like and dressed like he was the manager. I stopped him and frantically asked several times, is there a phone I could use?!?! Answer was no and he just kept going and left. I run outside, called the interviewer back and am now doing the interview outside, with all the background noise, people in the street, cars, you name it. I was really, really bummed out. Lucky for me, the interviewer understood my situation and he gave me a chance. I now went to get my laptop for the test via skype. As the manager said, the signal strength was good. But I couldn't connect to their F'ing wifi!!!! More than likely, their dhcp ran out of addresses and I struggled for the next 20 minutes trying to connect, I had a one hour deadline to finish this test. I was literally F'd and so F'ing pissed off. I grabbed my things and ran down the street to Starbucks to pay another round of fees to connect to their wifi. To top it off, not enough time to finish the test and lost my job opportunity. Motherf*ckers!!!! Will never ever come close to this F'ing café again. I don't usually write reviews but this café deserves a foot in their arse
author: Aaron H.

description: Excellent internet connection although charging for internet if you're purchasing food seems overkill. Also they need better variety of food.
author: Alfredo N.

description: Very few private rooms for events or meeting. Not suitable for startups. Food here is very plain with nothing special.  Employees are rude and it closes early. Won't ever come back again. Do yourself a flavor and go to WeWork instead even though this place is cheap.
author: Jack W.

description: Customer service was good. Barista not only gave me recommendations but brought my food to me and then threw it away afterward. I'd just give one star if it weren't for him. But the food was HORRIBLE. I got an Asian noodle dish. They were out of the sesame chicken so they used chipotle chicken. That was fine and wasn't the problem...there was so little chicken in it anyway. The problem was it was just...nasty. Overcooked noodles. Unincorporated and poorly cut/diced ingredients. Served in a cardboard tray. Tasted like something a college kid who has never cooked before might throw together in a dorm room using portable cooking appliances. I'd be ok with that if it were cheap but it was about $13. Don't order the Asian noodle dish. As for the work stations, they were fine as I didn't have to pay as a first time customer. Wifi was fine. App was fine. I doubt I'll return to work there though because I think buying food/drink is more than enough payment to work. I can see charging for the private rooms...but for a chair? Why not just require a minimum purchase amount for food/drink? I'll tell you why...because their food is inedible.
author: Lauren D.

description: Good food at reasonable price but dirty :( they need to bus their tables every once in a while
author: Chris W.

description:
On my journey of work-friendly cafe exploration, Workshop Cafe is probably one of the best for entrepreneurs, self-employed, or start-ups. The vicinity is HUGE! It literally can seat about 200 people. They have different size workspaces ranging from small conference rooms, big tables, couches, to benches. You log in through an app and you can even order your drink at your seat and they will bring it out to you. How convenient! 

In general, this is a very invigorating place to work and get motivated since it is right in the Financial District and everyone at the cafe is working their butts off! A plus is that they use Stumptown Coffee in all of their drinks. One negative would probably be that it can get very crowded and loud sometimes. The small conference rooms need reservations ahead.
author: Sally H.

description: This is a great concept but the music is way too loud!!!  The same horrible pop music you have to endure at the gym and at the grocery store you get to listen to full blast at this cafe. It entirely defeats the purpose of this workspace. Who can concentrate when you are trying to drown out the loud obnoxious music? And it's piping through the entire vast space. You cannot escape it. I put on headphones with my own music and I STILL couldn't drown it out. Why have ANY music when most people want to play their own? and it's a workspace!!! I complained and was told they do not control the music or volume. Well who does? They didn't have email or phone number for me to contact management. You can probably get more done at a Starbucks.  I will continue to search for a better workspace and unfortunately will not be returning to this place.  I had such high hopes :(
author: Carol K.

description: BEST COFFEE EVER! Orders the iced honey and it was absolutely delic! Not to sweet had a very smooth coffee flavor. The bagels are also great and the green goddess cream heads is very tasty! Definitely check it out if you're craving a coffee and bagel!
author: Smriti S.

description:
Love love love this place! Stumbled upon it yesterday while searching for a place downtown to work that had wifi, outlets, and a productive friendly atmosphere. Well, this place has all three of those in spades. The system is a bit complicated for first timers (I saw a few confused tourists and older people who didn't grasp the concept of having to provide a phone number and download the app while I was there), but I got more done there in the four hours I was there yesterday than I have in many, many other cafes. 

The staff were super friendly, smiley and welcoming and were happy to explain the check-in system to anyone who asked. 

Haven't tried the food yet but it looks yummy. Definitely a go-to for me from now on.
author: Grace C.

description:
Their drinks are not bad but so far, anything I have ordered for lunch sucked so bad. 

It used to be more quiet. These days, there are too many marketing guys making cold-calls from there. They are pretty loud and repeat the same thing over and over.
author: Shabnam K.

description:
Great place to work and use the Internet.  Comfortable chairs and quality coffee.

My one complaint is the number of restrooms is woefully inadequate.  Also the men's stall had a gap in the door about two inches wide so you feel like you're doing your business out in the open while a three person deep line hangs out outside your stall.  I'm sure building code will prevent expanding the restroom, but the stall issue can surely be taken care of.  Please fix this.
author: David S.

description: Expensive for the food you get. Food is really really bad (at least for my taste). But it's worth a try if you're looking to do work either individually or with other people. Good coffee
author: Rim K.

description: This place is amazing, why can't they open one in South Bay? I felt very productive here.. it made me feel like I was working at a super cool start-up. The food was actually pretty good too, I got the stir fry ramen. I really love how you can order the food on an app and they bring it out to you. I did wish I had a little bit more individual space as I was trying hard not to have my eyes wander around a little bit and accidentally make it look like I was looking at what someone was working on... either way, I'd still come back! :) I'm kind of curious if you can book individual spots next to each other with a couple friends instead of booking a room or a whole table ...
author: Fiona L.

description:
Workshop Cafe is a great place to study, work, or just hang out, especially in groups! They have tons of tables and some mini conference rooms that can be reserved if you plan on working with other people. On the other hand, you can also work alone in peace because the groups are usually pretty respectful of others. The first 10 hours are free and then it's $2 per hour after as most have stated. Most people pay for the environment but I pay to make sure I get shit done because $2 an hour can get expensive quick!

Experience: One of the better places to do work in FiDi. This place is even better than my own office! I have to get up and get my own lattes at work so this place definitely pulls at my very lazy heart strings. The service in general is pretty nice. I do feel like one of the guy's here mean mugs me / gives me a hard time but I forget all about it when my yummy latte and everything bagel with egg come.  

Food/Coffee: Both the coffee and food here are delicious! The prices are average which definitely helps offset the hourly sitting rate. Bagel + Egg = $3.5 of goodness while the Latte = $4. To be clear, the Egg and Cheese Bagel Sandwich isn't a steamed egg patty with a slice of cheese. They scramble the eggs with cheese (I think cheddar) and plop it in between two toasted buns. The Latte has a decent amount of foam with my perfect cream / coffee ratio. One of these things keeps me grinding for a good couple hours. If neither tickle your fancy, you're more than welcome to bring in your own goodies. 

Environment: This place must have it's own breaker with the number of outlets available (that means there's A LOT of outlets!). There's a nice mix of programmers, students and young professionals. In my experience, this isn't a place to talk to your neighbor. The vibe is pretty laid back but people try to be productive here. Not to mention, +1 for having to worry about bums harassing me while I work like at some other coffee shops.

At first, I was completely against going to this style of coffee shop because I didn't see the value for paying to sit somewhere to work when I can go elsewhere for free. Now, I come here a couple times a week simply because I don't have to get up for my own coffee plus it forces me to be productive. This place isn't for everyone but I definitely recommend everyone give them a try.
author: Chris W.

description:
I popped into this place the other day for lunch, because I had 45 minutes before a meeting that was right next door. I waited 28 minutes for my turkey sandwich, and when it arrived, it was on bread so stale that I had to throw it away. I would have asked for another, but at that time my meeting was starting in 10-15 minutes, and I had to leave. I was able to pull off and eat the cheese and turkey, so I guess there's that. 

In their defense, it was super busy, and so I understood the long wait time. The service was friendly, especially the guy at the register who took my order. However, the bread was so OBVIOUSLY stale, that I am quite surprised it made it to the plate. 

The space is very well-designed and functional, with a TON of space and electrical outlets, and I can see why so many people go there to work. I just wish the staff would have been more selective about serving something that was totally inedible.
author: Jean O.

description:
Came here today and I'm sort of in awe and blown away by this concept.  Basically, you pay 2 dollars an hour for a guaranteed spot with outlets in a beautiful and creativity-inducing environment.  With that, you also have the ability to order drinks and food from your phone, which will then be brought to you.  Also, you get to network with likeminded people thru the app.  I mean this place is basically the coolest hub I've ever been to.

The coffee is brewed from Stumptown beans so you know you're always going to get a good cup.  I can't say too much about the food, I only had a chocolate croissant, but the salmon miso salad was screaming my name. (Next time I promise!)  Also you can get popcorn which is weirdly something I always crave when I'm hard at work.

Also, you can get beer and wine (for a surprisingly good price).  Although it was a bit too early to add a cold Pranqster to my order, it's a definite possibility for the future.  I mean, what makes reading through academic research papers easier than a tall glass of beer? (Answer: nothing)

While this isn't a place I'd come to everyday I'll be missing it whenever I'm in my normal cafe settings.  Workshop, you've spoiled me and shown me everything a cafe COULD BE, now Starbucks just won't be the same!

Til next time, keep eating keep learning!
author: Jason M.

description:
Work Space: As a workspace it's decent. Better than being at a loud coffee shop. Specially if you are working on a project and have to be there for a few hours. It's also really good if you need to have a private space for meetings.... Overall its a good place to work at... thats if all you need is a desk space and to be in a quiet setting.

The reason why I am giving it 2 stars is because we are paying for an hourly rate to be there and it would be nice if you guys can keep things clean around there specially in the restrooms. It's so unsanitary, smells and most of the time in the afternoon your basic restroom needs (toilet paper, paper towels or soap) aren't even available.... which makes me think that your kitchen is even worst... 

Your food could be better but no judgement there, you guys are a co-working space not an actual cafe or restaurant..... I wish you could provide more options or try to improve since sometimes we spend hours there and it would be SO convenient if the service was good....

Staff: Nice people but really poor service.
author: Daisy Z.

description:
In love with this place! Can get a little crowded during peak hours in the afternoon if youre planning to stay in their work space so you can find yourself standing on the way side for a few minutes. TIP THOUGH: YOU CAN GET ON THEIR APP AND RESERVE A SEAT BEFORE HAND!! :O Shhh dont tell! Or If you're just planning to eat and stay for a short while, the seats outside and before the counter are free to use if available and with no charge! :)

Food here is delicious and youve got a variety of choices from a kale avocado salad, avocado or cream cheese bagel to a cheese plate or chicken stirfry that you can load up on SRIRACHA that they have on the side, thats a plus for me! Always come in for the CHAI TEA LATTE but thats just a personal favorite :) They serve BEER AND WINE AND COFFEE as well so take your pick!

Your 1st 10 hours are free to set up shop on one of their tables and they have multiple outlets for you to keep your electronics charged up and keep work going! Different table styles as well from high stools, comfy office chairs, couch types or regular wood chairs all for your tush's liking. 

Once you've redeemed your ten hours you have to start paying for use per hour but its quite affordable for what you get. Their website has everything on there and setting your account up is easy! 

Basically find myself working from here when Im in the city! You cant go wrong with this place if you want your own Cafe/Office for the day! :) 

They could do more cleaning up/renovation at that back room but I think they already are. :)

OH OH!! UPDATE: THEYVE PARTNERED UP WITH MR. HOLMES' BAKEHOUSE THATS SET UP A LITTLE STAND BY THE ENTRANCE FOR FRESH PASTRIES! TRY TO GRAB ONE OF THEIR CRUFFINS IF AVAILABLE OR CHOUX BOMBS! THOSE ARE THE BEST!
author: Margaret G.

description:
I can totally see this being a GREAT place to get work done and to collaborate with others.  Came here to work with P and ran into a friend who was here with his coworker!

Lots of different kinds of spaces and seats and a very smooth sign-in system.   The people who work here are incredibly friendly too.

The food and drinks? Not so great.  The iced honey almond latte was incredibly sweet and tasted like cereal milk.  I didn't finish it.  It was $5.  I guess though, in a way, like every other cafe, you're paying for the space.

PS: Great bathrooms!
author: Jun K.

description:
In the heart of the Financial District workshop cafe seem to be attracting hard working entrepreneurs and students of all ages. They take a small fee for letting go you use their workspace, filled with different types of seating arrangements to suit all type of working groups, and overflowing with sockets enough for all your devices. The entrepreneurial atmosphere and the well lit yet comfy environment inspires to get your stuff done. 

Only negative was that the items on the menu was quite pricy, I paid $4.35 for a quite watery iced coffee. But on the other hand I can imagine their electrical bill being through the roof so it might be justified!
author: Camilla E.

description:
Great, open working space. The concept of paying for working space kinda sucks but I totally understand. It's awesome that your first 10 hours are free though! The only reason I would rate this a star or two down is the wait to get your drink. With 4 people behind the counter, you would expect the turnover rate to be just a tad bit faster. This has been the case my last 3-4 visits, which have all been at different times of the day.  

For someone on a tight schedule, I wouldn't recommend this coffee stop. But if you're looking for a place to work in the FiDi for a few hours, this would def be at the top of my list!
author: Frances K.

description: Coffee is nothing interesting.. The energy from all the entrepreneurial people working here is great and the appeal to the place.
author: Tuan V.

description: Delicious Cusco soup, pretty good pour over coffee, and nice ambience. Decor is modern and hipster. There is a $2/hour fee to use their exclusive workspace, which is a bit of a turnoff, but I doubt I'll be spending much time there to want to use their wifi and work areas. I'll be back to try their horchatta and bagels.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Great coffee. Always happy, but a few tips for the barista who made a latte when i requested a cappuccino: http://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-make-cappuccino-2013-9

Don't reuse the milk
Don't burn it
You need foam, not just steamed milk, but foam.
author: Alina T.

description:
This has become my regular work space. I love that they only charge by the hour instead of requiring a monthly subscription - I don't need a coworking space every day. The wifi is great and always reliable.

+ order food and drinks by text, and delivered to your seat - neat!
+ coffee is great (stumptown!)
+ awesome popcorn is indeed awesome
+ lots of work arrangements (booths, tables, couches, little rooms, bigger rooms, tall chairs, short chairs, etc.)

- sometimes difficult to get a room to take phone calls, and only can use those rooms for an hour unless you pre-reserve
- the food is ok but gets a little monotonous so I usually go find lunch elsewhere now (this is not true for the awesome popcorn though!)
author: Matt H.

description:
This place has an awesome concept and I really, really hope it spreads. Sadly it's not cheap. On the other hand, (1) fast wifi (2) decent food (3) lots of drinks (4) lots of other people working to inspire you (5) plug outlets like crazy!

Easy to spend a whole weekend day working here.
author: B H.

description:
Need to get work done for a long stretch of time? This is definitely the place to be.

I was a total nube and had no idea how to check-in/get my coffee/etc and they were so sweet! I only stayed for two hours (first 10 workshop hours are free), but was so productive! I liked that the workshop area wasn't library quiet but it still had a wonderful, diligent atmosphere about it. I was half-expecting to be around grouchy, stuck-up customers and staff and was pleasantly surprised by how nice everyone was! This place really embodies the start-up, chill ambience of SF that I know & love! 

**bonus: AMAZING Stump Town coffee. Didn't know what the hype was all about until I finally tried it, and now I'm hooked. They don't even charge extra for almond milk substitutions #WIN!
author: Aradhana V.

description:
Great work space, but they charge $2/hour to use their workspace.  

Warning- the food is not good.  I never throw food away, but I threw my food away here.  (I ordered a kale salmon bowl and some stale blueberry muffin.)  Probably will not return, since SF has other incredible cafes with free wifi.
author: Dana C.

description:
Need to get work done? Ya need to come here. 

This was unlike any "cyber cafe" I've ever been to and a place that seemed oh so "San Francisco" to me. Not going to lie, it was a bit intimidating seeing the place packed with people working away but I decided to start at the counter and order an iced coffee while I figured out how exactly everything worked. Word to the wise, if you need something to really perk you up, Stumptown iced coffee is the rocket fuel to do just that! 

From there, I found one of the few vacant spots and "checked in" on their website to connect to the wi-fi. Whoever set this place up sure put a lot of thought into it! I didn't take advantage of some of the cool features like ordering from your seat but at least made sure to get my table number right. This is important as we had someone come and check-in to make sure we had done just that. Like others have mentioned, first 10 hours are FREE.

There are lots of focused people up in here, giving you that sense of purpose to really buckle down and focus. It also has plenty of outlets so you don't have to worry about losing juice throughout the day. 

So, yeah. Wi-fi, coffee, power and seats? Workshop has your back.
author: Cassie P.

description:
Walking through FiDi the other day, I got shat upon by a pigeon. So I stepped into this place for a napkin to clean myself up. The barista was so pleasant, and I was so inspired by the random choosing of me by a pigeon, I decided to stay and write awhile.
The cafe is crammed with hard-working tech kids on laptops. They have an extra level of service, where you log into an app and get the fancy indoor couches and outlet-laden work tables, but I opted for the front porch's shared communal table. 
The friendly barista turned out to know what she was doing with a pot of rose peppermint tea, rare at most coffee joints that feel as hip as this one does. I received exquisite service and enjoyed the intentional working environment. 
It's everything I want in a writers café. I might even check out the app next time.
author: Kristy L.

description:
Fast wifi, great coffee and your own seat for however long you need/ want to stay? Um why aren't you hesitating to come work or study here? 

First 10 hours are free, so if you're from out of town and working remotely park your booty in one of the seats! After 10 hrs it's $2/hour.

The staff is nice and the place is nicely organized.
author: Pattie L.

description:
I love this place. It's a combo cafe + co-working-space-by-the-hour. 10 free hours when you sign up. It's very conveniently located near the Montgomery BART station. Rent a chair or table or kiosk for a long or as short amount of time as you want. You can order from your chair via email and txt and they deliver your drinks and food. You can even rent conference rooms and private workspaces.

The overall package is terrific but, frankly, the best part is the staff. They are incredibly friendly, responsive and helpful.
author: Matthew T.

description:
Still loving Workshop Cafe.

For all the reasons I previously mentioned (great service, great coffee, great workspace!).

And, now, also for:

1)  Stumptown coffee--because it's the best.  Period.  They use single origin coffees delivered fresh from Portland weekly.  Coffee excellence, my people....coffee excellence.

and 2)  Their chocolate croissant.  Because, what makes a great cup of coffee even greater?  Sipping it along side and buttery, flakey, chocolate croissant.  Everybody knows that.

The service is lovely, the coffee is amazing, and great eats to boot? 

Get to it!
author: Ophelia M.

description:
Cocky and rude wait staff. I picked up my latte a minute late and the "barista" scoffed at me when I asked to confirm if it was my drink: "uh, yeah, duh" was his response. Sorry baby Napoleon. 

Beware the barista who looks barely above 15. He hasn't made it through his teenage years yet.
author: Adrienne S.

description:
I can't believe how long it took me to find this place. I study law around the corner of workshop. I experienced one year of solitude in a library. I could have been here!!!!!!!

Love this place. Love the concept. Brilliant!
author: Cece F.

description:
I will not use a cafe that requires my phone number to get a seat. I will not give you my email address to sit at a table at your cafe. Completely ridiculous.

Want me to "check in" to a table using your app? Put it on an iPad next to the register. Or hey: brilliant idea! Ask me where I want to sit, and I'll POINT at it. No app required. I realize that this might limit your ability to spam me later. I'm comfortable with that.

Also, $4 for a cup of tea is insane when you're being charged by the hour to sit down. Get real. You can gouge people for food, or charge them for tables. You can't do both.
author: Tim R.

description: Great workstations and ambience. Multiple options to where you can sit. Free WiFi. For the workspace, first 10 hrs is free and 2$/hr which is acceptable. I will definitely come back here.
author: Ihtha I.

description:
Very nice concept, it's right on the way to my evening classes from work, perfect spot to stop by. I wouldn't order anything because the food is pricey and I'm not a coffee drinker. I brought my own tea, instead in thermo. 

I wish they have a nap room, for extra charge of course, that would be awesome!
author: Yoko S.

description:
A nice spot if you need a place to study or work. Good wifi, and it's usually not too crowded.

I lost my wallet at this place a while ago. The staff helped me looking for it but found nothing at first. A couple days ago, the staff emailed me that they found it. I really appreciate that they took the effort finding me even I didn't leave my contacts! Thank you Workshop Cafe!
author: C L.

description:
Yay hipster coffee shops. This place is so SF tech scene. My friend and I wanted to grab a coffee here ... but did not realize that apparently you have to "check out" a work space since it's a workshop cafe haha clever. Anyways so if you don't check out a space, you're confined to this sad pathetic black carpet area where it is so crammed and if there are lots of people you would be bumping elbows. BUT if you check out a space, it's pretty sick. I would actually be really down to work here. They supposedly have super fast wifi, outlets everywhere, solid desks, and honestly the place has a really great working vibe; I dig it.

In terms of the coffee, I got a mocha which is not even real coffee but it was still delicious. $4.5 which is expensive but what the price is these days especially given that it's FiDi. Anyways it was a good mocha though.

tldr; would be more likely to want to come here to work rather than drink coffee. really dope working space
author: Jasmine X.

description: The food was very tasty. I was really hungry, so the portion didn't hold me over, but that was my own fault. This is probably a great place to hold a work meeting. They have dedicated seating for working with power and WIFI. I did not need to hold a work meeting, so the seating for just getting a bite to eat was a bit limited. Prices are typical for SF, but if you're on a budget, this might not be the best place to grab a bite to eat. The menu is not extensive, so if you need options, you may want to keep on looking. If you're standing in this place looking up reviews, I say give it a shot. The breakfast burrito was yummy and I'd order it again.
author: David H.

description:
This place is a great example of everything that's right and wrong in san francisco.
Are you a entrepreneur with a start up? Do you need a meeting space that is comfortable and offers everything you'll need to complete a project (meeting rooms, connectivity, white boards, privacy)? This place is for you.
The wi fi is blazing fast, the coffee and food are good verging on great and best of all if you are choosing the for fee (by the hour, two hour min.) inside section you'll be separated from all the common people that aren't like you.
If you are just wanting a cup of coffee this place has the fastest in and out in the area. Just walk in, drop a couple of bucks in the jar and grab a cup. 
And then get out because if you are not using the for fee section that has the wi fi, you are not welcome here. The section for non wi fi using folks is tiny and while the furniture is modern it is terribly uncomfortable, and does not compare well with the plush couches visible in the roped off section. Similarly the full menu is only available in the paid access section.
In summary this place offers a lot for the technology savvy success story, and practically nothing if you do not meet that criteria.   
I can think of no other place in america where the divide between those that have and those that have not are more starkly revealed. 
It's an interesting go to for that reason alone.
author: Steven W.

description: The wifi speed is unacceptably slow when the space is very crowded on Sunday evening. Wifi speed was at 5Mps upload and download that I cannot play my videos. For a workshop whose value prop is about providing a space for people with laptops, this is below par wifi speed. I will not go here again with my laptop. Otherwise, this is a good quiet space for reading a book surrounded by everyone using laptops.
author: Susan T.

description:
I came here a lot when I was grading practice AP exams, and it definitely was a lifesaver. I went through my 10 free hours fairly quickly, but it was the added pressure of needing to be productive during the paid hours that definitely put me in high gear. 

Most of the time when I come here, I manage to snag a seat on the long couch with a table, but I do know a lot of people who reserve spaces in advance (pretty cool feature). When I meet coworkers or friends here, we meet in the free section, which still has wifi and you have the option of being indoors or outdoors.

The snacks and drinks are all pretty pricey, but all delicious. My guilty pleasures: the honey almond milk latte ($5) and their almond croissant (~$4), which I think is from the legendary Mr. Holmes Bakehouse!
author: Julia H.

description:
This might have been the worst customer service I've received in San Francisco. On one occasion, there were at least six people working the bar but not a single person came up to help me until I called out a couple minutes later. While waiting for my drink, and off-duty employee came in and asked for a drink. The staff behind the counter immediately stopped making my drink and instead made the drink for the employee although I was standing at the counter at the time.

At first, Workshop seems like a novel idea. It offers a place to do work in the Financial District, a place where space is always at a premium. After some time, I realized it's just another way to charge extra money. The set up is fairly cheap and even the meeting rooms aren't very good for the price. If you need to meet in the FiDi, I recommend finding a real conference room that you can book for about the same price.
author: Bucky P.

description:
I think I've found my new work spot in SF. 

Food and drink options are good. Had the Avo scramble and a fantastic rose tea. 

The workstations are a separate, which is great. Got 10 free work hours for being a first timer and the wifi is strong. Great atmosphere, cool networking opportunities and perfect location in FIDI. 

Loved it. Will def be back.
author: Kamille R.

description:
The idea of a workshop cafe is that you pay to have decent WiFi. I spent more than half an hour battling terrible internet connection. After speaking with the concierge, he passed me onto a technician on the phone. 15 minutes of troubleshooting later, I had good connection for about 10 minutes and then the internet died again. 

The coffee here is so bad. Avoid it if you actually enjoy drinking coffee, their cappuccinos and americanos are worse than instant. On top of that, its expensive. Plain Ice tea is $4. No idea what I'm paying for. Its not like the tea tastes good, or that the service is good. Their chairs are nice but i seriously need to find another place to work. This is not the place
author: Evelyn W.

description: Love this space! Perfect place to work, and the coffee was good as well. Wifi is fast and I really like the layout of the coffee shop - comfy booths, plenty of outlets, very spacious. FiDi is a little out of my way but I'll definitely come back here lots. Also at some point during the 3 hours I was sitting here with my laptop they played SchoolBoy Q, which is definitely a plus in my book. Taking off one star just because I find the whole check-in system kind of finnicky.
author: Ava H.

description:
My rating is a 3, but I think that I simply came at a bad time.  The coffee on drip was not particularly fresh at around 6 o'clock in the evening, but that is to be expected.  However, it was on the water-y side, which was somewhat surprising.  The coffee is priced in accordance with SF standards (starting with a 3 dollar ish espresso).  Their food is anywhere from a 6-9 dollar price, but the portions are small.  The cafe is definitely a nice place to work or to read.  

You can sit and chat almost anywhere in the cafe.  They have a dedicated working area, but it requires that you sign up for an application and after you have worked there for 10 hours, it costs 2 dollars per hour to continue.  

I will probably go back again to try their espresso beverages.  I believe they were serving 4 Barrel Coffee, which is quite good, so I have high expectations for the next time that I go.  This is definitely a cafe that I would like to like due to the atmosphere.
author: Alexander P.

description:
$2 grab and go. Stumptown coffee. 
Outlets literally everywhere. Huge, cozy workspace, which I believe they charge by the hour for. Fresh squeezed OJ &kombucha on tap. Some employees are friendlier than others, but it's expected. Conveniently located near Bart in FiDi. Honestly, pretty much all you need to know.
author: Christine G.

description: Come to workshop cafe' if you are just walking in a cold evening and you don't know where to go; or if you want a quiet place to work with your pc. Please don't order the espresso, trust me. It is like geting a kick in your mouth. It just taste like burnt  manure. I m feeling sorry for all the italian espresso.
author: Pierpaolo M.

description:
This place is terrible

I ordered a latte and a bagel
I went to the non workspace place to sit, whereby didn't have to pay to sit.

The workspace was empty,, the regular place was small and packed.  You have to pay to sit in the "workspace".. I wasn't told this till after I ordered my latte and bagel.

Someone else grabbed my bagel so inward stuck in this dump for an extra 15min.  It was freezing , they had then door open.. 

Overall experience was a 1 star

If they opened up the "workspace" to is non paying type of people. Then it would be a lot better..

Not going back regardless..
author: Beth M.

description:
When you need a place to get work done without feeling guilty about taking up space. I've done phone interviews here, worked on resumes, worked on work. The hot cereal is delicious. Nice servers. It's a great concept.

Improvements: Add more snack choices.
author: T M.

description:
I was finished with class, and waiting for my boyfriend to get out of work-- so I wanted to get some work done and tried to search for a café. 

My search brought me to Workshop Cafe, mecca of many power outlets and abundant workspaces. It's cool because the first 10 hours of work here are free, and after that, you pay $2/hr, which is pretty chill and worth the wait. You can have people deliver food and drinks to your workspace, which you reserve on the app. I imagine this place must be great for startups who don't have a space, but I really liked it as a study space. You don't even have to get coffee or food (since you're paying for the "time"/"space" rather than the drinks,) but it works in a pinch since they can just deliver it to your seat. There are outlets EVERYWHERE-- you never have to fight for a space, yaaaas! There is also ample seating, and if you stay in front, you never actually have to pay for working here (hint hint.) 

It reminds me of all those London coworking spaces without the prices. Over all, I had a pretty good experience here and it was pretty conducive to working. I'll have to come back to try the coffee, but the iced chai I had wasn't that bad at $4. The food seems overpriced, but they are also more than willing to get more food nearby at an additional cost if you're not happy with the selection they have at the cafe. (Talk about customer service!) I'll be back, Workshop Cafe. Especially because you're open super late!
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
I stopped in here briefly to finish up a project, and I ended up cranking it out in less than an hour, which I fully attribute to the shared work space vibe of this cafe unlike that of any coffee shop in the Financial District. 

You technically have to pay to sit at a table and work, which is so Bay Area, but it's worth it.  It's quieter than you'd expect, (but not too quiet), and there's plenty of table-top space to get your work done, outlets galore, and endless cups of coffee.  Go here to finish up that one thing you've been struggling to cross off your to-do list.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Loved working here during my trip to SF! The service is great, the food is delicious, and they actually have fast WiFi (hard to find in SF oddly enough). 

Here's what I had:
Chai - good 
Avocado scrambled eggs - great 
Iced black tea - great, but expensive for tea 
White bean, Kale, pasta soup - great 
Bagel & cream cheese - good 
Gorgonzola grape walnut salad - good
Healthy popcorn - weird (had olive oil and nutritional yeast and was just a weird flavor)
**but when the staff saw that I didn't eat much of it they offered to make me more any way I wanted. 

Staff is super awesome and friendly! I loved texting my order in and they bring it right to your table. Work space is $2/hr but your first 10 hours are free!
author: Daniela C.

description:
I love this place but not tonight. The guy tonight played the "Closing Time" song at an unreasonable level and was really rude about it. I was leaving already, and I get headaches easily.
When I politely suggested to the guy that it was too loud, he said "oh, so you're sensitive??" and turned it UP. I'm sorry, but that's extremely insensitive and made me leave the place with a bad feeling in my mouth. It was only 9:57, plus I was well on my way to leaving. I normally love Workshop Cafe but this type of behaviour makes me not want to recommend it to friends.

Beside this incident, they normally treat their customers very well and it is a pleasant place to work. I'll still give it 3 stars, because usually it's pretty good, but this incident makes me think that Workshop Cafe would be a terrible place to have an important meeting. Imagine hearing "Closing Time" during a pitch!
author: Oliver C.

description:
This place is amazing.

You simply log in and find a seat...the rest is easy!

The atmosphere is very "startup-ish" with many aspiring entrepreneurs on their MacBook Pro's.  Whether you are there to study or do work, the vibe will make you more productive than if you were sitting at home, or even a regular coffee shop. 

From your seat, you can order food, coffee etc. and they bring it out to you, which is pretty cool.  I ordered a latte, which was amazing, and a Thai chicken salad, which was mediocre.  There are definitely better nearby options when comparing food only, but this place obviously has many advantages over a regular sandwich shop.  

Check this place out next time you need a place to do some work, send some e-mails, or study for the GMAT!
author: Juliana K.

description:
I would give it additional stars but I was a bit turned off for my first time experience with the following events:
1:  while taking my order the cashier was replaced by another during my order taking - my initial thoughts were - at least let the guy finish before being replaced.
2: Apparently this is a norm - which is another turn off - cashiers and food preparers rotate consistently - which means the guy who takes your cash and handles your credit card is also the guy who prepares your food which leads me to point 3
3: they dont wear gloves when they prepare the food. :/

There's a lot of basic etiquette that is completely ignored.   

By the way, to be fair,  coffee is great, the avo egg sandwich which I had - tasted fresh - the toast could have been warmer - it seemed like it laid there for awhile.

Other than that - great concept just need to clean up in terms of restaurant etiquacy ( not a proper word but used in urban settings) 

Good Luck - I'll probably wont be back until I notice the food preparers wearing gloves.
author: Karim A.

description:
There is some indoor seating and plenty of outdoor seating to have a coffee meeting or just get some work done. The free WiFi is super strong. The service is excellent. There is an actual workspace (with plenty of electrical outlets) available for $2 per hour. Apparently the first 10 hours are free.

They have a "grab and go" coffee station, and Workshop Cafe always seems to have some sort of drink special when I walk by, whether it's a beer & wine happy hour or coffee something.

Oh and the food! I ordered the Arugula Artichoke Pepper Veggie Salad, and it was probably one of the best salads I've ever tasted. It contains spinach, romaine, arugula,  green beans, corn, tomatoes, carrots, purple cabbage, artichoke hearts, roasted peppers, garbanzo beans, mozzarella cheese, and shallot-dijon vinaigrette. If you like salads, this one is definitely worth trying.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Workshop Cafe and it's lovely baristas and staff - make one of the best hot drinks in the Financial District.  

Their Hot Honey Almond Latte (made with almond milk) - with just a tad of honey - is insanely what's up. If you don't want the caffeine - just ask for steamed milk with a dash of honey and your taste-buds will be demanding an encore....

I'm also a big fan of their ginger lemongrass tea. I can get a good 2-3 cups out of one bag. A lovely addition to any rainy day.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: there is no shortage of cafes in san francisco, though not all are conducive to actually getting work done... i've found it easy to be productive here (hence the name, i guess). the food menu is pretty expansive if you plan on staying awhile. i like that you can guarantee yourself a spot to sit and reserve a small personal room if you need more privacy ($5/hr).
author: Connie Q.

description: Very okay. The food isn't good - the bread was stale. There are stains and spills everywhere, dirty carpets, and flies flying around. All in all, needs a facelift!
author: Ann P.

description:
I haven't actually come here to work, but I like this concept. FiDi is such a business-oriented part of SF, so it's neat that there are options for business travelers or entrepreneurs who need a place to get work done for the day. When you first walk in, you'll see the "patio" section that has free wifi. You can sit here for an hour or two to work as you drink your coffee and eat. There are a couple tables outside too. Beyond the drink pick-up area are signs for the co-working space. Download their app to pay for your space.

The reason why I came here the first time was because I saw on the A-board outside that they use Stumptown beans! Yes, that famous coffee spot based in Portland. I'm a latte kind of girl, and they make a delicious latte for $3.75 :) There's a pour over, drip coffee, capp, on the menu too...the usual suspects.
author: Katherine S.

description: This place is ok. If you are from out of town like me & just looking to grab lunch this is not the best place to stop. It's great if you need a workspace for an afternoon (there's an hourly fee). I was hoping to try The Plant which is a block down, but to my surprise it was closed. I know it's a holiday, but not the norm for a restaurant. Anyway, the reason this place isn't the best if you are just eating lunch is that the wait is deceptive. There was no line when I arrived & figured the wait would be similar to most places. Completely wrong as all of the people in the workspace order food through a mobile app. I wish I had gone somewhere else. I got the BLT, it was ok. Nothing to rave about. I ordered it with no cheese or aoili so it was dairy free & it came out with cheese on it. They were quick to fix it though. I also got a banana & date smoothie which was tasty.
author: Katrina R.

description: First 10 hours free! No pressure to buy their food or drinks, but their menu did look quite good. Will need to try the next time I go back.
author: Sarah L.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to work remotely at whenever I find myself in the city. Although in most cases, I find myself trekking up with Workshop Cafe on my mind. ;)

Everyone is on their laptop or having some kind of collaborative meeting, which adds to that productive atmosphere. Makes you want to dive into work and crank up the productivity, too!

You check-in to your "workspace" with the corresponding table number indicated by a sticker at the corner of the table using your mobile phone. The first 10 hours are free; this goes by quickly after a couple of visits. After your free 10 hours are up, you have to pay at $2/hour. However, you must buy in their package deal, meaning at minimum you're paying $10 for 5 hours. If you happen to score a workspace in the front, you don't have to pay. I personally think it's kind of lame to charge since there is a bunch of Starbucks nearby with plenty of seating -- for free! 

I do have to say I enjoy the Kyoto Cold Brew, which is more than reasonably priced. If you're a coffee enthusiast of any sorts, you'll know a quality Kyoto brew is a long, extensive process. $4 is a steal. :)
author: Kathleen N.

description: The best cafe to work from in all of SF. They do not have unisex restrooms, only gendered restrooms. Which is a complete shame, because everything else about this place is awesome. Refuge restrooms shows the closest nearby unisex restroom is sutter station, guess i'm drinking whiskey for lunch :/
author: Tommy D.

description: First visit but it's a good one: amazing salmon salad, comfortable and reasonably priced workspaces, good music that isn't distracting. I'd come back.
author: Be F.

description:
I freakin loved this place! I wish there's one in nova...

The food was pretty good, the drink was pretty good. The staff was really friendly in explaining how the "workshop" aspect worked. I was working on stuff for about 3 hours and pretty much every other person who wanted to work there asked her how the system works. She just kept explaining it to every person... such patience lol...

Fast internet, good music... really good place to focus. :)
author: Wendy D.

description:
I like Workshop Cafe. Great space. I really dig the Erik Otto paintings in the front and throughout the Cafe. The world needs more Erik Otto work. 
I give it 4 stars.

But I don't understand how people can be so dirty. I've watched grown adults eat, leave their trash on the table and just leave. This place stays clean until these type of idiots show up. Also I think it's quite stupid that this place doesn't allow their employees to accept tips. That's some foolish crap. The staff here handles multiple jobs and will even bring your food to you table. Thats the type of service I tip for. Thats probably the only thing I subtracted a star for. Everyone should be able to accept gratuity.
author: Merlin J.

description: First time heading to a shared workspace, and it was awesome. Download the app for that free 10 hours or so though and grab a seat inside. I felt compelled to order a burger (I got hungry) and it was surprisingly good, if a bit overpriced.
author: Ke D.

description:
I really love this place.  I worked nearby and didn't understand the concept at first.  Then once I did, I was very skeptical that the place would take off.  Now it is packed all of the time!  I'm absolutely willing to pay for using the space and avoid the problems with sitting in a regular coffee shop.  Workshop has comfortable seats, spaces actually set up to accommodate your laptop with lots of plugs, great wifi connections, relatively quiet with out a lot of loud talking because everyone is working, and good music.  I love the stations on the back wall with the big monitors!

The food is also good, especially the oatmeal.  You can just text your order, and they'll bring it to your seat and charge against your account via the mobile app.  That's actually better because sometimes the staff can have a bit of an attitude.

I got started because I downloaded the app as a way to check in and give it a try.  You get a bunch of free hours when you first download and start using the mobile app, so it was no risk.
author: Heather H.

description: This place is pretty cool, definitely has a hipster atmosphere.  It was near capacity when I visited for the first time on a late Thursday morning, around 10:30/11.  There are a few separate "areas" where you can sit: outside, inside (but not in the workplace area), and in the workplace area.  I don't think it ever got to a point where there were no more seats, but I know some people had to sit outside which probably wasn't very pleasant since it was cold out.  I wanted to sit in the workplace area but unfortunately there were no more available spaces.  Not a huge deal, I still got a seat inside.  From what I understood, you have to go up to the big screen with the iPad (it's near the back, hard to miss), and "check-in" to be able to use the workspace.  Hopefully I'll get to use it next time.  The espresso was delicious.  Will be returning soon!
author: Bayilani V.

description: Love bringing my laptop here and getting some work done! Super cool concept- you pay a small fee per hour to work here. Great for free-lancers and startups who want to be in a social fun environment instead of at home. You can order food and drinks through text and don't even have to get up! Very fast wifi and meeting rooms also available. Great location too.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Needed a quiet place to read and work while downtown so I stopped by Workshop Cafe. While I could've gone to any of the Starbucks in the area, most of the cafes with open seating in FiDi are very loud so it's difficult to focus especially if you have a lot of work to do. 

Workshop Cafe is a great spot since there is an open seating area, but also a reserved seating area for $2/hr. You simply check in with your smartphone via mobile web app and you have your table reserved until you check out. Your first 10 hours are free so definitely stop by and see if the space works for you. There are also some meeting rooms and monitors if you are looking for a group meeting space.

I only got coffee while I was there, but the cafe also has food. Can't attest to how good the food is, but I will update my review if I end up going back again.
author: Derek L.

description:
Pretty good, there was plenty of space available on a weekday morning. The coffee was fine, Stumptown is reliable though not my favorite. It was self-serve from a giant dispenser so didn't taste particularly fresh.

Pastries are decent, too, so all in all a good spot to drop in on for a snack and some caffeine while you work.
author: Jim B.

description:
Please note, that my review is only for the 'free section' and others who paid to sit will have different experiences. Or those that rent a conference room. 

If you, like me, want to get out of your apartment, go to a place to open up your laptop for a couple hours, drink a cup-o-joe and be productive, I'd recommend not going to Workshop Cafe. And this hurts me to say as I had high hopes for this concept. 

You can tell right off the bat they don't cater to the coffee and laptop clicker person. They only offer one size of coffee and while I'm impressed by the self pay, self pour Square station, the flip side says we don't even care enough to deal with our lower end customers. This is only reinforced by the rest of the experience. 

The seats for the free section are horrible. Metal. Small and uncomfortable to sit in longer then 15mins. I use no hyperbole when I say McDonald's plastic chairs are more comfortable, all the while in view of the 'paid section' chairs  which are plush and comfy. 

There is no power available in the free section. Although you can admire and covet those in the 'paid section' that will have all their electron demands fulfilled. 

Lastly, it's as if they went out of their way to punish those that dare sit in the 'free section' by offering tables that are so skinny, your laptop hangs in constant danger of tipping over off the precarious edge. 

In summary, if you plan on working for an extended period of time, it makes more economical sense to invest the money you would pay for just the privileged of a comfy chair and power outlet, into another cafe that you can use to buy food, and get a comfortable chair and free wifi... for free.
author: Tim D.

description:
great concept! there are outlets everywhere. first 10 hours free. 

however, i dont think that the conference rooms have great reception. so make sure you are prepared and test in advance if you are going to use the conf rooms for calls!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I was first drawn into this place after seeing a sign that they brew Stumptown coffee. When I walked in it clicked why this place is called a workshop. They have a section of the cafe for people to basically work on their laptops. 

There's outlets and wifi available to the customers but at a charge of $2/hour. Otherwise there's an area in the front to just lounge. Everyone just seem to be in their own world. Overall it looks like a great quiet place to get some work done.

Soy Latte - My usual. Roasty. Tasty. I approve.
author: Michael C.

description: This place always caught my eye hanging around FiDi or on my way to my bank.  I had a free afternoon so I decided to grab a soy mocha and read a book where they  have patio seating (good people-watching!).  The mocha was soothing and creamy.  I love the space as there are plenty of places to sit with plugs galore for your technology.  I am not sure what the back area was but it looked like you could pay $2/hour for a quieter space to work and concentrate.  I was too lazy to ask but that is what I gathered.  I liked the energy of the place as lots of casual meetings gathered to discuss and plan and entrepreneur.  Very cool!
author: Maile N.

description:
The coffee is average-low. 

The seating situation is borderline ridiculous. There's a very small space that you can sit in "for free" (of course consuming something), and then they have an entire floor that you have to pay by the hour. The surface area of those two sections should be more balanced. I don't want to pay extra to sit at a nice place to have a coffee. 

They clearly cater to people that come to work. Don't come to get a coffee.
author: Antonio B.

description:
Compared to other cafe where you can just sit and do your work for free, I just don't get what people are paying for, especially if you do not need their conference room. Do people pay for faster and more secure wifi? No, the wifi speed is definitely just ok, and it is not protected by any password. Cheaper food or complimentary snacks? No, the food, as noted in other review, is just average, and the portion is kinda small compared to the price. Seriously, they don't even have lemon slices in water. Quieter and nicer environment? Still no, the background music is very loud, and although this area is further from the kitchen, the giant A/C they installed on the roof is constantly buzzing. Yea you may take orders from your phone, but, at least for me, it's so unimportant since I need to walk around a little bit after sitting for hours anyway, and can definitely order food whenever I give myself a short break.

Some may find those five Dell computers and conference rooms useful, but since most people work on their own laptop, and the conference room is just as equally loud as the open area, I don't think that add much value to it.
author: Alice C.

description: Great spot to work with your laptop.  Able to order a coffee to my seat with a text.  Plenty of seats too.
author: Scott N.

description:
This place is great for boosting productivity for those who need it (tech workers, entrepreneurs, college students) due to the spillover effect of other customers working diligently and paying for a seat in the cafe to work and the convenience of ordering food/drinks. If nothing's changed, then you get $20 credit for purchasing a seat in the cafe as a first time user, which I appreciated.
 
I was working on editing a draft of an economics research paper and hit a productivity slump during the week, so I came to Workshop and paid $2/hr to sit in a reserved section of the cafe for about 4 hours. Once I paid through their in-house app and saw the timer ticking down, I was driven to focus more than I would have at home or at work. If you get hungry, you can order food  through the in house app to be delivered to your seat so that you stay in the zone of productivity. Their honey turkey and apple sandwich was surprisingly good and not outrageously priced.
author: Shelley C.

description:
This place looks like just another hipster coffee joint in San Francisco. I work less than a block away and I avoided it for a long time, until a friend offered to treat me to coffee here. I ordered the Kyoto iced coffee and a almond croissant and I was very impressed by both! The croissants are sourced from another local bakery, which I can't remember. Just like every hipster coffee joint around town, expect to spend a pretty penny here. My iced coffee and croissant set my friend back nearly $9.

For those who are in a big rush, they have a quick pay, honor system setup outside. $2.50 for a drip cup of Stumptown coffee.
author: Jenn C.

description: Good, fast wifi, and an interesting model (free and paid seating) with a good choice of food. I did come in shortly after opening time on Saturday and waited way too long for an iced latte. The food I later ordered was quite good for a cafe though!
author: Mark S.

description:
My oh my, how upgraded this modern gem has developed! It's been awhile since I visited Workshop Cafe. The last time I have been here is almost a year ago. I ordered a simple Americano, rather than the lattes I usually favor. It was one of the best ones I've had. 

My first time stumbling upon Stumptown coffee beans was during a NYC visit. It brought back so many delightful memories of roasted coffee aromas at the site in New York. The Americano delivered an exceptional punch and well-balanced taste (not too acidic and extremely smooth)! 

I am very happy for the spacious environment for studies, meetings and ample workspace. I even noticed a Bitcoin machine available for customers to buy/sell, which was different. Yay, additional points for the wifi and cool check-in process for seating!
author: Sally N.

description:
What a cool place to get some work done. Good coffee, friendly service. But what sets this place apart is the emphasis on a useful workspace.

For a small hourly fee, you get desk space, plenty of electric outlets, and most important: fast, consistent Wi-Fi. You can even order food and drinks from your table. Pretty cool.
author: Mike Y.

description: This place gives you 10 free hours of wifi and workspace. After that, only $2/hour. There are plugs everywhere and the environment isn't too loud so you can actually concentrate. But don't expect to be on any conference calls, the music is a little too lively. You can order food and drinks from your seat so you don't have to unglued your eyes from your monitor.
author: Bianca R.

description:
I had a day in San Francisco that I needed to be able to work remote, so I was on the hunt for the perfect work-share style of space. I got more than I ever could have asked for with Workshop Cafe. From the free 10 hours with the reserved seating, to the phenomenal and friendly service, to the on-point music, this place was better than I could've hoped for. For anyone that has a day or two that they need a location to remote work, this is definitely your spot - and it's close to a Bart station, which makes it accessible, too.  

Now if only I could take place back to D.C. with me!
author: Meagan E.

description: I went to here for a work meeting and thought that the concept was fantastic. The coffee was very good too and the lady that took my order was very friendly and nice. However, as I was standing waiting for our coffees I was almost taken out not once but twice but a 20 something year old girl. No excuse me's just you better get out of my way.
