Initially I thought is was just very important customer but when she came at me the second time with a huge scowl and yet again no excuse me I noticed that she was wearing the uniform shirt and stepped in behind the counter. I'm in the service industry too so I'm very aware of full hands so had she had something in her had a tray maybe I would have hopped out of her way faster but nothing. We all have bad days but she spoiled our experience. My teammate also experienced her angry face and the fact that despite standing as far out of the path of traffic as possible she obviously couldn't see us and/or just didn't care. Too bad for an otherwise cool place
author: Melissa L.

description:
I love that it is not noisy. Friendly people. Not lots of loud meetings/chats when I was there. 

Reliable wifi. 

Food is minimal but that's ok. At least they have some entrees. That's better than many cafés in which I try to work. 

I would come back again and also set up meetings here.
author: ari s.

description:
This place was super cool, and they had a bathroom when no one else lets you use it! i bought a coffee in exchange for the bathroom pass. $2 for a great cup of coffee and bathroom access? sweet!

its called workshop cafe for a reason, they have tons of outlets to power all of your electronics, they have personal service to where you can order food on their app or website and they bring it to you. You can also buy beer and wine! score! definitely a cool atmosphere and great customer service! check it out.
author: Jaime D.

description:
I am in love with this place!  It is SUPER conducive to studying/working, with lots of big tables, outlets up the wazoo, and even table service (you can order food and drink off their app and have it brought to your seat).  The space is quite large, and there's even a "meeting area" for a group of 5-6 to have a conference (complete with whiteboards and markers and everything).  People here are mostly on their own, so not a lot of chatting is going on.

It was great that they have food here, too, because most coffee shops just have the standard sweets and pastries, but nothing of real substance.  I got the iced honey almond latte, which was refreshing and not overly sweet.  The turkey apple sandwich was delicious, not terribly expensive (for SF anyway) and a hefty portion size (I ate half for lunch and half for dinner).  My friend got the pomegranate mocha, which was a little sugary, but also super tasty.

I only have 3 gripes about this place:
(1) The $2 per hour fee they charge to sit in the workspace kinda sucks.  If it's your first time, you get 10 hours free, so that's nice.  But otherwise, I don't think I would come back here after my 10 hours are used up.
(2) Street parking in the FiDi is a hot mess.  The first time I tried to come here, I circled for nearly 30 minutes before giving up and going home, because it was impossible to find parking.  Today, my friend and I got very lucky as someone was leaving their spot right as we turned the corner.  I would recommend taking public transit/walking here instead if you can.
(3) The bathroom was very poorly serviced.  There was NO toilet paper in any of the stalls, and the floor could have used a good cleaning.
author: Jess H.

description: Awful cafe. Got duped into using "3 hours free" at a regular table, all you have to do is a one click sign in. Total lie. Pain to sign in, requiring a laborious text message process, and I was there meeting a client, so ended up wasting both our time just to "sign in" to a cafe. But that's not all. We were interrupted after 20 min because apparently both people at one table have to "sign in" just to be at a cafe. Fine, we both sign in. Then we get accosted for not entering our credit card information. The employee actually told me to my face that she needs my credit card info to be entered into their website so they can verify I am a real person...excuse me? I'm literally sitting in front of you and you don't think I'm a real person? What a mindless sheep of an employee. You need my info so you can charge me for some nonsense without my knowing. We tell them we're almost done, then literally 5 minutes before we were going to leave, a different employee aggressively demands our credit card info again, and then kicks us out when I tell him I don't feel comfortable giving my credit card info out for no reason. Apparently the good old flesh and blood technique of proving you're real no longer applies to pretentious, intrusive SF cafes. Truly awful experience, and a disgusting example of the worst kind of unnecessary commercialization of every aspect of life, literally just trying to sit down, drink my coffee and talk.
author: Ilan G.

description:
Haven't been inside it.  I rarely go inside the coffee shops in FiDi to sit down, since I work nearby.  I do love the $2.50 coffee-on-the-go.  Honors system and self-service.

They have plenty of seating indoors, and from what I've seen and heard, lots of  outlets for computer/electronic device!  

As for their espresso drinks... I'll have to see.
author: Fannie S.

description: They were closed... We walked a mile for nothing... States they close at 10pm... Very unprofessional and an automatic fail!
author: Ismael P.

description:
This is a great place to work outside the office.   Good workspaces, wifi and food (delivered right to you if you just text the staff).   

Sometimes you get some loudmouth who wants to spend all their time phone, loudly, and I even saw someone conduct an interview there once (?!) but that's why man invented the headphone and for the most part people are just heads down and it helps in focusing yourself.  It's definitely nice to have a place that is work-centric and the fee is a small price to pay for not feeling like you're just an interloper hoarding space at a coffee shop.
author: Eric P.

description: I work from home or work remotely for most of the time and I love working at workshop cafe. Everything is so convenient and there are outlets everywhere which is just what I need. I tried going to other places and other coffee places and outlets are usually hard to find and wifi is slow, but not workshop cafe. The wifi is quick and the water is everywhere and it's just very convenient. You can even download the app and order from your phone and they will go to your table number and serve it to you. No need to get up and order or pull out your wallet because you can also put your card information into their app, which is very safe.
author: Janine C.

description:
It's incredibly hard to say no to Stumptown coffee and their almond croissants, but what makes it even harder to say no to is the fact that this is only place open past 8 pm in FiDi / SoMa that I can work at. Living in SoMa is great during the week and during the weekdays, but after 7 or 8 pm, it's a ghost town. On the weekends, some of the Starbucks only open until 4 pm, and other coffee shops (including other Starbucks) don't even open. Some cafes are open until 6, but remove all outlets so prevent people from trolling. Other cafes simply don't have enough seating.

Enter Workshop Cafe! Solves all these problems. Workshop Cafe is open until 10 pm, AND it is open on weekends!!The only downside is that after 10 hours of free internet, you have to pay. Aside from that, they provide all other services that can help you get work done without getting off your ass. You can reserve seats, which is great because sometimes I'll often trek to another side of the city to a cafe only to find that there are zero seats. You can also request service from your phone or computer without walking up to the cashier. I guess this is what makes up for the cost of doing work here.

I will say however that I am more productive at Workshop Cafe, knowing that I will soon be paying for my wireless usage. It's not expensive, and I have yet to hit the 10 hour limit, but... it is a great motivator!

Like others have mentioned, the coffee and food isn't the cheapest thing in the world, but they do allow you to bring in other food and drink (as if it ever stopped you before). But you don't even have to buy food because you're obviously paying them another way (through wireless).
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place is a preview of an awful dystopian future.  Ordered a salad and coffee and sat down at my registered "seat." which I had to reserve with my phone number.  Dumb but ok.  Then my phone starts buzzing asking me to confirm my identity by providing my name, address, and credit card number.  I'm not being charged to sit there so the info is being collected for no reason.  I decided to just ignore the messages.  Then the barista comes over and starts giving me reasons why I must provide my credit card number and address to sit in the cafe.  "Everyone is doing it!  It is required.". I just left instead.  That's some 1984 nonsense.
author: Todd G.

description:
I love the concept of a workspace that uses technology to let you pay by the hour.  But in practice the execution is poor.  The place is certainly more hip than Starbucks next door, but that seems like a silly thing to optimize for if you're an aspiring badass just trying to get stuff done.

--The internet is way too slow to pay 2 dollars an hour for it. 
--The wifi is an open network which is just an unacceptable level of security for pretty much any work of importance.  It's trivial for any n00b to run some security scripts out of the box and snoop your emails, passswords, credit cards, deployment keys, etc.  Given that so many important people might think of working here, if I were a malicious hacker this place would be a gold mine.  WPA or go home.
--Why play music so loudly in every section of the space?  Most people have their own headphones and would prefer their own selections.
author: Erem Z.

description:
I forgot the gentleman's name who was the barista that helped my fiance and I but he was great. He took great care of us. 

This is a great place to go to to catch up on work/study and focus on your work. Drinks are very good too. We'll be back!!
author: Joshua M.

description:
NOT ANOTHER TYPICAL COFFEE SHOP ON THE BLOCK!!
(3.75 stars)

Corporate Americans and future Corporate Americans... you get free 10hrs of workspace time!!! 

Need a professional and semi quiet place to do work/read/write? 
Need fast and free wifi?
Need to shut the world out and be in your zone? 

... Come here! Very interesting concept. 

Been trying to find a decent cafe quiet enough to hear my mind think, drink, eat, and get things done. Came in to check it out and study for my exam. Go to the site on your phone, check in with the site app, get 10hrs of free workspace time ($2/hr)... Good wifi and workspace don't come that cheap so take advantage, grab a clamp and place on your table/workspace, do your business, log out of website app, return clamp. 

I'm a cafe nerd (old college habits stuck with me) therefore I know a good cafe. You can bring your own food and drinks from outside, however they do sell pastries and beverages. Came in, studied for my exam for awhile, it was a good quiet where I can focus, got ALOT done!!! I have two weeks until my exam and will continue to come here for study reasons. 

Will I be back? Yes, for now. 

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: Super for breakfast! Try the Avo Eggs Scramble! Coffee is also pretty good. It changes to other big company!
author: Romain T.

description:
Only in San Francisco would you find a cafe with external displays, standing desks, and rows and rows of power strips. And it's AMAZING! (See what I did there? You thought I was indicting the tech elite, but I tricked you!)

Seriously though, this is the best place to get some work done. These people have managed to make the concept of an internet cafe hip again. (Or maybe it's not a true internet cafe, as you have to bring your own laptop--99% of the ones I see are Macs.) For those who've never been, it's simple: find an open seat in the spacious area in the back, plug in, sit down, and work. (And enter your seat number into their mobile-optimized web app.) There are a few standing desks in the back, a few rooms with whiteboards, and a lot of power strips.

Oh, and the Wi-Fi! It's free, and the speeds are decent. Based on my ultra-scientific testing, I believe each laptop is throttled to 5 Mbps down and 5 Mbps up. Not bad.

I also taste-tested their mocha, which was very sweet. Love it. Their yogurt parfait has raspberries, blueberries, and granola, and is similarly very sweet. I also appreciate their taste in music, which happens to intersect with mine (alternative/indie).

Of course, this atmosphere isn't free. After your first 10 hours, you'll need to pay at the rate of about $2/hour. It's well worth it.

Workshop Cafe. It's a library without the books. It's the future.
author: Daylen Y.

description: The workshop concept is great! The cafe has a lot of workspace and since it's paid, people tend to respect each other's work and not get too loud. Also, their cappuccino is the best in the city!
author: Kat S.

description:
I find it insightful that the negative ratings for Workshop Cafe on Yelp seem to be about "having to pay to sit", which is exactly why I rate Workshop Cafe so highly.  For a relatively affordable rate ($2-3/hr) they've figured out a way to create an efficient productive workspace inside a coffee shop.  The app lets you reserve tables in advance, order food to be delivered, and "go private".  I'm impressed they've figured out how to do this for a relatively affordable price (including food and drinks).  From now on I'm doing all my work and meetings here and will visit Starbucks when it's immaterial if I get a seat or not.

Related business idea: Spinoff and license the app to Starbucks and Peets!
author: Dave M.

description:
Lovely place to pick up coffee in the Financial District as many other places (other than Plentea) will close earlier in the evening.

Lots of options of teas and coffees, and although they only have one size for their drinks, the quality of the drink is much higher than other places - the strong herbal teas are a treat and no burned milk for the lattes.

The WiFi and workplace is then the biggest plus as you have a amazingly fast network to connect to and an in-store app that guarantees you never have to leave your seat. 

Two thumbs up!
author: Rotimi O.

description: I am very impressed with this place. I came here on a Sunday it was exactly what I needed. I was having a very hard time getting motivated and I was just flat out tired of library's. The mocha I ordered was perfect and the turkey apple sandwich was something I have never had before. I recommend this place if you are trying to get some serious work done. First 10 hrs in the workplace is free but its 2$ after that and I would think its worth it because every one around is on the groove of working and the environment is very work oriented. If you dont wanna pay that 2$ there is always Starbucks in the corner. I was very impressed.
author: Adnan K.

description:
There is nothing better than having an establishment make it right with a customer... and this does not mean getting free things but taking the time to understand and address concerns and customer service issues with customers.  The set up here at the workshop is great, the croissants are incredible! Shea and Jerry at the register are fantastic representations of what true customer service should be what more reason to keep coming back?  

Thanks Rich!
author: Angy G.

description:
Outlets, outlets, everywhere!

Great place to work for a few hours, you pay for your seat by the hour, so no need to feel guilty about taking up space at a busy cafe for the day.
author: Ro-el C.

description:
Great place to grab a coffee and sit down for a meeting or a space to stop in between work meetings in SF. Their back room offers the option to pay for a seat, recharge and not have to fight for a seat. $2 an hour per person which is great for me. 

Coffee not bad. I had an almond milk chai this time. Friendly staff who is chatty and will accommodate you. Great stop between meetings. Street or entry way to coffee shop is under construction right now so the entrance is hard to see. 

I like their outdoor patio out front. Great for people watching. The coffee shop is always full which is why I like the paid seating option.
author: Jessica M.

description:
What a good idea! When I was going to school coffee shops were my go to study spots. Now that I am working in Software, coffee shops again are my go to spots when working from home etc... This place really makes working from a coffee shop smart, easy and comfortable. I could easily work from Workshop all day without being uncomfortable, getting hungry or being bored. 

Being able to text your order is a really cool idea that I had not seen before and the app brings everything together smoothly. The vibe is also awesome. Everyone around you is working on the potential big new thing. I really am in love with this place and the idea. I would easily skip the office to work here for the day.
author: Mina M.

description:
01. Good wifi.
02. Enough power outlets to keep everyone happy.
03. A few different environments, open space and also private ones.
04. The food is good.
05. The music is good and not really loud.
06. If you like a spot you can reserve it (there's a whole "seat number" arrangement).
07. A few spots even have an additional monitor for you to use.
08. The first 10 hours are free.
09. Great location.
10. You can order food from their mobile website and not even leave your chair.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Great atmosphere. Tasty food. Great place to sit with your tablet or your cellphone. Also, there are special areas for working with your laptop. Also the place serves kombucha on a tap!
author: Stan B.

description:
For my needs, this is essentially like working at a Starbucks that charges you to use their wifi and seating. Where it exceeds Starbucks is in the # of outlets available so I can always be comfortable that my laptop won't die. Where it doesn't come close is in the food and beverage selection.

I've noticed people bring their bikes in which is cool, nice to feel secure that it won't get stolen outside. 

Staff is fine, usually it's a really laid back crew just interested in getting the job done from my experience. 

For someone rather introverted and liking a quieter atmosphere this place can overwhelm my senses a little bit but it's a great spot and I feed off the energy
author: Jesse Z.

description:
This is an interesting concept. This is a large space in the FiDi where folks can spent up to 10 hours working for free. They provide power and wifi. What's not to like?

The coffee shop was just OK IMHO. The hot chocolate was more like lukewarm chocolate. The choc chip cookie was good. But again, looks like you don't have to get anything from here to use the facilities. I even saw some folks there with Starbucks cups.  The thing I am really curious  about is how do they make money??
author: Sunil R.

description: I have been here a few times for coffee and I think their coffee is sour. Kyoto cold brew was pretty undrinkable. Will not be going back.
author: Ben G.

description: Love working in this convenient location and interesting workspace!
author: Louisa D.

description:
Venue: Spacious with free wifi and plenty of tables, seating, and outlets. However, the area is sectioned off into a zone where you pay $2/hour to study/work and a smaller and more limited free zone. 

Coffee & pastries were decent, nothing special.
author: Katrina L.

description: Being the third person in line I thought that this would be a quick cup of coffee as I had planned. I listened for 12 minutes as the lady behind the counter took this guys phone number email and a bunch of small talk before she got enough dirty looks to move on. I then ordered a latte and she started to tell me how it's made and compared it to Starbucks for 5 mins. I finally cut her off and asked for just a coffee just to shut her up. I then waited 7 minutes for a coffee as their were 4 other employees who waited around doing nothing, one was on a laptop. If you have three hours to kill and want mediocre coffee this place would be perfect for you. I wouldn't go back to this place if they offered me free coffee for a year.
author: Josh J.

description:
Well I'm not a big fan of $2/hr to sit down and consume the food I just bought from the business. 

My friend was staying at downtown hotel. I looked up coffee shops and this place looked great to sit down with a cup of coffee and talk. We met up and bought $20 worth of food/drinks, and found out that all the empty tables we saw were for people with reservations. Can you see that this can be very frustrating?? I don't like the concept at all and I will not be visiting this place in the future, but people must not mind it since the reviews are great and the business hasn't changed the policy. Good for them.
author: Jorge T.

description: This was an especially unique place because it has access to a lot of workspaces near outlets. You can get yummy snacks and coffee while working on work, school, etc. My only hesitation is that you have to pay if you'd like a workspace, but you do get the first 10 hours for free. I'd definitely go there again.
author: Kremi A.

description: Love this place for work. Great people, great atmosphere and delicious food !! However, sitting there everyday for a few hours as like my real work place is kind of expensive as you'd have to pay hourly.. Anyway, great spot you should definitely check out and please try the Breakfast Burrito :)
author: Jane W.

description: I've hunkered down at Workshop Cafe several times to work on projects and meet deadlines. The space is large and is consistent with the neo-industrial vibe taking over SF. In short, for $2/hr, you can select a workstation by a strip of outlets and get some quality, focused work done. Not an ideal space for those who work in silence, the cafe also gets flack for charging patrons to sit. I find that this pushes visitors to actually work rather than sip on lattes and chat. The app used inside is a little clunky (why a strange web app over a mobile app?) but it allows you to order food to your workstation (prices are reasonable for FiDi) and to communicate with others in the store. I dig these features. I have never had trouble getting a seat, and if the hourly rate puts you off, the very front of the cafe includes a small number of free seats.
author: Irina P.

description:
Workshop Cafe is like Harry Potter's Room of Requirements-- it's a fantastic multi-functional place to drink, eat, work, socialize, or whatever else you need space to do! 

Fully equipped with outlets, desk space, printers, scanners, and couches. Diverse healthy menu options, ranging from all-day brekkie, to dinner salads / sandwiches / soups. Drinks include good coffee, teas, house-brewed kombucha, and the alcoholic variety. Music and ambiance is nice, and not too loud.

A final bonus is they open late (10pm), and have the friendly staff!
author: Cathy X.

description: Love it here!  I always come here when I have things to din the city.  The playlist is fantastic, the coffee is great, and the work environment is exactly what I need.  You also get your first 10 hours of service free, so definitely come and give it a try.
author: Michael N.

description: Overpriced coffee and food but the workspace is great. There are a variety of different seating situations and sizes (bench, table, cozy chair, etc). The wifi is strong. If you plan to come and get some work done then the expensiveness (even by SF standards) is worth it. I forget which brand of coffee they brew but it was good. You can also order from your table which is nice so you don't have to leave your laptop unattended.
author: Mariam A.

description:
Cute coffee shop in fidi with everything you might need- delicious coffee, health salads/snacks, wine/beer, soups, plush couches, tons of outlets, and a perfect work environment!

 I love the concept of paying $2/hour to get a nice reserved desk with outlets and with your drinks being brought to your table. It's different and the model allows for you to work without hovering over other people to get a table. You can come here convinced you'll have a place to work, which is great because I've been turned away from so many Starbucks when all the tables are being used. The paid area looks a lot more comfortable as well and ambiance is great for getting some work done in. 

I tried the honey almond milk latte which i really enjoyed but wish it was less sweet. I asked for it to be less sweet, so I can't imagine how sweet this drink is regularly. Regardless, delicious flavors and a perfect place to catch up with an old friend (shoutout to my eating partner-in-crime Cathy X.) or to plug in your headphones to get some serious work done.
author: Anu P.

description: Workshop Cafe is a good place to hang out for a few hour and get work done. As the name suggests, everyone here comes to this shop to work first and the "cafe" part seems secondary. They do have good options for coffee and food. It can get a bit crowded during peak hours. They charge $2 - $3/hour for using their formal work space area, however they have a free front lounge section with high tables and bar stools. The bar stools can get somewhat uncomfortable after seating for a longer period of time. The paid section though has more comfortable chairs and power sockets for charging your electronic devices. As a first time user, you get the first 10 hours for free in the formal work space area. Overall, the shop is ideal to check-in and get some solid few hours of work done.
author: Ninad S.

description:
I love workshop cafe!!!!!!! People there so nice. I always run into people.

It can be crowded sometimes, but I'm only one person usually so it's easy to squeeze in between tables
author: Gina H.

description:
"Eek! Methinks not" is right.

Upon first glance, Workshop Cafe appears a most ideal spot to read, write, work. The ambiance is relaxed, with great music and good looking, friendly employees. And for the overwhelming amount of good reviews posted here, clearly the joint has its own mini-following for the above reasons. That being said, waiting 20 minutes - with no line - for a latte is beyond ridiculous. The first time I walked in, and left after a 30 minute waiting time for my drink, I was disappointed but assumed that the cafe was understaffed on the weekends (it being open in the financial distract Saturday & Sunday). The second time I stopped by, there were 4 employees on deck and no one in line in front or behind myself, and it still took 20+ minutes for my single latte to be made.

If you're in for going along with the slow ride, do step by the Workshop Cafe. But don't say I didn't tell you so when you're rolling your eyes, checking your watch 10 minutes in.
author: Lady F.

description:
Excellent new addition to the city. Smartly designed, smartly utilized. If you like human beings, there's a real barista, concierge, coffee, and patios to socialize. If you like computers, you can check yourself in via apps, RSVP, order drinks and food. 

Bright, modern, fast WIFI, it's a great place to get things done and get creative. 

Possibly everything I wanted in a productive cafe work experience.
author: Dilys S.

description: The Workshop Cafe offers a large space with ergonomic seating, super fast wifi, and amazing coffee! An excellent place to have a caffeinated beverage and focus on your work with minimum distractions.
author: Savera T.

description:
Try the honey almond latte! I was excited about Workshop because they feature my beloved Stumptown coffee + Califia almond milk.

Stumptown is an awesome Portland brand of coffee that does delicious cold brew, and Califia is like the Cartier of almond milks. Don't bother with that Silk crap, it'll separate in your coffee. Califia is like drinking full fat latte but better because it's healthy!

Workshop is located in FiDi and meant to be a work space for those tech and finance laptop people. You do pay $2/hour and the coffees are fairly expensive, so there's a high premium for that, but the atmosphere is really buzzy and collaborative, which I think is a nice bonus for a working environment.

There's a lot of food options and breakfast pastries so you won't go hungry.
author: Kate M.

description:
Wow talk about techie. And yet so awesome. 

Not gonna lie, when I first walked into this establishment I thought 'what's with all these stuffy fools?' and like, 'why do I have to check-in to sit down?' but I quickly changed my tune when I realized how efficient and friendly the service is, how quick the wifi, and how convenient the surroundings. I'm on the grind to find a job right now and being surrounded by people DOING WERK is pretty motivating. Not to mention, the food is decent tasting and more importantly, reasonably priced. When you plop your bottom down for a marathon session of computer work, these things are important. There are plenty of independent work stations but also group tables for collaborative efforts and two closed off rooms for telephone conversations.

Once you check in on your phone you can order food and have it delivered to your seat. The restrooms are well-maintained, there's freely accessible water, and you can sit around for up to 10 hours staring at your computer for free! If that's not a San Franciscan work slave's dream cafe then I don't know what you're doing in the Financial District. My tongue is in my cheek, but hey, I got a lot of work done today.
author: Alice L.

description: Really cute cafe and talented baristas! We ordered the pomegranate mocha which was well made but a little sweet! Good quality espresso and chocolate. Lots of people working but plenty of space.
author: Kate L.

description:
This was my first time using a place specifically designed for co-working. For the purpose of getting work on your laptop done, it sure beats your usual cafe, in that it's nice and quiet (but not too quiet) and there's tons of accessible outlets and table space. In terms of the clientele scene, it's probably one of the most hipster-y cafes in the Financial District north of Market; in fact, I had to gush to Facebook about how I saw the most hipster facial hair combination I'd EVER seen (in San Francisco or anywhere else) on a fellow patron here. It felt like there were a few students here, but mostly graphic designers, freelance creatives, "techies" (j/k, I hate that word) and bro-y non-technical founder-types.

I tried to order the Kyoto iced coffee I've heard so much about, but they were out. I got a regular pour-over, which took the requisite like, four minutes to make. It was pretty good, but I wouldn't recommend coming here just to get a coffee to go.

The coolest thing about this place is that you can reserve a spot even before you get there. Go to their website online and choose a spot, then check in there when you arrive. They'll put an orange clamp thingy on your desk indicating that it's reserved.

My only minor complaint is that people working here kind of seem to think this is their own personal UX testing ground. Ten minutes after I sat down to do some work, I saw one girl near me get approached to do some usability testing of someone's app, and then ten minutes later, I got approached by another pair of testers! I think it's cool to encourage an air of collaboration, but they need to make sure that it doesn't tilt too far into an interruption-fest such that you can't really get work done here.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
I practically live here! Hahaha. You guys are amazing. I do my fashion homework here almost every weekend. 

+ great atmosphere
+ yummy popcorn 
+ stump town coffee
+ outlets and wifi galore

The perfect workspace! 

I wish you guys took tips. You deserve it.
author: Laura L.

description: This is a fine workplace, with great music, coffee, space and WiFi to fulfill every worker's needs. Unfortunately, I visited for the first time a couple weeks ago and the employees came off a bit cold and unfriendly. I will probably visit again though, because the concept is thoughtful and the location is super accessible. :)
author: Kelly K.

description: Co-working space, offers coffee & wifi. Used it as a central meeting place for appointments.
author: Wolfgang G.

description:
Everything about this place is fantastic.  My experience in the short time this place has been open makes me hope that they take over SF.  I love going to coffee shops to be productive, and this place caters to that perfectly.  The hourly fee is a bit of a tough sell, but the quality of your experience totally justifies it.

I feel welcome here no matter how long I wish to work.  The staff is extremely friendly, and you can tell that they're going the extra mile to make this innovative place successful.  I also cannot wait to see what this place is like in a few months as some parts of the app etc. hint at very exciting things to come.

Oh yeah, and the coffee is great too!
author: Kevin F.

description:
This place is great if you don't mind paying an extra buck or so for a cool atmosphere. 

It's trendy, yes, but the coffee is good and the service isn't as surly as some other places around here.

They have a very honor system looking set up for grab n go coffee out front, a few stools aren't even bolted to the ground yet! 

That won't last. Sorry, I'm a pessimistic native who knows anything not chained down in the city disappears. 

(I'll be back when I want to have a faux power meeting with my co-workers like everyone else here seems to...)

TL;DR its cool, better coffee than at Coffee&Cultures around the corner. Pricey for us lowly admin folk.
author: Adora S.

description:
Revision: Workshop has gotten too big for its britches.  They used to be great, and I loved working there.  Now it's difficult to get to know the employees, and to get any response via e-mail.  They're streamlining, and it shows.

I've since moved out of the area, and wanted to create a home office with the same tall bench seating that they have along the wall.  I couldn't get a response from them to save my life.  They literally told me, when I called a second time, that "this is really not a priority right now, but I'll try to get you a rough estimate by next week."  To which I replied that I already emailed them over a month ago.  I don't expect any response.  

What a shame.  They have a good business model, and a nice space, but they're losing the kindness and helpfulness they once had, as a slightly smaller business.
author: Valerie T.

description: I'm here waaaaaaaay too often. Imho, it's the best cafe to work in the city. They are open 7 days/week!!! They also have a great menu. I just had to knock off one star because of cleanliness. The space is very clean and spacious (they just renovated their space and added many more conference rooms), but their dishes and silverwares are not very clean. I often find remainders of food and/or mysterious spots on them... Other than that, it's my favorite place to work in SF and the staff here are very friendly.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Workshop Cafe has a different way of attracting customers in comparison to other coffee shops that I have been to. The concept is to pay $2 an hour for a quiet spot in the cafe. People that come here seem very productive which leads to a very quiet environment. There are plenty of outlets, tables, a restroom, and free wifi. 

If you prefer not to pay for a spot, there are a couple of tables outside with outlets to study or and if you are lucky there are also a couple of spots in the front when you first walk inside. 

I ordered the Honey Almond Latte, it is a bit pricey but it is a must try for those that want a caffeine with a hint of sweetness.
author: Tiffany J.

description: I need a quiet place to study with a little more to offer than the library and that is what this cafe does for me. I certainly don't mind paying $2/hr to avoid the annoyances of coffee shops. It's also nice to be able to text an order and have it delivered to your seat. The staff is always very friendly. Whenever I've needed service, it's been great.  Also, I'm not a coffee connoisseur but their pour-over is really very good.
author: Joe S.

description:
I've been coming here pretty much every Sunday afternoon since it opened and today I think I'm going to consider going elsewhere. I walked in today like I normally do to look for a space, then check in online. Instead I got stopped by the woman behind the counter, and ordered to check in on my phone in front of her. 

Seems like a little thing, but it screws up the whole atmosphere. It feels less like an open work-collaboration space and starts to feel like a library. 

Moreover, it sends the message "we don't trust you" loud and clear, and obviates the necessity for a web-app in the first place, which is supposed to make things like this more convenient, and is doubly stupid because she should be able to see who is and is not checked in based on who is sitting where. But why trust the brown guy, right? 


If you don't know what I'm talking about: there is a mobile app, you check in on the mobile app, you reserve space. outlets, wifi, space. no one hassles you. $2 an hour. 

But let me actually take back that no one bothers you part. It's f--ked up to walk into a place you walk into every week, start to feel like a regular, then get treated like you're sneaking in. I'm over this place.
author: Neal P.

description: Im not a fan of uptight coffee bars with employees that are snobby as hell. Im sorry i dont look like a hipster or have a laptop in my hand but i am gonna use your wifi. I thought this place was quaint and convenient for its locale. Lots of chairs and space to work at and best of all wifi thats pretty fast. As far as the coffee goes....mediocre...its probably some organic made coffee that they claim is the best. Isnt everyones coffee the best when it comes to cafes? Come for wifi and ambiance not for coffee
author: Jeff C.

description: Awesome space for out of towners who need a spot to recharge (with good coffee and many outlets). It was never so crowded that I couldn't find a spot, and the service was very friendly. Love the quick station for coffees, skip that line!
author: Charlie W.

description:
Overall I had a productive 2.5 hours here. And the egg/bean/cheese tacos are amazing! Get the avocado addition. But:

1. Crumbs on the empty table that I used
2. The internet was 3Mbps down, and despite my bringing it to the attention of 2 employees, it remained that way throughout my stay.

I probably won't be coming back.
author: Darrell C.

description:
Best place for work in San Francisco, period.

Extraordinary concept: you can work on your own laptop with super high speed wifi, you can use the workstations, do real life meetings or conferences with your coworkers, or you can actually have your own room where you can lock the world out and focus.

The place is clean, location is good, café is cool and the staff is super nice!

I can't say that this place is laptop friendly - this place is made for people with laptops! :) Plugs everywhere.
author: Patyo E.

description: The best working space in San Francisco, unless you're a member of The Battery ;) I don't like the clunkiness of their check-in system but it's getting better. Check-In through their web app, get your hours, find a seat, and start working. The food selection is tasty and applicable for different palates. Good selection of beers for those late night sessions as well. Overall, a great experience.
author: Ajay G.

description:
I was a bit disappointed. I had been looking forward to this place for a couple months. I finally had some paperwork to get through so I thought I would run down on a Saturday, get a bite to eat, and work here. 

The good choices were rather minimal. I opted for the stir fry which was solid but kind of costly for what you got. 

The part that really kills me is having to pay by the hour to sit down. 80% of their seating is behind a velvet rope that requires payment. There are other seating options but it feels like a separation of classes. Trust me, it's not about the $2 per hour, it's about the atmosphere that this creates. 

After eating my stir fry, I ran down to Starbucks where I felt more at home.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Greatest idea for cafe. You pay an hourly rate for a co-op space that is a cafe. You can eat their food or not. First 10 hours free.


Good for:
Freelancers needing a place to work or collaborate. They have whiteboards, wifi, great big tables etc. Feels good.


Bad for: 
Dates, talks with mom, divorces.


Improvement areas:

* The check in/out app is frustrating. Please build app so I can manage my account. Geo fence the entrance, I get a pop-up that asks me to log in to wifi or not.

* Pricing. While 2 bucks an hour is nice, 2 bucks an hour plus 13 dollar small plate of food is expensive for people on a budget. If people eat or drink, they should be granted two hours free. Give a card with a free credit to purchases of $5 or $10 dollars and over?


Great job so far. Great concept!
author: Mr. N.

description:
I like the layout and concept of this place, and being in there makes me feel like I want to get work done. You can reserve work spaces by phone, and they have plenty of outlets, and wifi is $2/hour.  

The space is open and modern with some music in the background, but it's very conducive to getting stuff done.

I had a chai latte that was pretty good. Service was nice. One of my biggest annoyances is the square payment systems on iPads that ask you for a tip of $1-3 or whatever after you pay; even though they use this system, they have a no tip policy, which is pretty rare.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
This place is smarter than I am. Seriously! I don't think anyone (other than me) has ever even seen a fax machine. But once you begin to get to understand the "how toos" and "this is how" you too can look like a tech smart hard working Silicon Valley Stanford graduate and begin hanging out in one of the coolest places in town.

Firstly, the steamed milk with honey might be better than hot chocolate I've ever tasted. Yes, I went there...and back.

Secondly, their hot chocolate is the second best drink item on the menu. See Firstly.

Thirdly, Food. Great, better than most other coffee places.

Fourthly, work space with lots and lots of plugs.

Fifthly, they have a system, you can actually get up and not lose your seat.

Seventhly, I really do love this place.
author: V B.

description:
This is an excellent place to study and get work done. Although a little confusing at first, it is easy to understand how the place operates now that I have gone a few times.
FOOD: The cafe drinks are outstanding. I recommend the Iced Honey Almond Latte, or a Hot Chocolate. Their pasteries are great too- especially the Almond croissants. However, their other menu food isn't the best. I got a Chicken Veggie stir fry- and it was really bad (hence the 4 stars). Veggies were not fully cooked, and still cold. Sauce was too sweet, and the rice was very dry, not worth the 12 dollars. However, I just stick to the pastries and those drinks. 
WORKSPACE: The ambiance for this place is seriously awesome. Everyone around you seems focused, and it encourages you to be focused too! I always get a lot of work done when I go. The music they play in the cafe is also really good. Customer service is really nice too, everyone that works there is willing to help you and give you great service. What's cool too is that you get the first 10 hours free, if you work in the workspace and sign in with your application. Remember that the workspace is different from the patio/lounge. The patio is nice, but usually it's cold in the city, so its not ideal to get work done. Lounge is eh.. It's good for socializing, but not the best to get work done. No comfortable chairs or nice desk space. So, if you want to get work done, it's best if you go into the workspace. There's plenty of outlets, and free, fast wifi. 
However, I am a college student with a limited budget. So it can be pricy sometimes to have to pay for sitting in a workspace. I will only come in times of finals or midterms. However, its really worth it! I would recommend it.
author: Kiki C.

description:
Best place to work/enjoy in San Francisco!!

Pros:
- Super fast internet. SF coffee shops have the worst internet connections and there's absolutely no seating areas. This place has over 150 seats. 
- 4 Mbps upload speeds - yep, fastest I've experienced in this city
- You can always find a spot, even during business hours. 
- First 10 hours are free, yes, you can try out the place for 10 hours. 
- Food is super good and reasonably priced. Bought sandwich for 9 bucks. Best sandwich I've had in a coffee shop. 
- Entrepreneur atmosphere and everyone is working hard
- People respect neighbors and are quiet

Cons:
- None. Top spot in SF.
author: Alejandro S.

description:
I've been coming here every weekday morning for the past 3 months now and I love it. I will admit they can be a little slow sometimes at producing your order, but they are all so nice and the coffee is great that it's one of the very few places that I let it slide.

The prices are reasonable and honestly, compared to everywhere else in the area, they are the best (for coffee anyway - I don't get food so I can't compare that).

It's always really clean in there and there never seems to be an overly long line to wait it in either.

I totally recommend it!!
author: Elle B.

description: Convenient place to wait, work, study and have coffee or a bite. Sat outside in comfortable upholstered chair with footstools. Loved coffee. Popcorn was "meh" but service was friendly. The cheese & fruit plate is my next nosh while studying there.
author: Robin C.

description:
I can see why this concept works for some people who can't afford office space but need a place to sit and work. For the rest of us, who come into Workshop Café for coffee or lunch, it's not welcoming. Unless you to "pay to sit," you're confined to a tiny section with narrow tables and uncomfortable chairs.

I ordered a salad, was told my name would be called when it was ready. Sat in the tiny corral with the other bad children and kept waiting for... nothing. Finally, after 10 or 15 minutes I walked up to the prep area where three people were doing god knows what. I asked about the salad. They hadn't started it. One dude says, "Can anyone make this salad?" They'd just ignored the ticket.

I asked for my money back and the cashier was very apologetic. But hey... why should the customer have to remind the staff to do their job?
author: Marvin G.

description:
I come here all the time and love it! I hate coffee but love coffeeshops! and this place is fantastic to get work done. I wish they had more hours. Great for the person who doesn't want to pay for a co-working space.

Downsides- music is overly repetitive (I've heard the same music over and over). It's gotten better since I emailed them. Should have more locations and longer hours on weekends!
author: Sam F.

description:
Free wi-fi and and Stumptown Coffee is quite convenient in this part of town. If you have not tried Stumptown, be prepared to be mesmerized. It is the best coffee chain in the U.S. (better than Philz, Blue Bottle, Four Barrel etc.) There are a couple seats inside that are free but usually are taken up all the time; there are also stools and seats outside but it can get pretty windy and loud for those looking for some quiet.

Most people who give this anything lower than 4 stars are usually the types that 1) think this is a lounge like Starbucks or 2) hates coffee that is better than Blue Bottle or 3) works for another coffee shop.
author: E E.

description:
What is the point of having a designated workspace, with discreet ordering, if the barista just yells loudly for everyone's order (and over and over again until they come up).

They track where people sit, they allow people to text their orders. I think they should bring food to tables. Maybe that would make it officially a restaurant or something, but honestly this system just isn't functional. It's distracting. I've noticed other people looking up every time he yells. It's every 2-3 minutes. 

Poor kid, he is just doing his job. 

Reliable wifi is the only plus. I wouldn't pay for this (first 10 hours are free, then you pay 2 dollars an hour to use the workspace).
author: Martina R.

description: Great for working, good for coffee, not recommended for food ("soup" is a weakly-microwaved stew with a pile of cheese on top).
author: Daniel G.

description: They offer something you don't find elsewhere (such as a coffee shop) -- which is that they encourage and accommodate people who need to work, plug-in, meet people and talk, and even bring in a group. The food and drinks are fine, but that's not what you come here for. It's not as noisy as you expect since people seem to be focused on doing work. For first timers, the sign-in system is confusing, but you get used to it, plus the staff are helpful.
author: Dan C.

description: One of the most welcoming Internet cafes I've ever visited. Good prices on their menu items with great device to follow. The first 10 hours of internet usage are free. Perfect place to go if you're a freelancer looking to get some work done or work remotely.
author: Alan H.

description: Interesting concept and definitely a different type of workspace. This is certainly not a coffeehouse or cafe. Starbucks has more on an atmosphere than this place which already places the bar pretty low. But I would still score the place well for being different. However, the score I'm providing is based on the attitude of the worker I encountered. She was astoundingly disinterested and bordering on rude. Having worked at a coffeehouse years ago I can understand how the work can be trying at times...but I still I was surprised.
author: Marina O.

description:
Sometimes, when you want to go to a cafe and hang out, the laptop crew is annoying and makes it hard to tell whether you're in a social space or an office.

But sometimes, you need to get work done at a cafe and don't want to feel like a total geek or social outcast.Sometimes you're out and about and need to spend some quality time with your laptop between things. Sometimes you don't want to work from home by yourself. And we all hate that experience of being in a public place with no outlets, running your battery down to zero despite putting the screen brightness all the way down and struggling to work. 

Workshop is the perfect solution. They have rows of desks complete with tons of power strips. They also have some couch areas good for meetings. You don't have to feel bad about taking a phone call. You get the first hours free. You can even order food and drinks from your computer. The food is good, and I hear the coffee is, too. 

Gluten-free notes: The breakfast tacos are gluten-free and very tasty.
author: Ellie P.

description:
A very modern and smart take on a study café.

You check in with your app and then you check in your seat number. If you ordered something, it will get brought to you free of charge (meaning you do not necessary need to leave a tip). I haven't had their bites, but I am all for a café that serves friggin beer. Sometimes you just need some alcohol in replacement of caffeine. Who am I kidding... I'll take both! 

I love the seating. There are couches and there are throw, but don't get too comfy. This is not a starbucks your local bum can crash. A lot of people come after work to get more work done (or who knows... I've seen facebook-ing). They open early and close late. If you need to get a little more work done, this is great spot. Extremely close to BART and close to Fidi.
author: Phuong V.

description:
This is my go to place for coffee during work days. This place has a very clean and well designed ambiance. This is perfect for when you want well crafted coffee and the working space is accessible for when you need a place to do work without all the crowds and noise. First 10 hours are free then $2/hr after. 

They staff is very friendly when taking your order. My favorite drinks are the iced mocha, good balance of chocolate and coffee, and the ice honey almond latte, not too nutty. 

Prices range from $4-5 for a coffee which is normal for a place in soma.
author: Polly W.

description: Great idea, coffee, and staff. Not the most hipster spot (go to Sightglass for that) and the food presentation can be a bit more polished, but a nice spot to get some work done without paying the higher price for coworking space.
author: Steve G.

description: This place is bomb.com! The atmosphere is great if you want to get shit done! The food and drinks are amazing too! A little pricey but worth it! I can't wait to come back here, grab a bite and do some studying again :)
author: Catherine V.

description:
This place is so SF. Check in with your phone, pay $2/hour for a seat in a big warehouse space with mixed-type seating that could pass for any open-format tech office, minus foosball table. Order Stumptown coffee, food or beer/wine at the counter or summon it on your phone. The coffee's good, the idea is great, it meets a need and I like what the folks here have done.

However, I spent an entire afternoon here and I didn't get a bit of work done (I'm a writer). Obviously this is my subjective experience, but there were way too many distractions listening to the various startup people hatching ideas and a pair of particularly obnoxious neighbors discuss for half an hour how to find their true essence and achieve self-actualization through work (really). For a finicky, distractible hyper-procrastinator, I have a really good record of getting work done in coffeeshops, but not this one.
author: Cecilia L.

description: Great service. Clean environment. Free white boards! It's going to cost you $2 per hour to have deskspace if you sit inside. Outside it's free: great wifi either way! First 10 hours are free - SO worth trying out. Get the breakfast tacos. They're word.
author: Matt C.

description: Great atmosphere and workspace! The concept is genius and the staff + service is great!  I love how comfortable and convenient they've made it. Definitely my new study spot in SF :)
author: Shabnam S.

description:
I walk by this place all the time, and I finally got a chance to drop by.

Everything about this place is pretty awesome: plenty of outlets, good amount of seating, decent tea, nice decor, and good music.

You pay $2/hr to sit in the paid area (80% of space), which gives you access to power ports and wifi. First 10 hours are free. Otherwise, you can sit in the free area outside or inside next to the door.

It's a great place to study and get some work done, so I'm sure I'll be dropping by much more often in the future. You can bring in food from outside, and they also have a concierge to help order food or give you a power cable if you forgot yours.
author: David L.

description:
Pros: I love the coffee at this place! Plus the wifi is super fast and you can book a table or one of the two small private rooms in case you want to have a team meeting - must be pretty great as well if you have a startup but no office space!

Cons: After the first 10 hours, you have to pay 2$/h! But this place is always full so I guess it's a great business model!
author: Mariana F.

description: Good space and nice staff, but the last hour of my time was spent freezing because they kept the door open with 50 degrees F outside. I asked to close; they did, only to re-open 10 minutes later. They were closing and it seemed like they were trying to chase people out by keeping the space FREEZING.
author: Kate S.

description:
This is a top study spot for me, and I am yelping this review live and on location ;]!

These are my criteria for study / work spots: 

(1) Atmosphere? What I love the most about Workshop Cafe is the fact that the cafe is specifically set up for people who want to get some work done. People are respectful and aren't just here to socialize. On the other hand, it isn't maddeningly quiet like a library is. Everyone's on their laptops and it's a modern, minimalist space. The fluorescent lights are a bit harsh, but hey, at least it's well lit. They also have white boards in small, enclosed rooms (might be a good place to duck in and make a phone call if needed), as well as benches and chairs for small group meetings. They also offer printing and scanning (for a small fee). 

(2) Wifi? Workshop Cafe boasts having super fast Internet and provides the first 10 hours of wifi on the house. After that, it's $2 per hour. They track how many hours you use using a check-in system. You notify them, by checking in on their website or mobile app using your seat number, that you are working online and they put a little doodad on your table to show that you've checked in. 

(3) Caffeine? Their drinks are around $4-$5. Expensive, sure, but I'll pay a bit more for the knowledge that I'm actually going to be motivated to work while I'm here. I love their ginger lemongrass tea. Slighty sweet and spicy - yum! Ooh and you can order drinks from your seat through their site / mobile app and they will bring them to your seat for you to power up while you power through :].

(4) Lots of seats and outlets? I have yet to have trouble finding a seat on the weekends. It's a pretty large space with a good amount of seating and PLENTY of outlets. 

(5) Food? They serve little pastries and a toubouli salad, but they don't have sandwiches and that sort of thing. However, they do let you bring food into the cafe to munch on, which is a great policy. Working Girl Cafe is a block away (highly recommend the huge and delicious Chipotle chicken salad) and Sushirrito is also nearby (which I have yet to try, but have heard great things).
author: Eileen E.

description:
Only three external monitors available, and (of course) all three taken. This was my foremost reason for coming--I can work from my laptop monitor at home or at practically any other café. 

Concierge wouldn't look up from her tablet to answer questions. Baristas were very welcoming and willing to answer questions, but busy with drinks (naturally). 

"I thought we had five monitors..." said one. Guess not!
author: Jade P.

description: I like this place but since I didn't check in to use their formal workspaces it was hard to find a reliable power source in the common areas. I was able to plug in outside in the patio but then it was really noisy due to oncoming traffic. Good food and coffee though
author: Beatriz G.

description:
Let's start with the important stuff: coffee. It's very, very good, and they have exactly the right number of options (individual drip, regular drip, espresso). So this is enough to call it a Win.

As a lounge-y cafe kind of place, it's not ideal if that's what you are looking for - but that's okay.  There are 6 indoor seats and about 8 more outside - just enough to catch up with a friend, not enough to turn it into mooch central.

Then there's the "workshop" part, where dozens of individual seats, benches, desks, tables, and call zones make for an awesome spot to check in for a few hours and get some work done. Ideal for the individual contributor / consultant who needs to park themselves downtown for a few hours and get stuff done.

Last comment: super-friendly staff. Really impressive.
author: Jeremy T.

description: I would give this place FULL stars if it wasn't so expensive to work there.  It's a great work atmosphere, though, and that's why people pay to work there.  I presented my thesis in one of the conference rooms and have gone there when I absolutely need to get to the grind.  Coffee and tea are ok and so are the food options.  When you have to get sh** done, this is a great place to go.
author: Katherine K.

description: love this place! friendly staff, great wifi speeds. the only downside is the $2/hr situation. ballsy on their part, but I see where they are coming from. Keep in mind though the front section and outdoor area is free, so there is always that. No outlets in the front though.
author: Patricia K.

description:
I was looking for a space to have a quiet meeting, and stumbled upon Workshop Cafe. Approaching the entrance of the space, I saw a lot of folks seated throughout their outdoor seating engaged in lots of crucial conversations. The energy was interesting. 

Walking inside, their process is pretty easy and the team was very helpful. I was greeted by a nice cashier who explained the process of utilizing their paid space and the amenities included. I was fascinated by the amount of people inside Workshop Cafe, seemingly committed to their work. It was the energy I was looking for. They took my credit card and gave me table with two chairs ($2 per hr) near the front of the paid space. The baristas were quick and also pleasant. I ordered a soy latte ($4) and was pleased to learn they use Stumptown coffee. 

When my 5pm meeting arrived, I did not feel pressured to have to speak at a certain volume because of all the hard working guests around me. We were able to have a substantial meeting at a volume that worked for us. Plus, everyone was on headphones anyway. After my meeting, I returned to the cashier who closed out my "tab" of 1 hour of work time and my latte. 

Overall I had a great experience and appreciate the productive energy and culture inside of Workshop Cafe. I'll definitely return to get some work done myself, or to have another meeting with a client!
author: Ben C.

description:
It's a cool cafe to go to to get work done, but I just feel that they constantly mess up orders and their service is not consistent. Several times in the past they don't bring out orders if you email it in. Their app isn't that great, I was bothered about three to four times about checking in today when I already was checked in. 

The space and premise is overall good, but I just think the whole system needs auditing to flush it out and to steer it clear to its proper vision. 

Also, all of the meals are quite pricey.
author: Patty C.

description:
This is THE BEST place to get work done.  Where do I even start... You get 10 hours of free wifi usage before having to pay $2/hour, which is more than reasonable. and the wifi is super fast. 

SPACE: Tons of seating with gazillion power outlets- individual and group tables, even a couple tiny glass rooms with whiteboard walls for people to make private calls or have private meetings. High ceilings make it feel even more spacious. They place soft music so you can actually concentrate and work.  

FOOD:  They have coffee/tea, pastries, and sandwiches. They also have beer and wine! But, you don't need to purchase anything to sit and use their wifi. In fact, you can bring outside food in.  I've tried their chai latte (it's spicy) and chicken sandwich, which was plated beautifully but in my opinion on the dry/bland side.

SERVICE: "check in" to the seat via their app. You can send your order in by text or email.  You can even reserve your seat prior to arriving using their app.They also offer concierge service, like picking up take out from another restaurant.  They also offer printing services.  AND, if you forgot a cable or charger, you may borrow one from them.  

Bathroom is nice and clean.  They even have wall bike racks.
author: Jenn L.

description:
The good: blueberry Danish. 

The bad: I've been to this place a few times and I've never been upset with service nor wowed by it. Until today, I was waiting behind a customer to place my order. When it was my turn, I said hi to the waitress. She gives me a distracted hi and then promptly turns around to someone at the coffee, food bar and says she's going to clean up some tables. Doesn't say that someone will  be with me-- just up and leaves the cash wrap. There needs to be some sort of customer service training at this place.
author: Agnes R.

description: I went here to do a Skype interview SUPER early and luckily this place worked out perfectly. The internet worked fine, the salmon bagel I got was great, and there was a couple of water stations. I liked the atmosphere the most, so this is a great place to be productive.
author: Gloria A.

description:
A place in sf that serves Stumptown coffee and microbrews! That's a win in my book. 

Its a huge place and there's a large lounge/study area you can access (for a price but I hear you can get the first 10 hrs free) it was pretty quiet and everyone was working away on a Thursday afternoon. I even saw that they have a concierge desk with computers and printers you can access which can definitely come in handy sometime. 

Friendly staff and quick service. I'll definitely be back for the coffee and probably even try out the studying arrangement sometime.
author: michelle l.

description:
I saw this place while walking to North Beach one day and had to check it out. I thought it would be a typical cafe that serves drinks and provides wifi. However, it's more of a socially connected workspace that uses modern technology with a trendy coffee shop vibe. There are plugs everywhere and lighting is great--basically very ideal cafe for laptop work/studying.

Anywhere you sit, there will be a laminated piece of paper that explains how the cafe works. If you're in "the workspace" area you have to check in to your exact spot on your phone/computer. What? Check into a table? Yes, if you're sitting in seat #30, you have to check into it. After you do, they will put an orange vice thing on your table to signify that you've checked in. Apparently, if you do this, you can then get service to your personal space by using an iPhone app or a browser version if you don't want to use your phone. In other words, if you want a coffee or a cookie without getting up, just tap what you want on the app, you'll be served it, and your card will automatically be charged. Too bad they can't pee for you too. Something I thought was even more interesting was that you can check into a specific spot at the cafe if you're not even there--just log onto your app from elsewhere then reserve it so when you get there you have a space. For this service, they charge $2/hour but the first ten hours are free. I think that's a fair price because the place is well-lit, you can get personal service to your table, and there are like a million plugs everywhere.

I liked the Kyoto coffee system (I had to order something made from it) that had and the baristas were all nice.

This is like the best cafe to get work done in SF. The hours are good (close at 10PM) and it's easy to sit around for hours for whatever you need to do. I hope more places like this open.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I stumbled across this place recently--I'm a huge coffee lover and was pleased to learn that a new coffee spot opened near my job....And even more excited to learn that they serve Stumptown

My first visit was a few weeks ago--I ordered an Ethiopian pour over which was delicious! The place itself is cute and the girl who helped was extremely pleasant but not a fan of their music. May I suggest maybe some soothing Bossa Nova or Latin Jazz??--But 5 stars on my overall first experience.

However, I went in this morning right before work--around 620 am...This Asian girl "helped" me and was not pleasant at all. I'm no delight either in the morning, but I'm not serving coffee to the public! Not only was she rude but she told me they don't serve their drip till 7 am! I didn't have time for a pour over which is usually always my first choice wherever I go, so I left and went to my trusty, daily coffee spot that serves one of my personal favorites: Intelligentsia :)

Anyways.....1 star for her rude treatment and for their stupid no drip before 7 am BS!

You guys are a freaking coffee shop that is opened before 7 am in the Financial District and you don't serve your drip till 7 am???

Get it together!
author: This Is M E.

description:
Nice place to work and eat!

The workspaces cost $2/hr after the first 10 hrs, but the lounge and patio areas are free to use. I got some edamame to snack on while I sat in the free lounge. It was the perfect healthy snack! The wifi was fast and connected immediately. 

Didn't have a chance to try the other options but I'd go back again.
author: Allison H.

description: The staff are friendly. The food is good and the coffee is strong. I get a lot of work done in this cozy, hip, work friendly co-working cafe.
author: Meike H.

description:
We had a Python project night at the Workshop Cafe this evening.  

The setting was delightful.  There were lots of tables, good wifi, good lighting, comfortable seating, everything to fulfill the expectation of a good place to work and collaborate, with good coffee and snacks.  I attended a lecture near the front of the store, complete with whiteboard, that gave me knowledge I will take to work with me in the morning.  The complimentary food for the meeting was Patxi's deep dish pizza, and the free lattes I drank in real ceramic cups were superb.   

The gimmick that will draw programmers:  you will order your coffee through a smart phone app.  Yes, after you download the app you'll find out your table number and place your orders through it.  The snacks and coffee will be delivered to your table.  

The store plans to open for business some time next week.  I don't know what the prices will be, but if you are ordering your coffee through a smart phone app, I'm sure it will be a little more than Starbucks.  However, you'll get a much nicer working environment here.  

If you're like me, you are in the 50% of the market that uses a flip phone instead of a smart phone, and the app isn't going to help you.  Don't worry about that.  You can still walk up to the counter and order directly from the staff.
author: David D.

description:
You know what? I'm in a pretty lame catch-22 situation when it comes to working from home/writing fiction for fun. I hate bustling, agitated loudness and utter lack of electrical outlets that come with a lot of smaller cafes in my area. Unfortunately, I also live in an apartment with a room the size of a smart car garage space (with two cats who sometimes act like neglected, howling toddlers who can't be reasoned with). So, while I'd prefer to work in the privacy of my own home, a lot of times venturing out into cafe-land is my only option.

My boyfriend recently mentioned he'd gone to Workshop Cafe while waiting for me to finish up at work and absolutely loved it. Last weekend, with both of us in need of work space outside of the home, he suggested it again.

The Financial District is notoriously empty on weekends, so it was a surprise to me initially that this cafe was even open (let alone until 10pm!). The one time I'd wandered into Workshop Cafe to grab my guy had been on a weeknight during the end of business hours and the place had been packed (though not horribly loud, I'd noted). To ensure there was space available for two people to sit, we checked online prior to leaving the house. You can reserve your space prior to arriving for $2/hour (the first 10 hours are free to try out the place though...rejoice!), which I found really awesome. Who wants to spend money and time trekking down to FiDi on MUNI only to discover there aren't any spaces available?

The app revealed that there was ample space, so we decided to take our chances without an early reservation. Sure enough, we had our choice of spaces to sit down together at. It's perhaps a little irksome then that we didn't realize the near-arctic blast of wind that entered the building every time the door opened about 10 feet away would be hitting us straight-on for the next 3.5 hours we were there until after we'd chosen and paid for our seats. We probably could've moved elsewhere without too much fuss, but decided to brave it out. Unless you're a seasoned Midwesterner (and sometimes not even then, as I'm a Minnesotan myself), I wouldn't recommend any of the seating to the left of the entryway when it's cold enough to see your breath out. 

Anyway, the staff were friendly, the WiFi was super fast, and the drinks were more than sufficient. My only (other) complaint was that they didn't have any of their food available (not exactly sure if they just don't serve it on weekends or if they were actually out of it). We settled for cafe fare (granola cookies and the like). As a transgender guy, one of the things I dread most about ordering drinks at coffee shops is when the barista reads my name off my credit card and proceeds to shout it out when my drink is ready (I haven't legally changed it to my preferred name yet, and my legal name is very much female-oriented). Both times I ordered a drink though, they specifically asked me for my name, rather than just filching it off my credit card. Kudos. I appreciated it.

The atmosphere in the cafe is pretty chill. Sure, you'll get your occasional career-phone-chatter sitting right next to you, which can be obnoxious as heck (the bf and I were just really having bad luck on Sunday, it seems), and there will be some people who meet up to have group chats in the space. Overall though, Workshop Cafe is relatively quiet and comfortable, and if you have to get up to order another drink or run out for a bathroom break, it's nice to know your seat won't be taken when you mosey on back.

Definitely recommended for anyone who needs a space to work or study. I hope they open new spaces throughout the city, stat.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I pretty much live here.

Coffee is one of the best in the city, staff become your friends once they get to know you, super fast wi-fi, good food, you can have beers and wine, you can have meetings in a private booth -- it's like a super cool library with food and beverages and low level conversation. 

Loses a star because the toilet key situation is a bit annoying, you have to lug a big key to the toilet that has been touched by many toilet hands all day every day (I wish they just kept the toilets unlocked) and I find it a bit gross. I mean, I know bathrooms are for customers only, but there is a big sign that says "keys for bathroom" which strangers can use anyway, so I don't understand. 

Also, I hope they start accepting paypal one day, because I have accidentally left my wallet in another bag at home, and I was seriously hungry and also needed caffeine but I had to find other places that accepted paypal, which thankfully was a lot of places in the city. But I think for a techy type of workspace they should have paypal!
author: E B.

description: Pretty cool place.  You can get good food, drinks, beer whatever and super fast wifi and a great environment.  You rent a seat for $2 / hour but the wifi is high quality and workspaces are nice.   Lots of accessible power cords and work-minded people.  The music isn't too loud.  Atmosphere great for productivity.
author: Russ C.

description: I would give no stars if I could. First the person working there had no idea what size the drinks were. Second the pour over coffee was cold. They tried to convince me that's how it should be. This is not my first pour over but for sure my last at this place. They don't know what they're doing.
author: Scott S.

description: The quality and variety of food & drink at Workshop Cafe differentiates it from other coworking spaces, which (rather depressingly) lack dynamism other than the prototypical fast internet and wide tables. Definitely take advantage of the first 10 hours of checking in- they're free! Web app could use some improvements, but other than that, solid, productivity-inducing environment.
author: Clarice W.

description:
I'm a fan of the workshop service and the coffee/tea they serve. They have free Wi-Fi and they have two areas to sit in the cafe. The workshop area (larger tables, tons of outlets) is free to use for the first 10 hours and $2/hour thereafter. You could sit in the non-workshop area and use the Wi-Fi for free without a time limit. The only catch is the tables are very narrow and there are no outlets, so it makes studying/working a little more difficult. 

I haven't had too many of the food on their menu, but I can tell you the Avocado Egg Scramble is one of the worst I've had. The egg was so dry and spongy I only ate the avocado in the end. The pastries are fine, and I can't speak for the other foods they make in this shop, but don't even get the egg scramble. Definitely NOT worth $4.50. 

3 stars overall because I mostly come here for the workshop area and the coffee. 1 star or even no star for that Egg Scramble.
author: Tammy C.

description: Awesome place to work on my own stuff with reasonable price!
author: Yusuke T.

description:
Last time I was here about a year ago, I was amazed by how sweet the servers were by talking to us and brought out the charging cables for our phones. Therefore, I visited it again this time, and uh, not what I expected! 

Two guys at the counter didn't seem happy... I greeted them first and uh, no response... come on guys! (Then two female consumers showed up and these two guys talked to them with smile and nicer attitude..). 

Coffee was great! Nice and creamy! I enjoyed their Latte and Mocha. 

Nice working space with tons of outlets. And you will receive free ten hours to sit in the working space. I quite enjoyed a huge and wide space like this in this crowded city!
author: William W.

description:
Workshop Cafe has three things going for it: the espresso is awesome, the location is near my office, and the people are very friendly.

The financial district used to be a coffee desert. Coffee Bar moved in last summer (or thereabouts), but recently a bunch of new places have opened their doors, so it's really nice to see. Of all of them, so far I like Workshop Cafe the best.

They do a good job with their Stumptown roast served on La Marzocco machines. The baristas are pretty good. Sure the art could be a little nicer and the microfoam sometimes has a few extra bubbles, but the quality of the espresso shots they pull is quite good. The drinks are midrange in terms of flavor (not light and sweet like Blue Bottle or nor dark like they serve at Coffee Bar). 

I think it's also important to note that the people who work here are very friendly. There's no hipster better-than-thou vibe. Just nice friendly people behind the bar. 

The last thing I'll say is that the space is fantastic. They have outlets everywhere. If I ever need a place to work outside of my office, this is the place I would go. (and they're open until 10pm!)
author: Erik S.

description: From the outside, Workshop looks like a welcoming cafe of the sort that I often frequent in Boston. I was dismayed, however, that the interior was a fascist place of cordoned-off workspaces manned by a cafe worker enthralled by petty power. My boyfriend and I, upon paying for drinks, were told that we could choose to sit at one of the three tables upfront, or we could enter our phone numbers to gain entrance to the gated area. The first ten hours, we were told, would be free; since we were only planning to sit for an hour before dinner, we weren't worried. When we had been sitting peacefully for almost an hour, the aforementioned cafe worker came up to us to rudely rattle off policy, since we had only entered a phone number for the single seat we shared.
