Even though the place was almost vacant (we came two days after Christmas) and we couldn't possibly have stayed 10 hours (we arrived at 4pm), we were very rudely treated and the worker continued to glare at us even when we mentioned that we were leaving within 10 minutes and did not want to go through a time consuming sign-in process. I've been a huge fan of every other establishment I've frequented in SF over the last ten days, but the sheer rudeness, and adherence to rules without any logical cause, certainly put a damper on my night. I'll be sure to let my friends know not to come here.
author: Sophie H.

description:
Ah Yelp... where you can always find an idiot that gives a five-star review to a cafe that hasn't even been opened yet.

A freakish space. They at least charge for people to camp out here as a pseudo office to keep them solvent in this area of squatters and laptop zombies. But who really wants to pay to enjoy a place to have a coffee? And therein lies the main problem with this place: it feels too much like work to actually enjoy anything here other than getting work done.

Beyond these failures as a desirable cafe space, the coffee has solid pedigree (Stumptown beans, La Marzocco machines) but heavily underachieving results.

Too many better options nearby in town these days to want to come back here unless I'm getting paid to do so.
author: Teddy B.

description: Walking past this place on a sleepy Sunday morning and wanted to check it out since it looked like a serious coffee place. I got a chocolate croissant for my husband which was just ok according to him. I also got a soy mocha which was fine, I have definitely had better. Overall not as exciting as I thought.
author: Hela M.

description: Pretty cool idea and I like the idea of having somewhere to work where I can just sort of pay for the space and not feel obligated to get more coffee as I have lost my tolerance to caffeine and can't really do more than a cup a day. $2 an hour seems reasonable enough and the patio is still free. So it's not like you have to pay, unless you want an outlet.
author: Misha T.

description:
Ever since moving to SF, I've been looking for a good cafe to get some work done but it's hard to find a place with the magic trifecta of coffee + food options, free / good wifi, and the right level of background noise.  Workshop Cafe not only has all three, but outlets everywhere, comfy seating, late hours, and -- the real kicker -- an app that allows you to order anything you want (from within and outside the cafe) and hail a barista to your table.  You literally have no excuse to not be working.

To be honest, the ambiance was a little intimidating when I walked in on a Sunday afternoon- not much chatting was going on (most were there solo) and everyone was completely engrossed in their work.  The atmosphere did keep me from spending too much time on Facebook / other social media lest I be judged not worthy of the cafe's name.

They do charge $2/hour after the first 10 hours, so I'll probably be saving it for the days when I really need to get work done.
author: Kristina C.

description:
This is a great little study or work spot that I stumbled upon. I really enjoy the atmosphere and the service. A plethora of outlets perfect for all of your devices, pivotal in this day an age where even your toothbrush needs a charge!

I found the food a bit overpriced, and the fact that they charge per hour of working there will deter me from going back (after I run out of my 10 free hours).

My suggestion would be to let customers stay. Or even maybe just those who order food stay a few hours and waive the hourly fee.
author: Megan F.

description:
Part cafe, part coworking space. Definitely not typical.

They charge $2 an hour to use the space, but you get your first 10 hours free. You definitely see what that money gets you though. Good drinks, an excellent place to bring your laptop and work on things. Plenty of light, very fast and reliable wifi, and plenty of electric outlets.

Bathrooms are clean. They have a web site that you can check in on your phone and also make orders. They have power chargers for you to borrow if you've run out. Ergonomic chairs, a few mini-conference rooms with floor to ceiling white boards. They also have tables with super huge monitors you can hook your laptop up to.

This isn't a place where you'd pop in for a lazy afternoon reading a book, but rather a place to get work done. All in all, a very well-thought out space.
author: Al S.

description:
Why I think this place is awesome? Best environment to work, awesome playlist for working, reliable and fast internet connection, very friendly staff and lots of cool people which is encouraging to work. It's open till 10 pm and makes your time productive. Coffee is great, and you can order right from your phone. Everything is well optimized to create suitable environment for working.

What I don't like? It's just too expensive for long hours. If there were some long term membership like three months for $150 and then for example $1 per two hours could be way better for regular customers. Or for example for every 4 hours one hour free would be cool. 

Their pricing need some improvement. I know their operation costs a lot, but there are ways to balance it.
author: Siavash F.

description:
We needed a workspace with a whiteboard for our meeting, and Workshop Cafe fit the bill. We used up almost all 10 of our free hours over 2 meetings, but the fact that we could be there that long and not feel guilty about taking up space was great. Two of the whiteboard walls are in these tiny little rooms that can only fit one or two people comfortably, so if you have a bigger group pray you can snag the large whiteboard in the middle.

Drinks are pretty good here, but I really didn't see anything in the way of food. A couple of us left to get something to eat and then came back to keep working. It was actually a nice way to take a break and stretch our legs a bit so I'm not complaining.
author: Lisa A.

description:
This is the only café I think I've ever visited where you actually have to pay extra money to work in the café and beware- they are not at all upfront about that. 

I was eating my breakfast in the café and had an urgent work task I needed to take care of, so I pulled up my laptop at the table and was on an important call when i was told by a staff member that laptops weren't allowed in the café. Most people expect that a coffee house will allow them to use their laptop, it's a coffee house for goodness sake! This is the first time I've ever heard of a coffee house/café not allowing that. People specifically go to cafes like this one to work and drink their coffee. Not only was it rude, but embarrassing in front of the other customers around me. They should be more upfront with customers about the fact that they don't allow people to work in their "lounge" area, perhaps by putting up a sign. This is the only café I have ever heard of that has this policy. Again, I don't think it's a smart one. I wouldn't advertise a café as a "workshop café" when you don't even allow people to work in half of the café. It's false advertising. 

I'd save your money and go to one of the other bajillion cafes in SF that allows you to work without paying an extra fee.
author: Megan C.

description:
Almond croissant, tasty :). 
Breakfast taco, meh. 
Latte, can find better latte in Fidi. 
Staffs, very friendly and efficient. 
Wifi, super fast. 
I spent 5 hours in their work space, was able to get some work done despite of my neighbors' constant chatting/laughing/noise. Overall, I like this place. Will definitely come back.
author: Helen L.

description:
This place is extraordinary!

1. Super modern and spacious - there is an abundance of private booths, desks, outlets, monitors, and tables to suit your every need. Ergonomic chairs everywhere. They even have small, private conference rooms you can book in advance to schedule a meeting or interview. The cafe is brightly lit with open spaces that allow for maximum comfort. 

2. Tech-saavy - incredibly fast wifi. You can place orders, check who's sitting next to you, and view the menu on their online app. Great working environment for developers.

3. Staff - the staff is very friendly and accommodating to your every need. I've come up to them about order issues, monitor cable requests, and more. Each time they handled it professionally and with a friendly demeanor!

Last but not least, they gave out FREE ICE CREAM to all patrons today! Gosh, I love this place :D
author: Dev I.

description:
This place rocks!  Great Wifi.  Outlets everywhere.  Comfy seats. Great staff.

I love being able to work in a cafe without getting stink eye.  Nor do I have to buy drinks or food out of guilt.

When you do want something to drink, they have awesome coffee and espresso drinks.

I hope to see Workshop move to other neighborhoods where I hang out.
author: Donald P.

description:
Came here after work for after work - work.  real life work.

Fast internet, big space, love the music, external monitors, and good coffee!
Bonus points for the tall coffee tables!

If I ever find myself near the montgomery bart station I'll definitely come back and get work done here.
author: Betty S.

description:
This place is excellent.  Great coffee.  Friendly staff.  The guy who rang me up the first time was either a co-owner or just truly cared about the business and customer experience (either way it's a win for me).  
There is also grab and go coffee outside for $2.50.  Brilliant idea.  And great for avoiding any wait time when walking up Montgomery from BART, or heading to the Immigration Court.
author: Caleb A.

description: Cheapest real co-working space (complete with meeting rooms and places to make a phone call) in addition to a full coffee bar. Great place to work. Highly recommend.
author: Brandon B.

description: Workshop doubles as a workspace with some unique options. Costs extra money to sit indoors and use the Internet but it is in the middle of FiDi
author: Jim N.

description:
This place rocks!! I came here for a few back to back meetings with customers (I'm an out of towner) and this was perfect for post up work and meetings over coffee.

Great coffee selection, the food looked amazing, and I loved how comfortable the workspace locations were. If you sign in with the app your first 10 hours are free, FYI!
author: Lynne D.

description: The lighting in the back work spaces is fluorescent and after a few hours it felt like we were in an underground bunker. I'd recommend checking out some of the front bar seating to get natural light.  The food was overpriced for mediocre quality, but my friend said the coffee was good and you can bring in your own food. The following is preferential, but if you believe that getting up to walk/stretch for a few minutes every hour is important but get sucked into your work easily, this place fosters sitting in place all day... you can order from your phone and there are endless outlets.
author: Emily T.

description: You get the first ten hours for free. It's a cool spot, but I recommend you go there if you have to do work in a group. If you're alone, any cafe will do.
author: Akeem A.

description:
ENTREPRENEUR? STUDENT? STUDY FREAK? WORKAHOLIC? HIPSTER? CREEPY COFFEE SHOP STALKER?

Then this place is for you! Literally one of the best coffee shops I've been to because it's so, so tech savvy. When you go in, you sit down, check in on the app (app.workshopcafe.com), and enter your seat number. From the app you can order food, track how long you're there, and pay for your food. TECH SAVVY INDEED. I'll go ahead and list out the pros and cons:

PROS
-OUTLETS HEAVEN! Don't be afraid about not being able to charge your many devices. There are outlets everywhere.
-FREE & FAST WIFI.
-Great service. Text your order and get a response instantly. In a few minutes a dashing young lady or lad will come deliver your drink & food. They'll remember your name too!
-Prices are reasonable for great tasting coffee. Recommend the Kyoto Iced Brew if you're looking for something refreshing.
-SO MANY SEATS. They don't call this a workshop for no reason. There are chairs on chairs on chairs! You can choose to sit on a bench, in a spinny chair, on a sofa, or a stool. Take your pick friend.
-Great music, cool people, awesome vibe. This truly is the place to go if you're trying to get some work done or just need a relaxing place to read or browse the net.
-Other cool features like monitors, conference rooms, and well - I find out something cool about this place each time I come here. Check for yourself!


CONS
-You have to pay $2/hour. You do get the first 10 hours free. To be honest this isn't much of a con for the great space and fast internet. But there are cheapos out there who will go "UGH PAY TO SIT THERE? I DON'T THINK SO."
-Smelly bathroom. (Sorry, it's true!)

All in all, 5/5. See you guys here :)!
author: Ting Jung L.

description:
I like this spot a lot to get work done.  A hybrid coffee shop / coworking location, it serves the purpose.  The menu is limited, but healthy and solid.  The drinks are a litte pricey, but what is great is that they allow you to bring in outside food and drinks.  So I hit up Starbucks for a trenta iced tea for 2.85 then walk over to Workshop, plug in, and I'm set.  

Staff is cool.  Very helpful.  I was running out of power and forgot my power cord, and was able to borrow one for free just by giving my ID.  

Overall, I think this is a really good concept.  I've met a few cool people who are regulars, and I'm glad I found this place.
author: dave b.

description:
You check in with your phone. You find your seating which is numbered. You can text in your order. You may not even have to speak a single word to anyone in your time here.

An interesting concept. SF is so innovative. Not sure if I would come here after those ten free hours though. $2/hr for a chair and desk to sit in? I could just go to another cafe... Also not sure if I'm down with texting my order. Finding every way to convenience your life also foregoes human interaction... However, comfortable seating, quiet atmosphere, and lots of outlets does sway my heart a little bit... 

-Located in financial district so lots of cool, professional-looking people! (came around 10am on a Friday)
-Can choose to keep your tab open or close it immediately so not like a cafe in that sense
-Vibes of a cafe but it's a work space
-Got the Honey almond latte - I think I'm going to get just a latte next time. It had a strange, sweet yet bitter(??) sour(??) taste. But then again, I don't think I'm a honey/almond milk kinda girl. Tried to be daring and ordered the most exotic sounding one but I think I prefer the generic latte.
-Uses Stumptown coffee beans so ya know your coffee is good! (I got a good caffeine buzz with it)
-You can reserve your seat in advance so no worrying about running out of space!
-I saw many businesses hold conferences/meetings here. Really interesting meetup place.
-Time pressure was rewarding and terrifying even though it was free. I wanted to be productive knowing that I had a limited amount of time to work with.
-They played good music! (to my taste, at least)
-Pretty pricey (it was $5 for my honey almond latte but that was the most expensive from the lot)
author: Eunice A.

description: This place is really awesome! Cool atmosphere, great for work, and new concept. I wish there were more full meal options.
author: Ashley M.

description: Cafe style work space.  Private spaces available large and small.  Plenty of electrical outlets.  $2-$3/hour to use the space.  No purchase necessary.   Decent diner edibles and beverages.  Good expresso.
author: Stephen C.

description: This place is designed for working, and it's terrific. Fast wifi, monitors you can hook your laptop up to, outlets everywhere. You can order food and coffee by text message. First 10 hours are free, then its $2/hr.
author: Frederik H.

description: My beloved @Ashok Lalwani brought me something from here that I have never ever heard of : POMOGRANATE & HONEY COFFEE. He said it was a flavor which they had recently introduced.Trust me guys,it was superb. If you like dark chocolate with cherry flavor chocolates,you will like this coffee too. Just go for it!
author: Priyanka L.

description:
Great place for coffee + work 
https://twitter.com/anandsukumaran_/status/646466810276020224
author: Anand S.

description:
Just stumbled into this place while looking for a place to get some coffee without an egregiously long line. It's a great place to do some afternoon work or for a meeting. I went mid-afternoon and there was a lot of open space.

They've got some great meeting tables in back, a few places with whiteboards and dry erase markers, and some larger communal tables. Towards the front is some standard bench seating with lots of power outlets. The wifi seemed to work great as well.

Great place to get some work done. The coffee was good and the barista seemed to really care about the coffee being served, so you can still satisfy your inner coffee-snob while also being productive. And, since the place isn't in the Mission, you won't have to deal with an excessively too-cool-for-school crowd. 

I'm a fan.

PS - I think they have some type of app for booking space, but I definitely didn't use it and they didn't seem to be holding people to their bookings. I'm not sure if you really need to worry about that or figure that one out. Seemed complicated, but  I didn't try it so that's just a brash assumption on my part.
author: Neal V.

description: Excellent new coffee shop in Financial District. They serve stumptown and make a perfect 3rd wave espresso based drink or drip coffee. It seems like a solid place to work out of given ample seating and beautiful wood finish.
author: Victor W.

description: I walked into this cafe thinking it was a regular cafe. But realized it was "working on your laptop" like it is an office cafe. It was weird at first, but in the end I really digged it. The coffee was very good, and my croissant was delicious.
author: Andrea G.

description:
bottom line: starbucks 2.0

cool concept! you pay by the hour for working space (wifi and power) and can order food or drinks from the cafe while you work away. i was only there briefly and had the hot chocolate, which was pretty tasty, but could have been a little sweeter. it's very comfortable there, especially not having to fight over tables and outlets. also, the noise level is very reasonable, and the space in general feels very modern.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Good space with lots of power outlets for laptops, etc. Actually think there's more than 1 outlet per chair on average. Nice clean vibe, comfortable seating.

Now, I'm a coffee snob, so take this with a grain of salt: If you want coffee, go to the coffee bar across the street. If you want a place to work, have a small informal get together or meeting, head to this space.
author: Kris W.

description: Great place to geek out and kill the projects out. I prefer this place when it's dark outside.. lighting is terrible but i guess that's less distracting?
author: Denise M.

description: I had the most productive day working remotely from the office at workshop cafe.. Or maybe it was the espresso! You can reserve a spot before you arrive on their app and can have food/coffee delivered to you if you're in the thick of things. It's an awesome concept, workspaces do cost $2/hour but the first 10 hours are free. The staff here is also friendly!
author: Erica E.

description:
Awesome. Period.

Friendly staff, peaceful, and I came here because it just caught my eye while I was wondering aimlessly in San Francisco. Tried their Kyoto cold brew iced coffee that people were raging over and I liked it as well. The many outlets is good for the workers and students that need coffee and a workplace. Honestly, I'd go here rather than Starbucks.

The only reason why this place is a star short of a perfect 5 is the lack of food and drink variety. They only started 2 weeks ago, so I understand. I do hope that they'll get better and better in terms of drinks and food in the near future, though, because I'd definitely come back here again.

Should you visit here? Absolutely.
author: Terence H.

description: I liked this place a lot. I stopped for a quick bite and pour over coffee and liked it a lot. They also brew Stumptown which is a plus! I sat in the free section since I was in a hurry but it seems like a great working environment for people like me who like to get out when they work remotely. I'll be coming back!
author: Queen B.

description:
After coming here I felt like a sucker.  Sure the space looks nice and they have Stumptown Coffee. I stopped for takeout, seduced by the pretty pic on the menu. I ordered the kale salad with chicken for $13. Sure it was a little steep but I was willing to pay FiDi prices for convenience. 

When they called my name I tried to hide my shock and disbelief. They hand me one of those small takeout containers.  The one you might get for a small side dish. My $13 bought about 1 cup of kale salad and 2 oz of chicken.  This was easily $5 too expensive for the measly portion size, even when accounting for the FiDi surcharge. 

Usually $13 kale salads come with about 3 - 4 cups of kale and goodies. This place makes ordering at mixt greens feel like the dollar menu.

Don't get punked by the portions.
author: Jame E.

description: HANDS DOWN THE BEST PLACE TO GET WORK DONE! I have never stumbled across a cafe like this, something that is so conducive to getting work done. Each seat has at least three accessible outlets, and after checking in using the online system, you can order any food or drink from your seat by text, email, or phone call and have it delivered to your seat. Printers and desktop computers reside in the back, and study rooms and seats are reservable in advance. Larger meeting tables and whiteboards also exist, and with all of these resources, it makes sense that the cafe charges $2 per hour to sit and work. First time customers get ten hours for free, and I studied there for around six hours because the environment was so work conducive. In addition to the work environment, the coffee is also amazing; it serves Portland's famous Stumptown Coffee. Even better, the pourovers come served in Erlenmeyer flasks for the nerds out there. I will definitely be coming back to study and get work done.
author: Annie C.

description: Pretty good. Interesting login concept. Nice seating. Bathroom was clean. Teas were aight. Btw your 'green tea' is actually oolong :P Will be back again to do some pseudoworking.
author: Xue H.

description: I wish I could give this place a higher rating, as the concept works.  This isn't a place to come if you want a quick cup of coffee, because there is no reason to have to pay $2.00/hr to drink coffee.  However, if you are looking to get some work done and need a place to focus this is the place to be.  The 3-star rating is because this is a working atmosphere, however the employees don't treat it as such.  For example, they are yelling out orders, buzzers and timers are constantly going off.  I order a coffee and they bring it to me however, I am supposed to get up and get my own sugar on the other side of the cafe. If they say they are going to provide a service they should serve.  Don't advertise the concierge service if you are not going to take care of your customers, isn't that what I am paying for.  Also 20 minutes for a Latte, really?
author: Marjorie G.

description: They should really fix their internet access problems. A group of us sitting in the same area consistently saw terrible latency problems and web pages would also timeout.
author: Emmett K.

description: Wonderful coffee shop! The first 10 free hours of wifi was phenomenal. The service was excellent and the salmon bagel and coffee was delicious! Very happy to have stumbled upon this place.
author: Julia C.

description: This is one of my FiDi staples! Their almond milk latte tastes like marshmallow clouds in yo' face. Like so good I could have three in a row, but I won't do that to the good people of SF #hyper. The breakfast tacos and hot cereal are also ridiculously good. One star off because the service can be slow and I was given the wrong thing a couple times. They have room for dozens of people to work from their cafe, and the space is generally full (costs a little to use). They also have a pay-and-go coffee station so you don't need to go to the cashier...even had a bitcoin ATM for awhile! However, like many things bitcoin related, it was confusing and didn't last long...but kudos for thinking outside of the box. Thanks-a-latte Workshop!
author: Stephanie N.

description: Awesome place and coffee. Food was pretty good too. Just came for lunch but can see why people want to settle in to work here.
author: Julia B.

description: $2 drip grab and go coffee from Stumptown. Enough space to have a business meeting or do some solo work. Clean and modern ambiance. Solid music choices (at the right volume--not distracting, but enough to get my foot tapping). This is exactly what a coffee shop environment should be like amidst the sprawl of offices in the FiDi.
author: John G.

description: Nice clean area and located in a great location in the city.  However the problem is that you have to pay through a web app to actually use the tables inside. Also the food is very very small portions. I mean I'm Not a big buy and I was still starving after having what seemed like a filling meal. I do got to admit that the "work" area is pretty roomy and have incredibly fast internet. If you do go here I recommend eating somewhere first before do you work.
author: Hugo D.

description: You know there are lots of places you can get great coffee in San Francisco but hardly any make it hot enough . Workshop cafe makes great tasting hot coffee.
author: Deborah N.

description:
Awesome spot! Comfortable, plenty of electrical outlets, and good food/coffee delivered right to your table. The music was a little louder than I usually like when I'm working, but I got used to it pretty quickly. Only serious complaint was the bathroom, which was gross. 

Will be back for sure.
author: Erin P.

description:
The fluff Portlandia skits are made of.

A corporeal cliché.

This can be okay. I understand that businesses cater to their customers, and the Financial District isn't known for its warm and cozy mom and pop feel. The café doesn't pretend to be anything it isn't, and I respect its model even if I don't love it.
In fact, I want to like Workshop Café. There are very few coffee options in the area besides Starbucks and Peet's, so it'd be wonderful to have better alternatives. But this place simply doesn't vibe with me.

I find the place overwhelming and uninviting. The furniture, the methodology, the layout, the young corporate workers walking by flashing something--what??--on their iPhones to the workers simply doesn't appeal to me. Check-ins, apps, and touch screens have nothing to do with coffee to me. 

I understand that the concept is fine and useful for the area, but why also the Ikea-style furniture? Why make everything precise and factory-like when the concept is also a little dehumanizing and cold? There's something off-putting about a business establishment that literally only caters to people who own smart phones and credit cards. If you've got a landline and like to pay with cash, half the services are useless for you. 

I will say, however, that the workers are friendly but not always helpful. When I asked about the set-up of the place on my first visit, I got a memorized, word-by-word rendition that made me feel like my one human interaction in the sterile environment was with a corporate robot. Also, I fiddled with the grab-and-go station for a good five minutes, gave up, went up to the counter to pay instead, and only then was told that yeah, their grab-and-go pay station hasn't been working all day. Then why not help me?? Why not take it down??
Now, I can overlook all this. I mean, they still have a counter, a menu, and they still serve coffee. I don't HAVE to use the work areas or sit on the furniture if I don't want to. But unfortunately I also don't like the coffee, even after multiple tries. I've now tried both their espresso drinks and drip coffee, and it's definitely not a favorite, to the point where I don't want to finish my cup. Definitely not a good sign. I appreciate that they're not serving Peet's, but this place isn't a winner for me.
author: Marie L.

description:
Ok- I have never once yelped. I actually kind of loath yelp because everyone thinks they are a professional critic on every subject and sometimes these bad reviews really hurt a good, small business that is trying to make its way. I know people who are good at their jobs and work hard in a competitive city that have actually been fired over a bad yelp review. Good employees who had a bad day. NOT cool. 

All that being said I was compelled to put out some good vibes for Workshop café. 
I was turned on to it yesterday when I had a meeting set up there. It is a cool, convenient, well laid out space, that offers all you could need in a work space. 
Multiple options on work stations, singular, group, plug in, used their computer. 
Need to fax, scan, copy they got you covered. You are given 10 hours free wifi before they start charging you and then it is $2 an hour for super fast wifi. Seems reasonable to me.
The staff is super nice and friendly and efficient. They have a small but tasty and fresh food menu and will even go somewhere else to pick food up for you and bring it back to you for a small fee.

As I checked out my receipt was sent with out giving me the option to put on a tip. I thought it was just an oversight so I looked around-no tip jar. When I asked is there some place I can leave a tip. No-thank you, we don't accept tips its not part of our business model. I felt so weird leaving without tipping any one. 

Thanks guys-you  rock.
author: Trish T.

description: Not sure if the price is worth it considering how you can stay at Starbucks and work by your computer the whole day without paying $2 per hour. However, the ambience, cowork vibe, and weird San francisconess about the place makes me not care so much about price.
author: P.s. R.

description: The name says it all here because it's more of a workspace than a cafe.  It's just a coffee shop with unimpressive food that rents out table/chair workspaces  on an hourly basis.  As an out of towner I didn't really get the concept and the fact that that if you sat down you had to check in and checkout was annoying.  The salads and sandwiches we ordered were memorable only because they were so non-descript and something that could have easily been thrown together anywhere.  The place was also pretty dirty which was a big turn off.  If you're coming for a quick cup of coffee this could be OK but for lunch, not so much.
author: Doug G.

description: Great idea, great atmosphere and a very pragmatic approach to their business design. Yelp sent me here and within 10 minutes I had the best coffee I've had since moving to SF and a firm grasp on their system thanks to handy FAQ cards on all tables.
author: Sam E.

description: Thanks for not making eye contact with me the whole time I was ordering from you at the counter. Even when I stood there waiting for a receipt from my debit card and you told me I could wait "over there" for my drink, all the while still looking at your laptop. At the counter. Also, $4 for plain iced tea is stupid.
author: nikki l.

description: Part of me chafes at the idea of paying a premium for a place to sit and use my laptop after buying a cup of coffee, but another part of me noticed that there was nowhere to sit in any of the three other downtown coffee shops I had looked in at.
author: Erich V.

description: How can you not give this place a 5 star rating?! Great work and or study space. Delicious Mocha ( my fav), and the convenience is also amazing. I only write reviews if its worth it and this is one of those times. Keep up the great work here, I look forward to many more work sessions here as it is right around the corner from my office. Cardinal Chiropractic! So if you need to get checked after sitting all those hours I would love to help.
author: Oscar T.

description: Great place to work and meet people - clearly what it was designed for, and they excel in this space compared to their rivals. Meals and liquor is a nice touch. However, the coffee, though fresh, is unacceptably burnt.
author: Mojito G.

description: I don't  come for the workshop café, but I come for the honey almond latte.  How can espresso, almond milk and honey taste so good?!
author: Wakako U.

description: This place is epic. So many awesome study spots, fitting everyone's needs. The food is also really good and healthy. Fast internet and really nice staff.
author: Joel K.

description:
So I do like this place quite a bit. There are ALOT of positives, but there are some things that, for me, really drag their rating down. I have an account here and I've been here many times. My account with a large amount of hours left on it, so I'll be back quite a bit more.

So, I'll start with the good:
Their coffee is high quality and so is their food. 
For the most part, there is no commodity, GMO, pesticide ridden food/drink here. Yay! 
They have comfy furniture to sit in and outlets everywhere. 
They even have chargers for you to borrow in a pinch!  
The customers are there to work. 
The employees are helpful.
The music is not too loud.
It's a positive, productive environment.

Now for the negatives....
The bathroom is shared with the rest of the building, so you need to use these nasty keys with large objects attached to them to go to the bathroom. I don't like washing my hands and then having to carry a dirty key afterwards!
The bathrooms smell too bad too often.
The tables are not cleaned as much as they should be for being a pay-by-the-hour cafe/workspace.
It also seems to get dirtier in general and unkept more than it should for being a pay-by-the-hour place.

For me, the plusses outweigh the minuses, so I'll be back often, but I wish they would improve these things!
author: Ang S.

description: Well i figured today was the day I got some studying done. This place popped up on my suggestions and I have to say one of the best coffee shops I have ever been to. Food is great, coffee is really good and the internet is good! Definitely going to be one of my regular spots.
author: Alex P.

description: Loved the menu, everything I liked. Great environment to work from and people are very helpful even though I didn't know what to do with the check in and check out process
author: Cherilyn T.

description: If you are looking for a late night workspace, this is a pretty good cafe for study groups as well as individual work, but I don't understand why they charge $2 per hour to hang out there (this charge is not for wifi because you can access that for free.. also this rate is per person not per table). So if you plan on studying for a long period of time this is definitely not the place for you, especially because they already charge about $5 for a latte and the salads (didn't see any sandwich options) range from $9-13.
author: Heidi Q.

description:
Noisy, crowded, not cozy.
It feels like a public library where I have to pay money to have a seat. 

Food was good, bur portion is so small. 
Coffee isn't great.
author: Esther L.

description: Great place to work and buckle down & focus. I stop by here everytime i'm in SF to send some quick emails. This is the perfect place to sit for a bit and catch a quick break before moving to your next destination!
author: Madison L.

description:
CAUTION: This is an opinionated review.

The good:

* Wifi
* Conference rooms
* Monitors
* Coffee
* Food
* Printer
* Power outlets

Rich, one of the founders, is a very nice guy, but I noticed after about our first email exchange that offering suggestions for improvement wasn't going to do very much, unfortunately. An employee told me he gets suggestions all the time and has thought about everything a lot more than you or I have. Also, I think the importance placed on priorities may be skewed. So I'll just post my thoughts here for you guys to read, and maybe _that_ will help make things change.

After spending enough time watching people come in, I don't think *some* of the staff do a good job of making first time customers feel welcome; hiring people who are going to be a little more passionate about their craft, obviously cannot hurt.

Then, today I ordered a Mocha "for here", but received it in a to-go cup with an apology. They simply didn't have enough cups. There was a load running, and I was told they were understaffed. Does buying enough extra mugs to the point where this sort of thing doesn't happen fall too low on your priority list? I mean we're talking chump change. You should probably have at least double your capacity worth of mugs, if not three times. Also I would have waited for a mug, like I had initially requested, since I was not in a rush, but was not offered the option until it was too late. I told her it was no big deal, and not to worry about it -- it's not her fault, obviously.

They also have what I call the "guard-dog" who literally sits at the entrance to the workplace. The "guard-dog" is forced to have you sign-in through your phone, and prove to you that you signed in, by showing your phone to him/her. This is just awkward. Please do allow me to sit down without being badgered by someone I don't want to talk to. Also, the desk and chair you give the 'guard-dog' looks so uncomfortable, I'm sure anyone who has to sit there all day would become quite unhappy; I would.

Then you get to the app. Let's not even get started here. If you're going to open a techy cafe catered to programmers, designers and the likes, you REALLY need to up your "app". First of all, don't call the app an app. It's a _website_, and it sucks so bad, you can't even use it on your actual desktop. Furthermore, is it not optimized for the desktop. I really don't want to use my phone. I want to use my computer. And I don't know if that's jQuery Mobile but it's hideous. The whole checking in thing should probably be re-visited. We're programmers. Do something smart. You're already assuming everyone has a phone right? Well every phone has a Mac address. For your customers, they ususally always connect to the wifi. Your phone connects to wifi before you enter the building. Save mac address, make relationship between user and mac address, automatically detect users before they walk in the door, profit.

In conclusion, the benefits outweigh the costs in my book, but you still have a long way to go before I'd give this place higher than 3 stars.

I'll mostly be coming back because of all the super hot nerdy girls.

UPDATE:

I just had super weird experience in the bathroom. I went to go grab a key to use the bathroom, and someone grabbed it at the same time as me. So we went together. Only problem is, their male bathrooms only have one urinal and one stall. Somebody was in the stall. I was nice and let the guy go ahead of me, but he must have had http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paruresis because he didn't even start peeing until the guy got finished his business in the stall. I had to awkwardly wait for this guy to finish getting over his pee-shyness. It was either that, or go in the stall. And trust me, you did not want to go in that stall after hearing what was going on in there. Bottom line is... you need more bathrooms. Period. This is essential to any business.

UPDATE:

There is Ikea furniture here. And no, the Eames chair does not make up for it.
author: Zachary K.

description:
Over priced and didn't like the look of the food. 

Not sure I understand the $2/hr ethos to work there when you can buy a coffee and sit in a chair rather than just paying for the chair in other cafes. 

The concept and food is lost on me.
author: Jade H.

description: I work literally right next door to this place and NEVER go here. The portions are way too small and expensive and the service is really rude. They have an alternative set up for their lounge space. But they can't take a moment to break down what their weird seating arrangements are. The coffee is good and the decor is interesting
author: Kelsey N.

description: Great for getting work done. I had a soy latte which was not the best I have had but not the worst either. They charge 2 dollars/hr for the workspace but have free area by the door.
author: Reet R.

description: Although the idea is good in theory, the workshop cafe is very poorly executed. Not enough spaces, coffee is over priced and the overall feel of this place was a bit pretentious. As a college student looking for a place to just sit down and catch up on some homework this was not the right fit for me.  Only reason why I'm giving this 2 stars is because of the free wifi
author: Linda H.

description: It's a good spot to go to in the Fi-Di.  I gave it three stars because they don't roast their own beans, but it is a good place to go to if you work in that area.  Anna was the one who served me and she's very kind.
author: Johnathan W.

description: extremely dirty!! I found 2 gross looking hair in my food! besides that the internet kept going off! keep in mind they charge u 2 dollars per hour for their "internet" and space. i always herd from people that cafe sucks but i tried it myself and its worse than what people describe! i don't know how it hasn't been shut down yet for health issues!
author: Nelly W.

description: I know of places that look almost as nice with good coffee, wifi, outlets and you don't have to pay to sit.
author: Matthieu T.

description: Nice intersection between a co-working space and a cafe. Great atmosphere and staff. Perfect place to get things done!
author: Maximo R.

description: This place is great! I've been coming here to work for a few hours in between running errands downtown. The location is very convenient and the staff is very friendly. There are outlets everywhere and lots of space and variety (couches, tables, conference rooms, booths, etc.). The WiFi is good also, much better than at some other cafes I've worked out of so definitely a plus. The music they play is not my favorite but I just bring headphones and listen to my own music.. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Helen P.

description: This place is annoying.  Stop bothering me about checking in. I don't want my information to be in your lame hipster database.  Terrible hospitality experience.
author: D W.

description: This place is awesome. I've only been here once to do some work, so I don't have a lot to say about working here, but I can say that their drinks here are really good.  I'm a big fan of cold brewed coffee, and if you're looking for a good one, their Kyoto cold brew coffee is amazing here. It tastes very fresh, smooth, and not very acidic - which is a plus in my book!
author: Richelle L.

description: This is the best place for co-working aka 'working from a coffeeshop'.  They've got everything covered -- a ton of outlets, staff that brings drinks to you, so you don't have to worry about your seat, and a nice atmosphere.  Working from here costs $2/hr (the first 10 hrs are free) and you can bring in outside food no problem (they've got a microwave!). This is a huge find!
author: Mike V.

description: Probably a good place to go if you need a workspace.  But don't bother stopping in if you just need a cup of coffee and a bite.  Coffee is fine but EXPENSIVE.  The pastry I decided to splurge on was less-than-fine and expensive.  There are many better alternatives nearby if you just need your caffeine.
author: Gail J.

description:
I think this place is a GREAT place to do your work in groups or go solo. It's designed for it! Don't come in here with the expectation that this will be a place to relax and meditate. Since it is located in FiDi, Workshop Cafe is catered towards ANYONE who needs a space to study and/or do work. I didn't get to explore every corners of the store, but I've noticed that they have a lot of power outlets. Hello, Outlets Heaven!!! I think the coffee house at UC Davis should take a lesson from this place. College students, especially, are in dire need of outlets on campus. There are so many competitions for coffee shops along the streets of Montgomery. This place did something right. 
How it works: You download their app, check in when you come in for work and check out when you leave. Pay as you go, no commitment. I think that it's $2/hr. Barista told me that you get 10 hours free. 
They serve Stumptown coffee. Personally did not think my cappuccino was anything special. It's just not for me because I don't like wet cappuccinos. But please give it a try! Everyone's different.
author: Anh L.

description:
the ppl who work here are rude, and they either 1) don't want to work there,. or  2) they are too cool to help you when you place an order for coffee

the stereotype of ppl in SF being pretentious snobs - stems from the workers here. 


If you order a salad, they will make the salad whenever they feel like it... 
You will wait and watch them catch up on gossip before they make your salad. 

If you have a question, they will make themselves complete unavailable to help you.

Food/coffee overpriced, and at there are plenty of other places to go that are much better.
author: hannah g.

description:
this place is great - i love the concept. a cafe for those who actually want to do work. outlets *everywhere* and fast fast WiFi.
the atmosphere and decoration is modern minimalist. plenty of seating and a wide range of seating choices including arrangements for small groups. 

10 hours are free. 2$/hr after that, plus you don't need to buy anything unless you want to.

food is limited, so eat earlier or come prepared.

this is my second time in here, and i've interacted with several of the staff. they *all* have been very friendly and relaxed.

IMPORTANT: the outlets for the front row seats are powered by battery-backup devices. if you're not getting power, then the backup box might need to be switched out. just ask someone at the counter.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description: An unusual place that is primarily a place for people to work. They pay by the hour for this. There are very few seats for people looking to dine in. If you want somewhere to dine in, go elsewhere. My breakfast plate was affordable but of somewhat poor quality. The fruits were dethawed frozen fruit. Not very yummy. My recommendation is to come here for coffee that you will take on the go.
author: Michael M.

description: The mocha was amazing and the young man, who helped us who looks like Joseph Gordon Levitt was very helpful and courteous.
author: Tom H.

description: One of the greatest startups/ inventions ever made. In a city filled with startups and work-at-home/freelance types, this is the perfect place to get work done in a relaxed, cafe-like environment without the boisterous chatter and children being around. Also, the staff couldn't be nicer. There needs to be more locations in San Francisco soon!
author: Katey S.

description: I really like this place! It's a bit cramped when crowded, but the seats are comfortable. I love working from home, but sometimes I just need to get out and interact with human beings. Everyone was generally friendly and didn't seem to mind my coworker & I's occasional chattering about silly things.
author: Christy S.

description:
TLDR: Great work space. Best customer service I have ever received. 

Let me talk about the awesomeness of this place. The food is decent (small portions, but that's good since you don't want to go into a food coma), the coffee great, the system for never having to leave my space (which I've checked into online; hurrah) and food/drinks are delivered to me is PERFECT for getting work done, but, even more important to me, is that they take feedback really, really well.

I am sitting here right now working on a business plan for a company my family is starting. Three things disturbed me in quick succession that have happened before while working in this area. I decided to email my concerns to Info@workshopcafe.com

Literally ten minutes later the manager came up to me to address my concerns (I'm signed in at my seat, so they knew where I was and I mentioned in my email I was currently there). Ten. Minutes. They were thorough, polite, and genuine; one of the issues they considered a feature not a bug (I encouraged a poll which they took well; both of us were clearly convinced we were right, neither of us had data beyond anecdotal), one they already were actively addressing, and the other they thought was a great idea and hoped to implement. They were also forwarding my email to the owner (who I met a year ago and I know is actively invested in the business and the decisions within it).

It was the best customer service I have ever received.
author: Morgan W.

description: Great place to work and monetizes us idiots taking up room with our laptops.
author: Ryan S.

description: Fail on my part, walked here for a meeting and this is a cafe where you rent seats by the hour to work.
author: Sarah T.

description: Can't comment on cafe itself, which isn't yet open, but comfy chairs and chill vibe equal refreshing addition to FiDi.
author: Super D.

description: Cool place to get work done. Love the option to sit and use wifi for $2/hr without having to buy food/beverage. Elec outlets everywhere. Friendly service, amazing playlist, closes at 10pm every day. Very very crowded during the daytime, roomy in the evening. Sign up and the first ten hours of wifi are free.
author: Ethan L.

description: passed by one day and decicded to walk in. the place is filled with group of people working on their laptops. You can rent their space by the hour and can order your food and drinks from your seat. Pretty cool place and the coffee is good. I had a ice latte.
author: Jan H.

description: I thought my experience was pretty good, pleasant service and I enjoyed my breakfast bagel and coffee very much but what got me to write this review was how incredibly fast of a reply I received from them from my request several weeks later to get a copy of my receipt.  I don't think I waited more than a few minutes!  That was amazing follow up service!
author: Lauren S.

description: Exactly what I needed. This is what I wanted Starbucks to be like; the perfect place to work. The place keeps track of how long you sit there through an app; 2 dollars an hour for wifi and charging. First ten hours are free. The place even has conference rooms. And the best creamy, hot chocolate in the US.
author: Jorgen S.

description:
I am giving them 4 stars instead of 5 because the music is extremely annoying.  Everything else is perfect.

The staff are helpful, the environment is great, there are outlets for you laptop everywhere.

The only problem is people come here to work, which is challenging sometimes when music is playing so loud.  I would suggest they end music completely, except maybe a small area near the entrance and bar, and only play it quietly there.

Everyone here has a laptop because they come to work.  If the customers want to hear music they can easily use headphones and listen to pandora, spotify etc.

Otherwise challenging to do anything that requires focus like working on a finance model or writing code.

Again, everything else is perfect, and I do suggest you try it out if you are in between traditional office spaces.
author: Tobias B.

description: I think they need to stress that their main business is to provide a working space for $2/hr (who just happens to serve coffee on the side). Being right in the middle of the financial district and getting such a huge space, the overhead cost must be high. This is a new concept and I wish they succeed.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: I really love coming here to catch up with work. If you are the kind of person who needs a little background noise to focus then this is the place to come! I do think charging $2 per hour is a bit pricey for those like me who come very often and can easily spend 5 hours here. A monthly membership fee would be a great option to have instead so I could pay maybe $20 a month for unlimited hours or something. I wish there was maybe a little more on the menu to offer as well, but this is still a fairly new business and I've been coming here all of 2014 so it can only get better! Love the vibe here, great work.
author: Aaron B.

description:
+ 5 stars: The Workshop cafe a drop-in co-working space designed to facilitate getting work done without the isolation of a library, without the expense of a monthly membership work space, and without the discomfort of a typical cafe. The staff is great. The space is great. The wifi is great. The outlets are great. You get it - the place is great. I hope this idea spreads like wildfire. 

-2 star: The music is obtrusive, both in the volume and in the style, considering the co-work nature of this cafe. It's much easier to put on headphones to listen to your own version of inspirational music than it is to block out unwanted music when trying to work, have a conversation, or listen to your own music. I would bump this up to 5 stars if the next time I came in there was much quieter jazz, or ambient sounds, or something of that ilk playing in the background. I took away two stars because the music is a pervasive part of the Workshop cafe experience.
author: Jacqueline G.

description: So much space. So many outlets. I love it here. Great place to get some work done and to stay caffeinated.
author: Eunice K.

description: Workshop Cafe's smartphone app actually works on my outdated clunky old Blackberry.  So I can actually reserve a table and have a nonfat latte waiting for me when I walk in.  This is a nice place to have an impromptu meeting with a client or to stop in and actually get work done because there is an abundance of outlets for your computer.  Although you might get distracted by eavedropping on the hip people at the next table planning a hot new startup.  Not that I evesdrop.
author: Dan W.

description:
Amazing concept!  I happened to come across this place through a Yelp search earlier today while looking for a nearby coffee shop to work out of for a few hours.  This place fit the bill perfectly!

As the video on their homepage does a great job of explaining, you're basically paying $2/hour to rent a seat in their location with the option to buy food or drinks (or not).  For folks who just want coffee, there's some free area seating up front.  For everyone else though, you can reserve a specific seat either on the fly, on your walk over, or days in advance (though that last one involves a $4 reservation fee).  Your phone number is your identifier in the system online, and your first 10 hours are free to test out the concept -- so there's nothing to lose.

The setup feels just like a shared office environment where people have cafe memberships - such as NextSpace...except without the monthly fees.  As I'm just starting up my own company, having the ability to work outside of home in a space that's guaranteed to work (ie fast wifi and accessible outlets) without being tied to pricey monthly contracts is great.  They also have different seating setup types depending on your mood and who you're working with (shared tables, booths, private spaces, etc).

Oh also, they have free chargers for you to borrow (they just need to hold onto a card or something) to charge up your phone, laptop, etc.  That was a HUGE save for me today.

They're still working on figuring out things themselves I think, but I'm not taking away any stars for that as they legitimately seem like they're continually improving their offerings and genuinely want to make you happy.  The one thing I hope they offer in the future is virtual business addresses - then it'd be a one-stop-shop for businesses just getting started!
author: Liz E.

description: I really like this place. Had a big work week, so spent the extra hours here. Coffee is yummy (Stumptown, and they made the espresso _right_, don't get me started, just say its a happy little cup). Fit out is fun and there is plenty of choice depending on the amount of noise you want to make or deal with.  I like a little noise, and enjoyed the music (mod level, alt-j sensibilities), helps me concentrate.  Food is quite good. Enjoyed the salad and have made a habit of the warm cereal & espresso ($6 deal!) in the early morning.  (BTW: Thank you for opening at 6am weekdays, I know, its hard). Internet is fast, and was there when they had an outage and I they comped everyone for the hour.  I can't explain the super-neg reviews except to say that wasn't my experience at all. I wish there were more places like this.
author: David B.

description: The best! Love the Stumptown coffee, the power strips at every table and the excellent wifi. The 10 free hours are a great way to get settled in here, but after that the rate is perfectly reasonable.
author: Jason S.

description: I had a wonderful experience at Workshop Cafe.  Seeing as it was my first time there, the staff was eager to show me how it all works.  Sometimes you just need to get out of the office and continue your work somewhere else.  The idea of being able to reserve a space to work, combined with a coffee shop, is genius.  The coffee was great too!
author: Beau T.

description: Most awesome cafe ever. The coffee is good, but what's most astonishing is the atmosphere. Plenty of power, wifi, etc makes this the perfect spot to camp out and get some work done.
author: Phil D.

description: Great hot tea!! The flavor was delicious! I can't drink coffee so I usually get boring tea at coffee shops. I finally felt like I was getting something that I actually enjoyed, at this new cafe!
author: Lisi G.

description: Spacious, friendly staff and good coffee :) There are few coffee places open late in the financial district (apart from Starbucks) so this is a nice alternative.
author: Pooja S.

description:
The best working cafe in San Francisco.

Terrific coffee, amazing vibe, and comfortable seats.

You can't really get better.
author: Jason H.

description: The drip coffee is actually damn good. Agent Cooper would approve.
author: Maximillian M.

description: It's a rent-by-the hour co-working space with the perks of also serving coffee and food. It's definitely a place SF really needs and seems to be doing well in the financial district. The space is huge with lots of people working. Thumbs up for the first ten free hours, decent food and drinks, clean facilities and being exactly what I need. Things to improve on: Their app could use a little bit of tweaking for easier use and the bathrooms, while spacious, could use extra hooks/table at the entry so you don't have to lug your stuff into the stall with you.
author: Trinh N.

description: great coffee (stumptown) and unique offering... somewhere to sit in the financial district! this place is large.
author: Andrew K.

description: For a workspace it's a bit on the pricy side (bc of the amount of time you'll spend there). Also, that's because there's a good menu with items in all sizes and for all tastes. The place is very well located right next to the embarcadero ferry port (where they have a market and all sorts of goodies btw). The space is well designed, temperature is nice, and it's nice to work with a view on the street, or further inside for less distraction. I like that you can even sit outside. It's 2$ an hour for the workspace but they start you off with 10 free hours which spells confidence in their business; I like that. I tried quite a few of their menu items, you can order via the app straight to where you are sitting without getting up (also a nice touch), and the food comes in all sizes and kinds so you can munch a  bit while you work as the day goes by or pause and have a meal. If you don't want to pay for the workspace, you can sit outside in the non workspace sections and run your machine off the battery. I like that that is an option: the thing is I feel like I have the choice of where and how and what to do and that's my kind of business.
author: Zou Z.

description:
First off, I should probably apologize. The only reason I came here in the first place was because I was looking for a bathroom open on the night of the CNY parade. Now with that out of the way, onto the review itself.

I ordered two drinks: a cappuccino and a cold brew, both about 4 dollars each. The cappuccino was excellent. Not only was it topped with a creamy cap of finer-than-fine  milk, it met so well with the dark espresso underneath that I was instantly asking my friends to try it upon my first sip. Shit's good man. The cold brew was pretty good, but not quite as satisfying. I wish they sold some sort of chocolate treat, as it would complement the flavors very well. Still, this could just be personal preference.

Oh yeah, the bathroom is pretty nice to.
author: Zeno H.

description: Very cool place that is very accommodating. Its free to use until 10am and then just $2/hour with ten hours free! Really good coffee. Good people watching and a comfortable and centrally located venue.
author: Joel B.

description: This is a great place and concept and welcome addition to the public work spaces in SF. The food/coffee is quality but you're not forced to purchase good from here (they allow outside food drinks as well and let you simply work or meet here). The space is kept clean and the staff is very friendly.
author: Lily C.

description:
They put skim milk in my chi. Tasted terrible. You should never default to skim milk, it should always be 2% or whole milk.

Very overpriced. They only offer one size-$4.00 for a watered down iced chi is a joke. 

Go to Coffee Bar.
author: Elaine M.

description: The wifi works great, plus they serve Stone IPA and Rasputin Stout. Very nice space. Check it out for yourself.
author: Dan N.

description:
I've been a regular for a few months now and loved it until recently.  The quality of this place has gone way downhill.  They recently hired some new employees who seem to have dragged the business down quite a bit.  My last few visits have been frustrating to say the least.  

One visit I ordered an item from their menu (using their phone number app), received a confirmation text, and 30 minutes later nothing.  I texted again asking about it and again nothing.  At this point it had been 45 min so I talked to an employee directly and found out they sent my order to the wrong table.  I understand mistakes happen and I blew it off and remained a regular.

My next visit back I was working at a communal table which seats ten.  Their were already about 5 people scattered around the table and everything was fine until a woman came in trying to teach a class.  She decided to take over the table we were working at.  Clearly they wouldn't fit and instead of taking it somewhere else she decided to inconvenience everyone around them.  They dragged chairs from all over the cafe and squeezed the people already working there into a corner.  Some people just left fed up and others tried to tell them they couldn't do that.  It honestly felt like the customers were doing the staffs work in dealing with the situation.  Staff eventually came over about an hour later to check them in but again didn't fix the situation.  Another flood of her students later came in and we just decided to move across the cafe.  She was also so loud you could hear her from every corner of the cafe.  It was very frustrating and inconvenient. 

After this experience I'm sad to say I won't be back.  The older employees have always kept everything in control and maintained a reliable and consistently great environment.  The newer staff didn't do there job and left the customers to deal with a mess that shouldn't have been their problem.
author: Jas C.

description: Wish I knew about this place in grad school! Great workspace and delicious Stumptown coffee.
author: Denise M.

description:
Very nice staff, lots of power outlets and strong wi-fi; what more can you ask for? Oh yes, since they're relatively new, the first 10 hours are free. Having said that, the place was pretty full both times I stopped by so it seems that promotion may end soon.

Great place to stop, check email, vmail and re-group after meetings in the city.
author: Michael M.

description: This place really is no different than dropping your butt at a Starbucks. When I walked up to the order counter, I was immediately educated by the counter girl, that this is a 'workstation' bar. But, I am welcome to order some food and either take it to go, or sit outside. Here they cater to people coming in and utilizing the many electrical and computer ports, while sipping their favorite (fill in the blank) beverage. I was a bit put off by this bold explanation. But, told her I wanted to order a salad anyway. . . I paid and was told they will call my name when it's ready, I am welcome to . . sit outside. (again a little put off by the dismissal to the outside). So, out I went, which was where I intended to be anyway since it was a nice day out. . . and I waited. . . and waited. .  .and waited. . . 20 minutes of waiting for a flipping salad. I walked back in to see if they had called my name inside, and didn't remember I was outside. Nope... the girl says, "what was your name again?. . Oh, yeah, I'm going to get to that". . (please let me explain to you the reader, that there are NO OTHER ORDERS being worked on). Well, another 6-8 minutes and my salad was handed to me. I went outside where I had already been banished, and ate my lunch. I am giving ONE STAR here simply because the salad was actually good. BUT, the service (extreme lack of) and the attitude towards a person who simply wants to sit down and enjoy their lunch, I definitely say, forget this place. . . While I was growing old waiting for my order, a couple of women walked up to the door, and one says "there's no crowd here, it must be bad". . . then they turned around and walked away. There is no crowd because they have no concept of service.
author: Greg S.

description: Great Stumptown coffee and good snacks, and I like the $2 fill it yourself coffee.  However, the service is soooooo slooooooow if you order any barrista-made drink. If there's a line out the door at Coffee Bar it'll still be faster than coming here if there's no line at all.  On the weekend, there's nothing else open nearby that compares.
author: W W.

description: fast internet and can order coffee with phone.
author: David S.

description: Great place to work. The location is pretty good (at least for me) and it's a well designed place that fits its purpose: give you a great place with the things you need to do some great work.
author: Alexandre N.

description: Service is very nice but the wireless is like molasses! 1.3 mps?? What?? When I asked the concierge what was going on, he didn't even know what the speed was. I tested the speed in front of him and he thought 1.3 mps was totally acceptable. Well, it's not if you ask people to PAY for wireless. Yes. First ten hours are free, but after ten hours...do they expect people to pay for such a slow connection??
author: F V.

description:
I am at workshop cafe right now and I like this place.  The food is a little pricey, but I just had their locally sourced chicken sandwich and it was pretty tasty.  

Its $2/hour after the first 10 hours which they throw in for free.   Plenty of space to work, plenty of power, and you can order from the app and they'll bring the food right to your table.    They claim that they have "crazy-fast wifi" but I just tested and got about 2.5Mbits down and 25Mbits up.  the upload speed probably does qualify as crazy-fast, but that download speed doesn't deserve the "crazy" label.

I think this model of charging by the hour is superior to the workspaces that charge by the day.  There are quite a few people here, despite it being pretty late on a weeknight.

Downloading torrents seems to be blocked by their router.  My recommendation to them is to have some portion of food/beverage purchases count as a credit for future work-sessions.  This would incent users to purchase food, and come back again - it would serve as a built in loyalty program without requiring a loyalty card.

Update - I came back again, and its starting to get really crowded - still room, but i anticipate that they are going to need to open up a few more locations to keep up with demand.
author: Denis G.

description: So the idea of paying for a place to sit was a little weird for me. But, when I needed a place to get some work done I stopped in here one day (the first ten hours are free). I got a surprising amount of work done; the place is designed for it. The cafe portion of the enterprise almost seems like an afterthought. There are plenty of outlets, monitors to plug into, decent wifi, printing/scanning, etc. For all that, a couple dollars an hour doesn't sound too bad. Sure you could go to a regular coffee spot, but you aren't going to get those amenities and you are going to feel obligated to buy something. I feel no such obligation here. That said, the pomegranate mocha is pretty good. If you do order something, you don't even have to stop working, just text them your order and they will bring it to you. The only negatives I could were that the prices for food and drinks weren't cheap...welcome to San Francisco; also the concept is a little confusing the first time you visit.
author: Justin H.

description: Amazing place to work. The staff is super helpful and genuinely friendly. Wifi is low latency, speedtest.net reported ~3.4 Mbps down and ~ 4.0 Mbps up.
author: Malcolm G.

description: Great space for hammering out work in a more relaxed, awake space--Hope is da bomb as is the rest of the staff!
author: JJ M.

description: Workshop Cafe is a good concept, good space, but the food and tea is sooo expensive ($4 for a cup of tea...really???). At least I can bring my own food. What's most irritating about this place is like every other damn cafe, the staff thinks it's about them and have the music up so loud. If we wanted loud music we would use our headphones or go somewhere else. We're here to work done. It's so impossible to find a cafe to spend time and do some work that's relatively quiet. I mean, in most cafes we already have to compete with loud expresso/cappuccino machines. Just wish staff were more considerate. I wish people in general were more considerate.
author: Kay O.

description: I've been here 11 times, and provided a 1 star review before, but it was removed and censored by Yelp. I still maintain that the blonde girl that works here treats her customers like criminals.
author: John D.

description: This review is only for the latte. One of the best in the area, very smooth with no bitter aftertaste.
author: Keith L.

description: Great cafe to get some serious work done. The staff is very friendly and helpful and the seats are comfortable. Different heights, configurations are available so its good for working solo as well as collaborating. The Wifi is fast and there are plenty of power outlets at every seat. I've only been here a couple of hours and it's awesome!
author: Manu P.

description: Came here for a group meeting. I ordered a mocha which took a while for them to make but was pretty good. If it's your first time here it can be confusing. Seating up front is free but pretty packed. The back is for groups, you have to pay $2 a person an hour . It is pretty busy as well. All the seating is marked with numbers and you go to the front to tell them what seating you are taking up. Two people in our group had the mobile app so they had ten hours free. The music is good, noise level is low and wifi is free. It's a pretty good spot to meet up and get work done!
author: Lizzie L.

description: i've been coming to work here a lot. love the space, it's affordable considering that they actually have good, working wifi, as opposed to most other "internet cafes" i've been in the city. their food menu is really good for a coffee shop. they have vegan and vegetarian options as well. -1 star for having the worst coffee i ever had in the city. still ove the place! :)
author: Judit H.

description: Brilliant idea.  Reserve your seat, order a coffee, free wifi and you're ready to go.  Stumptown coffee, great music and folks are quick to help you if you need.
author: around town e.

description: This place is really cool.  Awesome workspaces and great coffee.
author: Brian M.

description: great place to actually get work done, while surrounded by other people doing the same. still a few kinks to work out, eg texting drink orders to the staff, but I was impressed overall. stumptown coffee was great, and they'll have wine and beer soon. and they're open late! will def be a regular here.
author: Leila H.

description: My new favorite place to work.  A bit pricy but they don't care if you bring in outside food. The food selection has improved. Love the soup salad combo. Great background music. Wishing they had a monthly rate or some kind of discount for frequent flyers.
author: Laura W.

description:
i like this place.

very reasonable deal, and you get to order coffee and delicious almond croissants by email or text.  fast wifi.  however, many times there are almost no available seats and also some of the chairs are more comfortable than others.

they should have just gotten all good chairs.  but for a few hours where you need to get shit done, this is pretty great.
author: Yin L.

description: Very nice place for doing some casual work. The wifi is free and the table height is good for using laptops (your back won't hurt). The cappuccino was perfect!
author: Frane S.

description: This cafe was wonderful, a lot of comfortable seating and a good atmosphere. The croissant I had was a bit burnt but it was so delicious that I didn't really mind. The service was really convenient, I was able to text my order from my table. I will definitely go back
author: Sarah B.

description: Workshop Cafe, you had me at Stumptown. But your space is awesome, your staff is friendly, your lattes are delicious AND you are open on Saturdays! This is indeed the start of something beautiful.
author: Zoe M.

description: I am currently in the workshop cafe enjoying the chill atmosphere and my deftly poured shot of espresso. Nothing bitter about it. I don't want to mention any names, but "this person" poured a damn good shot. "This person" also went above and beyond to make me feel welcome. It's almost like they were a real human being with an intact emotional center, something all too commonly either contrived or absent altogether in today's hustle-bustle economy.
author: Blart G.

description: i work across the street and i love this place!  i'm from portland or originally, so i'm stoked they serve stumptown and the baristas are awesome.  it especially seems like a cool place to work remotely. check em out!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Super cool place. Was very comfortable. I wasn't in here for too long but the staff was friendly and the place was quiet. I can see this place as a great place to getting a good chunk of work done or just doing caudal work. Would go back if need be.
author: Tyler C.
